Subject: [sfraves] JON LEMMON & RICK PRESTON for a buck! <psb>

Hello all,

Hope you all had a wonderful Thanksgiving holiday weekend! Mine was off the 
hook.. Thanks to Gunnar, Stevian, Podge and Keep Tahoe Deep for having me 
play in Tahoe.. was the first, but certainly won't be the last.. if you 
haven't been to KTD on the last Saturday of the month, you're missing out 
for sure.. Well worth the trip!

Tonight we have a very special Secret Society.. After some developments over 
the weekend, we caught wind of an out of town DJ kickin' it in the South Bay 
tonight, so we asked him if he'd like to come down and play some tunes for 
us.. He graciously accepted and asked if he could have a friend play with 
him.. So tonight, although not our normal 2nd Monday of the month, come down 
to the Savoy for a special treat.. Due to the re-working of the schedule, 
this may be the last Secret Society of 2003.. we're not sure if we'll be 
back next week, or next year.. You should come get your fix tonight! Also, 
for those in the know.. I'll have STICKY! Invitations available tonight.. 
Email me if you haven't heard and/or you want more info! See you tonight..

Secret Society -- Monday December 1
A Reunion of People, A Revival of Culture

First time Secret Society appearance!

JON LEMMON (VIVA! RECORDINGS)
along w/ label mate
RICK PRESTON (VIVA! RECORDINGS, GLASGOW UNDERGROUND)
with residents:
JUSTIN HALE
KEVIN JAMES
Full Powered Sound By Twilight Studios
Full Visual Control By Viberation

POWER HOUR -- $1 draft beers for from 10pm to 11pm

9pm to close
21+ please
$1 cover

Secret Society -- The South Bay's Greatest Monday Night Bash
The Legendary Club Savoy
3546 Flora Vista Avenue
Santa Clara, CA 95051
408.244.6909
Secret Society continues in loving memory of Chris "Laffy" Taflanidis. We 
miss you brother. ESCT



Jon Lemmon Bio ---

Seattle native Jon Lemmon, through hard work and devotion, has developed his 
musical taste into a necessity in the Northwest house music community. 
Having heard his musical calling at the wee age of five years old, he 
learned to play a wide range of instruments until 1986 when he discovered 
turntables and new horizons unfolded, pointing the way that would become 
Jon's musical path. While his initial tastes laid in post-disco electronic 
sounds he discovered house music two years later, and has yet to look back.
Over the next eight years he made the move to Louisiana and helped foster 
the local scene (and in turn, his creativity) before coming home in 1995 to 
a blossoming Seattle house scene and quickly set up residencies around the 
city and gigs around the world. In 1998 Jon launched Viva Recordings and hit 
the ground running with releases from some of the most respected names in 
the house music community. Jon's breadth of experience and his ear for 
quality music has lent to his success thus far and will only assist him in 
his plan for world domination.

----- Original Message ----- 
From: "ravah luv" <ravahluv@hotmail.com>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Saturday, November 29, 2003 8:48 PM
Subject: [sfraves] NRR: Please consider signing gay marriage petition


> Hi all-
>
> So I don't post too often, and never on politial issues, but I'm hoping some
> of you will consider signing the million gay marriage petition.  The rave
> scene has always historically been about accepting everyone, peace, live and
> let live... everything that the right wing conservatives, well, aren't.
>
> The religious right is trying to amend the constitution of the United States
> to make gay marriage "or the legal incidents thereof" illegal forever...
>
> Most people don't care so much about the word "marriage," but the "legal
> incidents thereof" part will erase civil unions, domestic partnerships -
> things like hospital visitation rights, adoption, owning property, joint
> health care... the saddest thing about about it is that all the gay and
> lesbian families and their kids will have no legal protections whatsoever,
> and even progressive states like California will be legally unable to
> provide them with any.
>
> Also, note the difference between civil marriage (and civil unions, domestic
> partnerships, etc.) and religious marriage... no religious organizations are
> forced to perform same sex unions if they don't want to, and never would be
> - this is NOT a push for religious marriage, but rather to keep basic civil
> rights, like adopting your partners kids, visiting your partner in the
> hospital, buying a house together, etc.
>
> http://www.hrc.org/millionformarriage/index.shtml
>
> Thats the link, and thanks for your time-
> B

Today is World Aids Day.  As with Patrick (whose remembrance appears 
below), my life has forever been changed by this disease.  So many dancers, 
good friends, and lovers taken by Aids.  And it continues....

A WORLD AIDS DAY REMEMBRANCE

Patrick Letellier, AlterNet
AIDS has taken some of the people I loved most in the world; people I loved 
fiercely, passionately, and entirely.
http://www.alternet.org/story.html?StoryID=17255


Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm




"A human being is part of a whole, called by us the 'Universe,' a part 
limited in time and space. He experiences himself, his thoughts and 
feelings, as something separated from the rest--a kind of optical delusion 
of his consciousness. This delusion is a kind of prison for us, restricting 
us to our personal desires and to affection for a few persons nearest us. 
Our task must be to free ourselves from this prison by widening our circles 
of compassion to embrace all living creatures and the whole of nature in 
its beauty."
-Albert Einstein

Subject: [sfraves] BFP - LiteBrite presents Northern Lights!  (B.latant F.riend P.romotion)

If you're not going to Sticky on the 13th, check this out!  Should be
fun..  For information on the Sticky Christmas cocktail party, hit me
up!  

--------------------------------------

Retro Diva, thegraymasquerade and Smoove present -  
 
*Club Lite Brite: Northern Lites
*Saturday, December 13th, 2003 9p - 2a. 
Rawhide 280 7th St. @ Folsom, 21+ w/ID 
http://www.litebrite.org/club
 

As winter approaches, the days get shorter, the temperature gets 
colder, the nights get longer, and we've got just the thing to rock 
your 
jingle bells and make it hotter!

Come and celebrate the holidays with us at Club Lite Brite. We'll have 
music pumping the heat back into you veins downstairs courtesy of 
Resident DJ *Smoove* "the red nose"  (*space cowboys*) with his 
merry cohort dj's "Dasher" *The Geometrist*  (*space cowboys*) and 
"Dancer" *Laird* (*golden gate recordings*).  Saturina "Ms. Freeze" 
will 
be putting the chill on upstairs and together they'll guide you on a 
journey through our Northern Lites!

If you're still feeling a bit on the icy side, then maybe our Naughty 
Mr. and Mrs. Santa Claus can warm you up. (Hey, what goes on in the 
North Pole, stays in the North Pole!)

After all that, if you're still feeling frigid, then warm up to the 
flames with a tasty drink as we bring you a Fire Performance by our 
sexy 
elves *Sintillation/Fire Pixie (Fire show begins @ 11:30pm.)* 

Dress in your favourite holiday attire and get in for only $10. If your

Santa suit and bells are out to the cleaners entrance fee is only $12.
 
Not enough fuzzies in your closet ? No problem,  get your holiday 
shopping done while you shake your booty.  We've got cute and cuddly 
fashions from the Cloud Factory Design Collective for your buying 
pleasure.
 
Great music, flaming elves, a blizzard of not-stop music, what else 
could we possibly give you? How about your favourite childhood toy. 
Yes, 
folks, the mighty super-sized Lite Brite will be on hand for you to 
show 
off your best yuletide creations.

So don't be shy, come on down to the Rawhide on December 13th and play 
with us. We promise not to run your grandma over with a reindeer.

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: Mars' Vinyl & Dubplates from Sonic Sunrise on ebay...The Next Generation - 2 days left [nrr]

Hey Everyone!

I have a collection of Mars' Dubplates from his new CD Sonic Sunrise and
some out of print tracks also available on ebay now.  There are 2 days left
in the auctions so if you're interested in the vinyl listed, then you better
get crackin'..hehe..

The Dubplates are of course unreleased material and available on the sonic
sunrise cd.  The vinyl releases of the Mars' dubs won't be available for
several years so this is a once in a year-or-so time to get a hold of them
while they're available now.  If you guys have any questions about the
plates or vinyl, let me know privately.  :o)

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] NRR physical sciences: matrix and thermodynamics



An excerpt from "The World Almanac and Book of Facts 2003:"
"Experimenters at the Australian National University in Canberra and Griffith 
Univ. in Brisbane established that, over a short time period, nano-machines 
can violate the 2nd law of thermodynamics.  They came to this conclusion in a 
paper published in the July 29 issue of Physical Review Letters.  The 2nd law 
says that, for an enclosed system, disorder increases; for example, it is 
impossible to use the heat energy in a glass of water-- that is, the energy of the 
molecules of water jiggling around-- to run a machine and leave behind a 
cooler glass of water, or perhaps just ice.  That would clearly violate the 2nd 
law.  The 2nd law is admittedly regarded as a statistical law, which applies with 
perfect accuracy only when vast numbers of atoms are involved (objects on a 
human scale involve trillions of particles).  The Australian experiment 
involved the movement of a tiny bead (micron-sized, or about 1/4000 inch wide) 
through water.  A laser was used to position the bead--in effect, pulling the bead.  
But even though the bead was tiny, millions of atoms were still involved.  In 
the experiment, friction-- the 2nd law in effect-- would usually resist the 
movement of the bead, but sometimes (although not for more than 2 seconds at a 
time) the water would push the bead in the direction it was being pulled, in 
effect extracting heat extracting heat from the water to do work, in apparent 
violation of the second law.  Scientists voiced surprise at the result.  
Researchers said it meant the new field of nano-technology might have to take into 
account unusual phenomena that could make nano-machines run backwards for brief 
periods. Denis Evans, one of the researchers, indicated there also might be 
implications for biology, since many life processes involve systems on similar 
size scales as those in the experiment.

Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  The Future of Drug Testing

--=====================_6803012==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

***************************
The Future of Drug Testing
***************************
Wired Magazine reports on a new drug-detection patch under development
by SpectRx. "For the monitor to work, employees first have to have four
microscopic holes -- about the size of a human hair -- burnt into the
outer layer of their skin by a handheld laser... The oval patch houses a
miniature vacuum pump that sucks out interstitial fluid, a clear,
water-like fluid that surrounds cells in the body.") When a drug is
detected, a miniature transmitter sends out an alert signal.

 >> Read More at:

http://www.cognitiveliberty.org/topnews.html




Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no 
safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring 
adventure or nothing."
-Helen Keller

-Spanish Proverb

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Subject: RE: [sfraves] NRR: The Future of Drug Testing

That's pretty intense.  I study Cellular Bio and I wasn't even aware of the 
presence of some substances that get stored in the extracellular matrix.  I 
can't imagine subjecting myself to being "lasered" unless it was a job that 
I really-really wanted.  I think that technology is going to be pretty 
expensive for McDonald's to try to implicate on its applicants.  I wouldn't 
really worry about it all that much.

>From: Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org>

>Date: Mon, 01 Dec 2003 16:05:11 -0800

>***************************
>The Future of Drug Testing
>***************************
>Wired Magazine reports on a new drug-detection patch under development
>by SpectRx. "For the monitor to work, employees first have to have four
>microscopic holes -- about the size of a human hair -- burnt into the
>outer layer of their skin by a handheld laser... The oval patch houses a
>miniature vacuum pump that sucks out interstitial fluid, a clear,
>water-like fluid that surrounds cells in the body.") When a drug is
>detected, a miniature transmitter sends out an alert signal.
>
> >> Read More at:
>
>http://www.cognitiveliberty.org/topnews.html
>

i want to hear some Electro too ... but to me, "Electro" as part of Skills' 
"Elektro-Tekno-Disko" theme doesn't refer to Electro music; it's part of a 
playful, tongue-in-cheek reference to electronic dance music in general. It 
doesn't mean they feature actual Electro, Techno, or Disco, although I wouldn't be 
surprised to hear Enemy or one of the others throw down some techno tracks. I 
sure as hell don't want to hear any actual "Disco"; had more than enough in my 
early days of clubbing (yes, I actually remember when clubs would close with 
Donna Summer's "Last Dance" -- gawd what a cliche!). 

It's like when Eminem says "nobody listens to techno." I really seriously 
doubt he means real Detroit-style Techno. He's speaking generically and means, 
"THAT SHIT MUSIC THAT MOBY MAKES" since we know he hates Moby. He means "people 
listen to rap, not that 'techno' shit." 

Anyhow ... at any Skills party you can expect to hear a lot of Trance, some 
NRG, and usually some Jungle. As big parties go, their parties are excellent; 
much better and more honest than a Coolworld party. 
I'm going to go to it, for sure. I don't think I've missed a single Skills 
party! Good memories ... anybody remember "Tronic & The Magic Bubbles" and 
"Trancegiving" in 1999. Fun times.
JonnyR    

-------------------------------1070393607--

Subject: [sfraves] FW: happy holidays! (nrr)

Thought this was a cute little piece. See for yourself...


>From: "Mike Schultz"
>To: sacraves@hyperreal.org
>Subject: happy holidays! (nrr)
>Date: Tue, 02 Dec 2003 14:40:15 -0800
>
>======================================================================
>
>  SANTA CLAUS: An Engineer's Perspective
>
>I. There are approximately two billion children
>persons under 18) in the world.  However, since Santa
>does not visit children of Muslim, Hindu, Jewish or
>Buddhist religions, this reduces the workload for
>Christmas night to 15% of the total, or 378 million
>(according to the Population Reference Bureau).  At an
>average (census)rate of 3.5 children per house hold,
>that comes to 108 million homes, presuming that there
>is at least one good child in each.
>
>II. Santa has about 31 hours of Christmas to work
>with, thanks to the different time zones and the
>rotation of the earth, assuming he travels east to
>west (which seems logical).  This works out to 967.7
>visits persecond. This is to say that for each
>Christian household with a good child, Santa has
>around 1/1000th of a second to park the sleigh, hop
>out, jump down the chimney, fill the stockings,
>distribute the remaining presents under the tree, eat
>whatever snacks have been left for him, get back up
>the chimney, jump into the sleigh and get on to the
>next house.
>
>(That's really why it's pointless to stay up and watch
>for him...)
>
>Assuming that each of these 108 million stops is
>evenly distributed around the earth (which, of course,
>we know to be false, but will accept for the purposes
>of our calculations), we are now talking about 0.78
>miles per household; a total trip of 75.5 million
>miles, not counting bathroom stops or breaks.  This
>means Santa's sleigh is moving at 650 miles per second
>--- 3,000 times the speed of sound.  For purposes of
>comparison, the fastest man-made vehicle, the Ulysses
>space probe, moves at a poky 27.4 miles per second,
>and a conventional reindeer can run (at best) 15 miles
>per hour.
>
>III.  The payload of the sleigh adds another
>interesting element.  Assuming that each child gets
>nothing more than a medium sized Lego set (two
>pounds), the sleigh is carrying over 500 thousand
>tons, not counting Santa himself.  On land, a
>conventional reindeer can pull no more than 300
>pounds.  Even granting that the "flying" reindeer
>could pull ten times the normal amount, the job  
>can't be done with eight or even nine of them ---
>Santa would need 360,000 of them.  This increases the
>payload, not counting the weight of the sleigh,
>another 54,000 tons, or roughly seven times the weight
>of the Queen Elizabeth (the ship, not the monarch).
>
>IV. 600,000 tons traveling at 650 miles per second
>creates enormous air resistance --- this would heat up
>the reindeer in the same fashion as a spacecraft
>re-entering the earth's atmosphere.  The lead pair of
>reindeer would absorb 14.3 quintillion joules of
>energy per second each.  In short, they would burst
>into flames almost instantaneously, exposing the
>reindeer behind them and creating deafening sonic
>booms in their wake.  The entire reindeer team would
>be vaporized within 4.26 thousandths of a second, or
>right about the time Santa reached the fifth house on
>his trip. Not that it matters, however, since Santa,
>as a result of accellerating from a dead stop to 650
>m.p.s. in .001 seconds, would be subjected to
>centrifugal forces of 17,500 g's.  A 250 pound Santa
>(which seems ludicrously  slim) would be pinned to the
>back of the sleigh by 4,315,015 pounds of force,
>instantly crushing his bones and organs and reducing
>him to a quivering blob of pink goo.
>
>V.  Therefore, if Santa did exist, he's dead now.
>
>_________________________________________________________________
>Has one of the new viruses infected your computer?  Find out with a FREE 
>online computer virus scan from McAfee. Take the FreeScan now!  
>http://clinic.mcafee.com/clinic/ibuy/campaign.asp?cid=3963
>

_________________________________________________________________

months @ $9.95/month now! http://join.msn.com/?page=dept/dialup

Subject: RE: [sfraves] NRR -=-  Soda Machines in schools.

I'm long past school and don't really plan on having kids anytime in the
near future, but I think the addition of fast food is better than the
crap they served in school when I went.  I mean, healthy?  Not even
remotely.  We had some fast food added to my high school my junior year
and they had a pizza hut with good salads for the same price as mystery
meat and lumpy milk.  Fast food may not be the best thing, but the kids
will eat it over the lunchroom crap and maybe someone will get a good
salad bar in there too at some point.

-Rayn

Subject: [sfraves] BSP:  Get Freaky This Friday

--=====================_7683137==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

FRIDAY DECEMBER 5TH
<<<GET FREAKY>>>

Adam Freeland (Marine Parade UK)
One of the pioneers of the breaks genre of music and founder
of Marine Parade Records in London, plus has made it into the
top 50 DJs in the world few years runnnig in DJ Magazine UK.
his latest tracks including the huge international hit "we want your soul"
which takes a jab at american corporate greed and mass consumerism
,which I am shure most of you have heard plenty of times on the dance floor.
adam Is on an international tour promoting his new album "Now and Them"
this will be your only chance to see him in the Bay area for a while. for more
info check out www.freeland.fm

KraftyKuts (Fingerlickin Records UK)
A man of many faces and talents and DJ's DJ. Krafty will be playing 2 sets
one in the main room doing breaks and the other in the green room doing
a funky Hip Hop oriented set. Besides releasing on major breaks label
fingerlickin he also runs top breaks labels Supercharged and against the grain
and has been the man behind alot of the top ragga and dub infused breaks
tracks around. They are still cleaning off the sweat from the last party he 
played
at in SF earlier in the year. there is not a set that me or Lorin or any 
breaks DJ
that dosent includes some track by krafty kuts.
Miss these sets at your own peril. www.figerlicking.co.uk

Plus we have what must be one of the best local lineups ever at a party 
here in SF:

Adam Ohana (an-ten-nae.net/get freaky)
Lorin (bassnectar.net)
Random Rab Live! (El Circo)
Bencun (False Profit)
Nep-tune (groovepharm)
Ikarus (Infinite Kaos)
andres Octavio (stress collective)
waterjuice (vaporvent)
Eve (get Freaky)
Shawna (Apsara)
Laura (EFL)
Dragonfly (Groovegraden)
Neal (SF)

there will also be an appearance by the next mayor of
san francisco Matt Gonzales who is a big supporter
of late night events and progressive culture
please vote for him.
plus

multi screen visuals by spook chaos cosortium)
Decor (fuzzy Philippe's Fabulous fluff
altars Huggi Ma

space 550 - 550 Barneveld SF CA 94124
21+ $15 presale (plus you get to cut the line)
$20 at the door online tickets @ www.groovetickets.com
just put a search for get freaky to find the page.
I also link to it from the website in the events section
www.an-ten-nae.net/events.html
tickets are available locally at Distractionson haight st.
and skills dj workshop in berkeley.

Its gonna be off tha hook so please get presale tickets
and let your friends no about it so we can take over the
venue for the night and close the doors ;)
please help spread the word.



Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Security is mostly a superstition.  It does not exist in nature, nor do 
the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no 
safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring 
adventure or nothing."
-Helen Keller

"Beware of being too rational.  In the country of the insane, the 
integrated man doesn't become king.  He gets lynched."
-Aldous Huxley, Island

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Subject: [sfraves] [SRR]A major retraction (Ecstasy not as bad as scientists implied)

------=_NextPart_000_0018_01C3B997.32042AC0
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

This is just something I thought I would share it isn't for, against, or
stating my beliefs.

 

http://www.nytimes.com/2003/12/02/science/02ECST.html?8hpib

 

New York Times | 2 Dec 2003

 

Research on Ecstasy Is Clouded by Errors

 

   By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

 

   In September, the journal Science issued a startling retraction.

 

   A primate study it published in 2002, with heavy publicity, warned

   that the amount of the drug Ecstasy that a typical user consumes in a

   single night might cause permanent brain damage.

 

   It turned out that the $1.3 million study, led by Dr. George A.

   Ricaurte of Johns Hopkins University, had not used Ecstasy at all.
His

   10 squirrel monkeys and baboons had instead been injected with

   overdoses of methamphetamine, and two of them had died. The labels on

   two vials he bought in 2000, he said, were somehow switched.

 

   The problem corrupted four other studies in his lab, forcing him to

   withdraw four other papers.

 

   It was not the first time Dr. Ricaurte's lab was accused of using

   flawed studies to suggest that recreational drugs are highly

   dangerous. In previous years he was accused of publicizing doubtful

   results without checking them, and was criticized for research that

   contributed to a government campaign suggesting that Ecstasy made

   "holes in the brain."

 

   [...]

 

   Pictures from the study PET -- scans of the brains of Ecstasy users
--

   were

   used on a famous postcard from the drug agency, "Plain Brain/Brain

   After Ecstasy." The postcards were distributed to thousands of

   teenagers and implied that Ecstasy users had shrunken brains with

   holes in them.

 

   The study had nothing to do with holes, but with serotonin levels,

   which Dr. Ricaurte found drastically depleted in 14 subjects who had

   taken Ecstasy 70 to 400 times.

 

   Dr. Marc Laruelle, a Columbia University PET scan specialist, called

   the work so technically flawed that it was "something to put under
the

   rug." He cited a recent German study showing that serotonin decreased

   only modestly and returned to normal within six weeks. The Hopkins

   team, he said, presented its data in logarithmically compressed
graphs

   that seemed calculated to mask the fact that it had found impossible

   results: its 15 "control" subjects had serotonin levels 50 times

   normal.

 

   Dr. Ricaurte defended the study, saying his recalculation technique

   was common when results from two groups varied widely, although he

   said he no longer used it.

 

   Of the photos, Dr. Ricaurte said he had no control over what the

   national drug institute did with his work, but he had asked an agency

   official to fix their "poor quality."


------=_NextPart_000_0018_01C3B997.32042AC0--

From: AndyW <andy@saturn5.com>
X-X-Sender: andy@atari
To: fishinoutonthefloorfacefirst <yomommasabama@yahoo.com>
cc: _ fable _ <fable4our@hotmail.com>, <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
In-Reply-To: <20031203182815.61390.qmail@web21324.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0312031320230.13005-100000@atari>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves]NRR: How many peeps can fit 3000 sq ft venue?


On Wed, 3 Dec 2003, fishinoutonthefloorfacefirst wrote:
-&e->it usually goes by square footage per person.  check the local gov't
-&e->statutes.
-&e->
-&e->maybe 3 square ft per person?

More like 9 (tops for a standing row concert venue or other "standing"
type situation), but you usually run into fire exit and other limiting
factors first.  For dining or table seating, you'll find that it's way
more space per person than that (which I assume you'll be seeing a lot of
in your lounge).

Imagine the most crowded undergrounds you've been to, and that's around 4
square feet per person (too crowded to dance really, that's just a 2x2'
square - I've actually been to rock/punk shows where people started
falling over and causing little domino effects at that density... not safe
for sure).

Regarding exits, there's some math they do, assuming people are 3'x3', you
can get one person at a time out a door every two seconds, and for fire
codes you have to be able to empty your capacity within two minutes so
every standard door is good for 60 people of capacity.  Other factors like
sprinkler system, overall fire rating (100% concrete is less flammable
than a movie theater with fabric all over the place), detection equipment
present and ceiling height (taller ceiling means more time to get out
before flashpoint and CO oxygen displacement occurs) also come into play.

Of course, your results may differ.  I've been working parties where two
people have given me way different numbers on capacity... even fire /
safety personnel that are familiar with the space.

andyw

Subject: [sfraves] music industry keeps going after the little guys

summary:  ASCAP can sue venue owners if bands playing at the venue play a 
cover of a copywritten song.

full story is here:

URL: 
sfgate.com/article.cgi?file=/chronicle/archive/2003/12/03/BUGL13CH5H26.DTL

what's next?  karaoke bars or...gasp....DJs that play other people's music!?

<clip>
In the past few years, Skip's also became home to a small but burgeoning 
music scene, even as live music declined in the rest of the city. Bands with 
names like the Lab Rats and Thunder Blue staged marathon jam sessions that 
attracted crowds that often spilled onto the sidewalk.

But the stage at Skip's has been silent since Oct. 1, when owner Bill 
Courtright pulled the plug after deciding that offering live music wasn't 
worth the legal trouble it was attracting.

Twice in less than a year, Courtright was sued for copyright infringement by 
the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers, which collects 
royalty payments for copyright holders and represents them in legal 
disputes.

"I wasn't going to wait for a third lawsuit," said Courtright, who has owned 
Skip's since 1990.

As record companies conduct a much-publicized effort to crack down on 
Internet music downloads, Courtright's bitter legal dispute shows how small- 
club owners, simply by providing a venue to local musicians, can run afoul 
of the guardians of copyrighted music.

Courtright's troubles began in September 2002, when he received a letter 
claiming that a private investigator hired by ASCAP heard musicians playing 
covers of copyrighted songs at Skip's on June 22, 2002.

The letter, from the San Francisco office of the law firm Heller Ehrman 
White & McAuliffe, threatened a lawsuit.

Under copyright law, Courtright can be held liable for the copyright 
infringements at his club because he never purchased a license from ASCAP.
</clip>

Subject: [sfraves] FYI: BART is FREE on Thursday, December 4 (tomorrow) from 4am to 9am

Free Morning Commute on BART: On December 4th, BART will be free from 4
a.m. until 9 a.m. This is an opportunity to reward regular BART
commuters with a free ride and draw new commuters onto BART. Customers
will be able to enter BART faregates at no cost and with no BART ticket
required (although a ticket will be needed for return trips later that
day.) Daily parking fees at the Westbay and Lake Merritt stations will
also be free that day. A recent study reveals that the average Bay Area
commuter waste 42 hours a year sitting in traffic and by taking BART to
work commuters can save $20-40 a day in automobile costs. A person who
commutes on BART instead of driving can avoid 5 tons of auto pollution.
Further BART riders achieve the equivalent of 250 miles per gallon on
BART =96 about 10 times the fuel economy of a typical car. Questions can
be directed to the BART Marketing Department at (510) 464-7161. The
free morning commute on BART is courtesy of ING Director, an on-line
savings bank and the sponsor of this promotion.=

Subject: RE: [sfraves] music industry keeps going after the little guys

> The license for Skip's, which is based on the club's seating capacity,
> number of nights per week that music is performed and whether it's
> played live or by a disc jockey or jukebox, would cost Courtright $698 per year.
>
> Reimer said his group first sent a letter asking Courtright to buy a
> license in 1997."


The guy is fighting a license fee of $59 a month, or about $2 a night.

ASCAP licensing has been in place for a while (I'm sure google will give
more details than you'd ever want to know). Technically, any business that
plays music that is published by an ASCAP member artist has to have an
ASCAP license. This includes cafes, bars (the jukebox probably has an
ASCAP license sticker), and yes, live performance venues.

This system is arguably a good thing, because it allows anybody to play
other people's music as long as they pay the license fee, without having
to negotiate with the author of each copyrighted work directly.

From: JonnyR@aol.com
Message-ID: <140.1debafdc.2cffd69f@aol.com>
Date: Wed, 3 Dec 2003 19:15:27 EST
To: yomommasabama@yahoo.com, invibe@hotmail.com, sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative; boundary="-----------------------------1070496927"
X-Mailer: 9.0 for Windows sub 5002
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] music industry keeps going after the little guys

-------------------------------1070496927
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

I'm sure that if the industry hires private investigators, the PIs are bonded 
or have some way of certifying that they're telling the truth. If they keep a 
written log of the songs, that's probably evidence enough that the song was 
played. I know that radio DJs have to keep a log of what they play so that 
ASCAP or BMI can be paid.

Almost all songs are copyrighted. Almost any cover song is subject tp 
payments to either ASCAP or BMI. If you're playing something that's in the public 
domain, that's up for grabs. For example, if you play Mozart, his heirs don't 
collect money from performances of his work, and there is no payment to ASCAP or 
BMI. You can play music by long-dead blues musicians and even copyright a new 
version with your name on it. (In the late 60s Led Zeppelin got away with 
using old blues songs and claiming them as their own, earning royalties, rather 
than just saying the songs were "traditional.")

The rule was something like this: the artistic creation (song) is protected 
by copyright law until 50 years after it's created. I believe it was changed to 
50 years after the death of the creator, which extended the protection. So, 
all those 800 albums a year by the supposedly dead Tupac ... 50 years after his 
death, his music will be in the public domain so they better sell what they 
can, now. 
This might not be 100% right as there have been changes to copyright law, but 
I hope this sheds a little light on the subject. 

-------------------------------1070496927--

X-Mailer: Apple Mail (2.552)

Subject: [sfraves] Booze it up! Tomorrow is 70th anniversary of Prohibition Repeal   8)

--Apple-Mail-4--151852272
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset=ISO-8859-1;
	format=flowed

Criminalization Doesn't Curb Booze, Drug Use
Wednesday, December 03, 2003
By Radley Balko

The great journalist H.L. Mencken was a fierce critic of alcohol=20
prohibition. He wrote in 1925:

"Five years of Prohibition have had, at least, this one benign=20
effect:=A0they have completely disposed of all the favorite arguments of=20=

he Prohibitionists. None of the great boons and usufructs that were to=20=

follow the passage of the Eighteenth Amendment has come to pass. There=20=

is not less drunkenness in the Republic, but more. There is not less=20
crime, but more. There is not less insanity, but more. The cost of=20
government is not smaller, but vastly greater. Respect for law has not=20=

increased, but diminished."

Mencken was right, which is why Prohibition was repealed in 1933, 70=20
years ago tomorrow.=A0

No amount of legislation could curb America's taste for booze. What=20
Prohibition did do=A0was create a lucrative black market for booze=A0and=20=

invite the ancillary crime -- organized and otherwise -- that comes=20
with it.=A0The corruption of the bootlegging industry infected every=20
level of law enforcement. Local cops and prosecutors, members of=20
Congress (which had its own private stock of liquor) --even President=20
William Harding's Attorney General -- were buyable, bribable, and to=20
coin a word, imbibable.

Forcing Americans to go underground to satiate their thirst for alcohol=20=

also brought with it a major public health problem.=A0Americans drank=20
harder, because they had to get their fix in one sitting, and didn't=20
know where or when they'd get their next drink. And they drank more=20
potent stuff -- bathtub gin and other home-brewed spirits, liquor that=20=

was unchecked by market forces or regulators, and so was not only vile=20=

and potent, but could at times be downright poisonous. By the mid=20
1920s, hospitalizations and deaths from alcohol poisoning soared. Some=20=

say we have Prohibition to thank for the success of the cocktail, as=20
the only available alcohol was virtually undrinkable straight-up.=A0

What's unfortunate is that our lawmakers still haven't learned the=20
lessons of Prohibition.=A0

For the last 40 years, for example, we've engaged in a Prohibition of a=20=

different kind -- drug prohibition. The similarities are striking.

Despite harsher sentences, increased funding for law enforcement, more=20=

prisons, expensive public relations campaigns and frightening=20
trespasses on our civil liberties, Americans still generally use=20
illicit drugs with the same frequency they have since the drug war=20
began, according to the=A0National Survey on Drug Use and Health.=A0

Different drugs come in and out of vogue, but the percentage of the=20
populace using them=A0=A0has largely remained the same for 30 years.=A0The=
=20
only difference is, as we make access to those drugs more and more=20
difficult, the drugs become more expensive, making the drug trade more=20=

and more lucrative, meaning pushers will go to greater lengths and take=20=

greater risks because users will pay more money to get them.

The drug war has made war zones of some urban areas in much the same=20
way Prohibition famously turned sections of Chicago into public=20
shooting galleries. We've made millionaires of cocaine and heroin=20
cartels in the same way temperance=A0made wealthy men of=A0Al Capone and=20=

George Remus. And we've made hardened criminals of small-time dope=20
dealers the way alcohol Prohibition made felons of bartenders and=20
distillers. The number of people behind bars in the United States for=20
drug crimes alone now exceeds the number of people in prison in Europe=20=

for all crimes combined.

Now, increasingly, states and municipalities are going after tobacco,=20
too, believing that higher taxes and bans on public smoking will=20
persuade longtime smokers to quit. In New York City, which has long=20
imposed a cigarette tax that is among the highest in the nation, a=20
thriving black market for tobacco has emerged, serving as a copious=20
source of funding for organized crime and smugglers, as well=20
as=A0international terrorist organizations like=A0Hezbollah=A0and=A0al-Qae=
da.

The states of California, Delaware and New York now forbid smoking in=20
public places. In the late 1990s, Canada experimented with an=20
aggressive hike on cigarette taxes. The tax resulted in such an=20
overwhelming wave of black market crime that lawmakers repealed the tax=20=

two years later. The United Kingdom has the highest cigarette taxes in=20=

Europe. Consequently, the UK has become a hub for international=20
cigarette smuggling, the beneficiaries of which include such nefarious=20=

elements as the Irish Republican Army and the Italian mafia, among=20
others.

American lawmakers haven't even=A0learned the lessons of Prohibition =
when=20
it comes to alcohol. In the last 10 years, a well-funded group of=20
neo-prohibitionist advocacy groups have sprung up and have begun=20
calling for a variety of public policy initiatives aimed squarely at=20
restricting (again) the public's access to alcohol. Groups such as=20
the=A0Center for Science in the Public Interest, the Center for Alcohol=20=

Marketing to Youth, and the Center on Addiction and Substance Abuse=20
advocate such=A0initiatives=A0as raising taxes on alcohol, forbidding=20
alcohol manufacturers from advertising, using zoning laws to limit=20
the=A0number of bars and liquor stores in a particular neighborhood, and=20=

making it more difficult for restaurants and pubs to obtain liquor=20
licenses.

The hard lesson we should have--but have not--learned from=A0our various=20=

"prohibitions" is that no amount of legislation or social=20
engineering=A0is going to prevent some segments of the=20
population=A0from=A0using substances many of the rest of us disapprove =
of.=A0=20
=A0 =A0

Perhaps our lawmakers will soon learn that we can't simply legislate=20
away the supply or the demand for Americans' more piacular appetites,=20
no matter how distasteful we may find them. Certainly, there are people=20=

who abuse controlled substances. But the better course of action=A0would=20=

be=A0to deal with the individual.=A0Sweeping, expensive, far-reaching =
bans,=20
prohibitions and declarations of war have never worked, and history=20
proves that they invite far more problems than they solve.

Radley Balko is a freelance writer and publisher of the=20
weblog:=A0TheAgitator.com.=A0 He's also the author of the new Cato=20
Institute paper, "Back Door to Prohibition: The New War on Social=20
Drinking."

...
http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,104757,00.html=

--Apple-Mail-4--151852272--

In a message dated 12/3/03 4:40:47 PM Pacific Standard Time, 
electrofunk138@hotmail.com writes:
going after a bar-owner because some band played a COVER SONG, is 
fucking retarded.
I agree, but I think the logic is that if you have some unknown band playing 
their own songs, nobody would go, and they wouldn't sell any drinks. So, by 
allowing covers to be played, the bar makes more money and therefore needs to 
give a little chunk to the licensers of the songs. 
ASCAP and BMI are desperate for money because music sales are down, so 
they're trying to squeeze it wherever they can. 

-------------------------------1070498753--

On Wed, 3 Dec 2003, Van Mundegaarde wrote:
-&e->Yea, but going after a bar-owner because some band played a COVER
-&e->SONG, is fucking retarded. I understand why they do that for places
-&e->that use jukeboxes or radio stations, but that's just taking it to
-&e->the extreme....

ASCAP is not the RIAA, and it's a good thing that songwriters can make a
bit of money when their song gets played at a commercial venue by someone
else.

Chances are it wasn't ONE band playing ONE cover, but rather the venue
featuring cover bands or jazz combos that rely heavily on standards
for material without ponying up to the ASCAP venue fees.

http://www.skipstavern.com/music/bands.php

This is a for profit establishment charging people to get in but not
paying anything to the authors of many of the works presented there.
ASCAP is a pretty decent organization and has protected the rights of the
original authors of works many times in cases against major record labels.

andyw

Subject: [sfraves] Music industry goes after Girl Scout campfire songs as well...not just bar music

-------------------------------1070500250
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Found this on the Internet, from earlier in the year: 

"Something is missing at Diablo Day Camp in Lafayette, Calif., this year. ... 
 Starting this summer, the American Society of Composers, Authors & 
Publishers has informed camps nationwide that they must pay license fees to use any of 
the four million copyrighted songs written or published by Ascap's 68,000 
members. Those who sing or play but don't pay, Ascap warns, may be violating the 
law. 
 Like restaurants, hotels, bars, stores and clubs, which already pay fees to 
use copyrighted music, camps -- including non-profit ones such as those run by 
the Girl Scouts -- are being told to ante up. The demand covers not only 
recorded music but also songs around the campfire.  ...  No more "Edelweiss" free 
of charge. No more "This Land Is Your Land." An Ascap spokesman says "Kumbaya" 
isn't on its list, but "God Bless America" is. 
 Diablo, an all-volunteer day camp that charges girls $44 a week to cover 
expenses, would owe Ascap $591 this year, based on the camp's size and how long 
it runs.  ... . 
 "At first I thought, 'You guys have got to be kidding,"' says Sharon Kosch, 
the council's director of program services. "They can't sing the songs? But 
it's pretty threatening. We were told the penalty can be $5,000 and six days in 
jail." 
 So, the camp's directors have scrutinized its official "Elf Manual" and, in 
the section headed "Favorite Songs at Diablo Day Camp," have crossed out the 
most popular copyrighted tunes with black Magic Marker. ...
 "We wanted to sing 'Underwear,' but it's set to the tune of 'Battle Hymn of 
the Republic,"' says Mrs. King, the co-director. "We're not sure if that's 
copyrighted; so, we don't sing it." 
 "When in doubt, don't sing," advises Site Director Leslie Shanders. 
 Even harder than figuring out which songs are which, directors say, is 
explaining it all to young Brownies. "They think copyright means the 'mean people,' 
" says Debby Cwalina, a 14-year-old Elf. Mr. Holly explains it to them this 
way: "The people who wrote it have a thing on it. A little 'c' with circles 
around it. There's an alarm on it. And if you sing it, BOOM!" 
 That explanation doesn't always sink in. Alissa Fiset, age 8, crinkles her 
nose when asked why she can't sing "Puff the Magic Dragon." While squirting a 
friend with a water bottle, she says: "They did a rewrite on it. A copy thing. 
But why can't they just take the 'c' away?" 
...
 The federal copyright act allows composers and music publishers to demand 
royalty payments for any public performance of copyrighted material. The law 
defines a public performance as "where a substantial number of persons outside of 
a normal circle of a family and its social acquaintances is gathered." 
Although the law has been on the books since 1909, Ascap began notifying large music 
users, such as hotels, only a little over a decade ago and more recently has 
worked its way down to small users, such as rodeos and funeral homes. This 
year, it negotiated a reduced annual fee of $257 with camps enrolled in the 
American Camping Association. For camps, such as Diablo, that aren't association 
members, the fees are higher, ranging from $308 to $1,439 a year. Small camps 
that last two weeks or less get a special rate of $77. 
 Penalties for noncompliance can be stiff. The law sets fines up to $25,000 
or a year in prison, or both, for major infringements. Ascap, which sends 
monitors around the country, has successfully sued restaurants, retailers and 
private clubs...
 Ascap contends that its members have contributed heavily to the Scouts over 
the years. In 1940, Irving Berlin donated all future royalties from his "God 
Bless America" to the New York City Boy Scout and Girl Scout councils. Although 
the Scouts still get royalties from it, Mr. Lo Frumento concedes that, 
nevertheless, they can't sing it without paying the fee. 
 So, it's back to black Magic Markers. 
 After finishing the Macarena at the Diablo sing-along, one mother whispers 
that today is the sixth birthday of David Warneke, a camp volunteer's son. 
"We're not allowed to sing 'Happy Birthday,' " warns Debi Jansen, a co-director. 
 Huddling with the Elves, the directors come up with a plan: Sing a modified 
"Happy Birthday" to the tune of "Ninety-Nine Bottles of Beer on the Wall." 
 But Mrs. Jansen is worried. "I hope that's not copyrighted, too," she frets. 
" [end quote]

Regarding Happy Birthday, Michael Jackson owned the copyright but I wouldn't 
be surprised if he sold it to pay his legal bills or food for his captive 
animals. 

-------------------------------1070500250--

Hi folks,
Plenty of San Francisco house in store today for An Epiphany of Sound.
We're bringing in Les Carter and Cronos today, starting with Les Carter.
Sure to bring you plenty of ass shakin house!  Do tune in!!  90.1 FM in
the bay area, or online at http://kzsulive.stanford.edu

Also, for you San Frandisco folks, don't forget to vote in next
Tuesday's election!  Both Mayor and D.A. offices are critical to our
scene.  (I myself endorse Gonzalez and Hallinan.  Gonzalez got an A+
rating from the Sierra Club, while Newsom got a D after all.)  You can
also submit an absentee ballot ahead of time at city hall (just take the
elevator down a floor and it's right there.)  That way you won't
possibly forget or run out of time on Tues.

Peace!

-- 
"To announce that there must be no criticism of the President or
that we are to stand by the President right or wrong is not only
unpatriotic and servile but it is morally treasonable to the
American public."

-Theodore Roosevelt, 1918

"Opinions are my own only, and do not necessarily represent those of
KZSU Radio or Stanford University." (or words to that effect.)

Subject: [sfraves] (bsp-ish)space for rent in the mission, live, rehearsal, art, storage...also need donated housestuff

--0-1409790386-1070577770=:16744
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

hey, all,  :)
we have a big rehearsal space (soundproofed room) and art/storage space available, also we have a 'writer/artist room' for rent, and 2 rooms for rent to live/work.  the rehearsal space is $15/hr, $25 for 2 hrs.. the rooms for rent range from $225-$400.
it's a big unfinished space, eventually it will be an art/music/performance coffee house kinda space.  but for now it's our big dirty hovel with potential.  it used to be mission records, now it's in transition.
as for the roommate part, we're looking for people who will invest time/work/$  into the place, in trade for big cool digs.
we need lots of donated stuff, too, house furnishings, electrical work, lighting, AV stuff (vhs projector, pa system), paint, furniture, etc..

hey, all, :)
we have a big rehearsal space (soundproofed room) and art/storage space available, also we have a 'writer/artist room' for rent, and 2 rooms for rent to live/work. the rehearsal space is $15/hr, $25 for 2 hrs.. the rooms for rent range from $225-$400.

we need lots of donated stuff, too, house furnishings, electrical work, lighting, AV stuff (vhs projector, pa system), paint, furniture, etc..
sooooooooo..... email me if interested, or if you'd like to get involved somehow.  we need lots of help, but this place will be dope when it's done.  :)

musical program

The Wind Ensemble
Tonight - Friday December 5th - 7:30pm @ SJSU Concert Hall

Conductor - Edward Harris
Percussion - Galen Lemmon
and SJSU Concert Choir Conductor - Elena Sharkova

The program features...

Joseph Schwantner - Concerto for Percussion
Aarom Copland - Old American Songs

I know some of you in college need to attend musical concerts for credit =
so this is your chance.  It's going to be an awesome show and for once, =
you don't have to listen to something that has a beat of some sort... =
(Well the percussion piece is gonna be awesome..hehe).

Anyway I hope to see you guys out there.  The Music Hall is located in =
the Music Building at San Jose State!

Subject: [sfraves] MEeeeeoooOW... BAD KITTY last night was fun!

OK... so i was probably there for the total of like an hour 'cause ofcourse I gotta go there after class & hang out b4 the last bart train runs 2 ElCerrito la la la... buyt man.. it was Bad Ass last night... Felix The Woof Woof Dog was on the decks & he was spinning this crazy electro clash set... it was fun... but man... ok... then he mixed in this totally classic Breakbeats song... I mean... seriously... from like 1983... but like @ a totallly slow pace... so like it was fun, but weird 'cause well.. ya know... it was slow... but it was Fun still! =)

It was totally a Groovy night there also...I ran in2 2 old Homies who I haven't seeeeeeen in like 43ever... Al & Brett... Love those guys... I mean... they always helped me out earlier this year & I consider those 2 2 of my closest bros 4 that!!  So that was fun!!  I mean... we had soooooo much 2 catch up on & well... I dunno if y'all remember me talkin' about Al in like mondo past posts... but he's the dude who I can always Groove w/ on the floor & we always used 2 battle each other during Jungle sets all the time & I swear man... HOmeboy got moves... 

Then what kinda sucked 'cause 11 struck & I had 2 catch bart & Forest fuckin' walks in... so we talk & hug & kiss 2 like 3 minutes... man... she had this awesome glow lastnight & she ws in total good spirits... it was Groovy...

What sucked even more was when I was almost out the door... then I saw Serapim who I was looking 4 the whole time I was there & it was CooL 'cause well... I don't get enough Seraphim as of the past few months... so I think I'm still like getting my fill... I mean.. I miss that girl when I don't see her 4 long periods of time & well... goin' 2 Bad Kitty helps 4 as long as I can stay there b4 I go so I can spend some time catchin' up w/ my homegirl=)  Hey Sweetie.. congrats on the new gig!! If U need help w/ any updates on anything or new stuff goin on... let me know! =)

The crowd there was pretty Groovy... I mean... there were what seemed like a good bunch of preppy people, but a few of them were kinda dancing & was diggin' Felix's set... well.. it was pretty much a mix crowd there... but it was all Groovy people though & I had fun for as long as I was there... I mean.. the dance flor ain't all to big either, but it's fun though & there is enough room 2 get your groove on... I have fun when I go there each time.. =)

Anywaze... that was my Thursday night... YAAAAAY! =)  Hey.. go 2 Bad Kitty next week & let's hang out! =)

Subject: [sfraves] DEA Tries RAVE Act Intimidation Again, But Activists
  Successfully Fight Back

--=====================_6081594==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

Newsbrief: DEA Tries RAVE Act Intimidation Again, But Activists 
Successfully Fight Back 12/5/03

Oregon NORML held its Oregon Medical Cannabis Awards banquet November 15 at 
the Lloyd Center DoubleTree Hotel, but not before successfully fending off 
an effort by the DEA to scare the hotel into canceling the event. As was 
the case earlier this year in Montana 
(<http://stopthedrugwar.org/chronicle/290/dearave.shtml>http://stopthedrugwar.org/chronicle/290/dearave.shtml), 
the DEA attempted to use the RAVE Act to shut down an event it didn't like. 
Under provisions of the RAVE Act, the owners or operators of venues where 
drugs are present could be subject to severe civil and criminal sanctions.

According to the Portland alternative paper the Willamette Week, two days 
before the event, Ken Magee of the Oregon DEA office sent a letter to the 
hotel noting Oregon NORML's planned event and raising the specter of a RAVE 
Act prosecution. Did the hotel intend to "knowingly permit... the illegal 
possession, conspiracy to possess or to aid and abet the possession of 
marijuana"? asked Magee.

Good corporate citizen that it is, the DoubleTree promptly canceled the 
event. But Oregon NORML was having none of that. Instead, the group teamed 
up with the Oregon ACLU, Graham Boyd of the national ACLU's Drug Policy 
Litigation Project, and Portland attorney Michael Harting to send letters 
to the hotel and the DEA threatening legal action for breach of contract 
and violation of the First Amendment.

A compromise ensued. Oregon NORML ditched its "Beautiful Bud Award" and the 
hotel relented. Afterwords, Magee told the Week that he wasn't trying to 
block the event, only ensure that no drugs were used there. But this is the 
second time the DEA has blatantly attempted to suppress drug reform events 
with RAVE Act threats. Sen. Joe Biden (D-DE), who got the act passed by 
sneaking it into another, more popular bill, has said this is not what he 
intended the RAVE Act to do. Maybe someone should let the senator know 
what's going on.

-- END --

And, a fundie site focused on the sinfulness and evil of the rave community:

<http://www.truthaboutrave.com>www.truthaboutrave.com

Love,

Apollo

the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no 
safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring 
adventure or nothing."
-Helen Keller

"Beware of being too rational.  In the country of the insane, the 
integrated man doesn't become king.  He gets lynched."
-Aldous Huxley, Island

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

"Security is mostly a superstition.  It does not exist in nature, nor do 
the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no 
safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring 
adventure or nothing."
-Helen Keller

"Beware of being too rational.  In the country of the insane, the 
integrated man doesn't become king.  He gets lynched."
-Aldous Huxley, Island

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Subject: [sfraves] **Dope Beats for your Ass Cheeks**

--0-986454288-1070667511=:78059
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

This week on Daytrippin' we join our resident DJ's Buckner and Sean Davis as we welcome Matt Harris of Black Label Records, www.floridahousemusic.com, and Crooked Bayou. So tune in and Get Down this Saturday to the funky-techy deep house goodliness you know and love. Tune your browser to www.pulseradio.net This and Every Saturday for the very best underground dance music. From 1-4pm EST
 
Pulseradio.net is a global internet radio station featuring 3 hour shows from all over the world! Started in Australia, the pulse crew has grown to represent shows from the U.K., the Far East, All parts of the US including shows from San Fran, New York, Orlando and Miami, South Africa, Boston, and Toronto, Canada.
 
While this email originates with the DJ's of Daytrippin which airs every Saturday from 1-4pm EST, we wish to highlight other shows as well. Here is a small list of the shows broadcast each Saturday as well as their corresponding genre of dance music. For a complete list, visit www.pulseradio.net and view the 'full schedule' for the whole week!
 
ALL TIMES EASTERN STANDARD TIME
5-8am The FatPharm playing Breaks and Bootlegs (AU-Sydney)
10am-1pm Rhythmic Jungle Punch playing Jungle/Drum 'n' Bass (US-Orlando)
1pm-4pm Daytrippin playing House, leaning toward tech and funk (US-Orlando)
4pm-7pm Gettin Smitten playing House, D 'n' B, Downtempo (US-Orlando)
7pm-10pm Euphoric Excursions playing Trance, Prog House and Breaks (US-Orlando)
10pm-1am Energy Guide playing Breaks (US-Orlando)
**Also be sure to check out Evolve from Boston on Mondays 7pm-9pm EST 4pm-6pm PST**

Subject: [sfraves] (NRR) Demand 2-way Communication! (A Short Rant on Saving the Internet)

--Apple-Mail-18-26502021
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset=ISO-8859-1;
	format=flowed

Attention Internet Citizens,

	Are you subscribed to electronic newsletters or announcement =
lists=20
where all you can do is read the email that comes in, not hit "Reply"=20
and send a message back to the person who sent it to you?

	If so, please ask yourself:  Do you really need that newsletter =
or=20
list? Is receiving it worth reducing yourself to the level of a TV=20
watcher -- someone who is only able to watch the images the broadcaster=20=

puts on his screen and can't send any images back the other direction?

	Do you want the Internet to keep becoming more like Television, =
where=20
a few people control what most other people see and hear via that=20
technology?

	No? Then why not use your voice as an Internet participant to =
vote for=20
more two-way communication?  Here's how:

-Unsubscribe from read-only newsletters and lists.

-Don't buy products or use services promoted by spammers who send you=20
unwanted emails that you can't reply to. If a product, service, or link=20=

sounds too good to be true, it usually is. Don't waste your time.

-Don't even click on the links they send you. That just gives them more=20=

hits on their websites and makes it easier for them to sell advertising=20=

space. It also helps them determine that your email address is an=20
active address which they can send more spam to or sell to other=20
spammers.

-Boycott websites that make it too difficult to get in touch with the=20
people running them.

	No spectators! Keep the Internet interactive! Demand 2-way=20
communication!

For liberty,
							<<< Starchild =
>>>

The Libertarian Party - Partnership for a Free America -=20
http://www.lp.org - (800) ELECT-US
"Just because you do not take an interest in=A0politics doesn't mean=20
politics won't take an interest in you."
-Pericles (430 B.C.)=A0=20=

--Apple-Mail-18-26502021--

----- Original Message -----
From: "Starchild" <sfdreamer@earthlink.net>
To: <SFRaves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Friday, December 05, 2003 5:51 PM
Subject: [sfraves] (NRR) Demand 2-way Communication! (A Short Rant on Saving
the Internet)


Attention Internet Citizens,

Are you subscribed to electronic newsletters or announcement lists
where all you can do is read the email that comes in, not hit "Reply"
and send a message back to the person who sent it to you?

If so, please ask yourself:  Do you really need that newsletter or
list? Is receiving it worth reducing yourself to the level of a TV
watcher -- someone who is only able to watch the images the broadcaster
puts on his screen and can't send any images back the other direction?

Do you want the Internet to keep becoming more like Television, where
a few people control what most other people see and hear via that
technology?

No? Then why not use your voice as an Internet participant to vote for
more two-way communication?  Here's how:

-Unsubscribe from read-only newsletters and lists.

-Don't buy products or use services promoted by spammers who send you
unwanted emails that you can't reply to. If a product, service, or link
sounds too good to be true, it usually is. Don't waste your time.

-Don't even click on the links they send you. That just gives them more
hits on their websites and makes it easier for them to sell advertising
space. It also helps them determine that your email address is an
active address which they can send more spam to or sell to other
spammers.

-Boycott websites that make it too difficult to get in touch with the
people running them.

No spectators! Keep the Internet interactive! Demand 2-way
communication!

For liberty,
<<< Starchild >>>

The Libertarian Party - Partnership for a Free America -
http://www.lp.org - (800) ELECT-US
"Just because you do not take an interest in politics doesn't mean
politics won't take an interest in you."
-Pericles (430 B.C.)


---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Have you ever tried responding to an email, only to have your response 
bounce back because the sender's account is configured only to send 
messages, not receive them? Some newsletters and lists work like that. 
Perhaps you are only subscribed to email services where you can respond 
to the sender(s). If so, great!

Whats up peoples. I just wanted to let everyone know about a brand new bi-weekly party called "Sanctuary" for the 21 plus starting tomorrow,  Saturday December 6th at Waves Smokehouse & Saloon @ 65 Post Street in downtown San Jose. 

"Sanctuary" is all about house music. From the funky, techy, and acidy flavors in the main room to the deeper soulfull flavors upstairs on the patio. We are focusing on local talent and will be bringing out all your favorite house head dj's as well as giving some up and comers who have the skills to pay the bills a chance to show what they can do behind the decks. 

Our goal is to bring some REAL house music back to San Jose and bring people together to share in the beautifull vibe we call house. We are looking forward to getting this party started right and seeing some of you out on the dancefloor. So please spread the word............ and know that we appreciate your support. 


Line up for This Saturday December 6th: 


Special Guest Dj:      Justin Hale (Secret Society, Sticky, Moksha Tribe) 


Plus Main Room Residents:      Kevin James & John Bailey 

& 

Upstairs Patio Resident :            Greg Steichen 


Doors open at 9:30 and its free before 10:00 and $3.00 after. Absolutley no dress code...... we want you comfortable so you can dance your *ss off. 21 plus ID required. 



Kevin James 










Sanctuary Saturdays 
2nd and 4th Saturday Every Month 
Grand Opening Party Saturday December 6th 
Located @ Waves 65 Post St. San Jose

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] How to Tell a Democrat from a Republican During the Holiday Season

-------------------------------1070695339
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

LOL!!!!!!!!!!!!
------------
Believe it or not, this appeared on the Stanford University web-site....


How to Tell a Democrat from a Republican During the Holiday Season
by John Carlson And you thought you could tell Republicans from Democrats 
by how they
vote. Not so! Just observe how they act during the holidays:
Republican say "Merry Christmas!"
Democrats say "Happy Holidays!"
Republicans help the poor during the holidays by sending $50 to the
Salvation Army.
Democrats help the poor by giving $50, one buck at a time, to panhandlers
on the street.
Democrats get back at Republicans on their Christmas list by giving them
fruitcakes.
Republicans re-wrap them and send them to in-laws.
Democrats let their kids open all the gifts on Christmas Eve.
Republicans make their kids wait until Christmas morning
When toasting the Holidays, Republicans ask for sherry or mulled wine.
Democrats ask for egg nog.
When not in stores, Republicans use a catalog.
Democrats watch for "incredible tv offers" on late night television.
Democrats do a lot of their shopping at Cost-Co and WalMart.
So do Republicans, but they don't admit it.
Democrats give their children gifts that make a political statement.
Republicans give their children gifts that will keep them out of their
hair.
Republican parents have no problem buying their kids toy guns.
Democrats refuse to do so. That is why their kids pretend to shoot each
other with dolls.
Republicans spend hundreds of dollars and hour of work decorating the
yard with outdoor lights and Christmas displays.
Democrats save their time and money and drive around at night to enjoy
the scenery.
Democrats favorite Christmas movie is "Miracle on 34th Street."
Republicans favorite Christmas movie is "It's a Wonderful Life."
Right-Wing Republicans favorite Christmas movie is "Diehard".
Republicans always take the price tag off any expensive gifts they buy
before wrapping.
Democrats also remove price tags off pricey gifts ... and reposition them
them to make sure they are seen.
Republicans wear wide red ties and green sport jackets during the festive
season.
Democrats do too, all year round.
Most Republicans try, at least once, enclosing indulgent, wretchedly
maudlin form letters about their families in their Christmas Cards.
Public ridicule from Democrats usually discourages them from doing it
again.
Democrats favorite Christmas song is "Deck the Halls".
Young Democrats favorite Christmas song is "Grandma Got Run Over by a
Reindeer."
Republicans favorite Christmas song is " White Christmas."
Young Republicans favorite Christmas song is "White Christmas".
Cheapskate Republicans buy an artificial Christmas tree.
Tightfisted Democrats buy a real tree, but they wait until the week
before Christmas when the lots lower their prices.
Democratic men like to watch football while their wives, girlfriends or
mothers fix holiday meals.
On this, Republicans are in full agreement.
Republicans see nothing wrong with letting their children play "Cowboys
and Indians".
Democrats don't either, as long as the Indians get to win.
Republicans first began thinking like Republicans when they stopped
believing in Santa Claus...
Democrats became Democrats because they never stopped believing in Santa
Claus...
-----------


LOL, HAHAHAHJAKHDASKJhdsjakhdsk!!!!!!!!!

-------------------------------1070695339--

Subject: [sfraves] (BSP) SPEAK OUT_Sunday Dec. 7th_Feat. "Uncovered" documentary

--0-1143392750-1070751524=:8036
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii


On Sunday, December 7th, we are showing a screening of the new documentary Uncovered: The Whole Truth about the Iraq War. The documentary clearly describes, in the words of experts and former intelligence officials, how President Bush and his administration manipulated evidence to take our country to war.  
There are over 2,000 parties across the nation taking place simultaneously for this event and will be brought together through a huge cross-country conference call. At 5:30 PM, party attendees will be able to dial in to a call featuring director Robert Greenwald, the MoveOn team, and guests from parties all over the country. You'll also be able to submit questions for Mr. Greenwald and the team online. 
Here's a little more about Uncovered: 
MoveOn.org doesn't usually sponsor documentary films, but this movie is a really important one. It's built around interviews with over 20 intelligence and military experts, many of whom are speaking out for the first time. True to the MoveOn ethic, director Robert Greenwald lets the facts speak for themselves. And the results are pretty shocking. 
Uncovered combines expert interviews with extensive research to go behind the walls of government. Interviewees include: 

   Joe Wilson, the former Ambassador to Iraq who exposed that the famous "16 words" in Bush's State of the Union address about uranium in Niger were false. In retaliation, senior White House officials appear to have blown the cover of Wilson's wife, an undercover CIA agent. 


   John Dean, White House lawyer for President Nixon during the Watergate scandal. 


   Rand Beers, former Special Assistant to the President and Senior Director for combating terrorism. 


   David Albright, a physicist, nuclear weapons expert, and former weapons inspector with the IAEA Action team. 


   Rt. Hon. Clare Short, the British Member of Parliament who recently resigned her position as Tony Blair's secretary for international development because Blair did not support a UN coalition to rebuild Iraq. 

It's a powerful film and we hope you will come to learn the truth.

The schedule will be as follows:

Sunday, December 7th from 4:00 PM to 10:00 PM

4:00 PM Screening of the documentary (approx. 1 hour in length)

5:30 PM Nationwide conference call

Following the call we will have DJs T-Ray (breaks/house), Cyzmik (progressive house/trance), and Roy E (trance) playing until 10:00 PM. 

There will be no cover, $2 beers and $3 wells until 6:00 PM, free video games and lots of free parking. 

Location: Sublounge 628 20th Street @ 3rd Street

Bar phone: 415.552.3603

Click or copy and paste link below for a map:
http://maps.yahoo.com/maps_result?ed=aF_qVOp_0To.GYZhTZLXmZLbsxYknt79&csz=san+francisco&country=us 

For more info:

http://www.sublounge.com/

http://www.moveon.org

http://www.cosmicproductions.org/

or email me (Heidi) @ cosmicdancer777@yahoo.com

Hope to see you!

~heidi

CosmicProductions

Subject: Re: [sfraves] vote gonzalez

On 7 December 2003, DISCONNECT4@aol.com wrote:

> i think it was willie brown that officially killed the sf latenight
> scene. i can't vote for gonzales because i live in marin. but i'd
> suggest that if you do live in sf, if you're not planning to vote
> please do me the favor of letting me get a vote in for gonzales in my
> place. even if only so we can get a fresh ear on the sflnc scenario.

NOTE: You can place an absentee ballot at City Hall tomorrow between
10am and 4pm (enter city hall and take the elevator down one floor.)  I
can't remember if you can vote absentee on Monday or not.  Anyone know?

Newsom is definitely no democrat.  He even made a campaign contribution
to Bush in 2000.  There's an article in The Nation about Democrats
supporting Gonzalez (http://www.mattgonzalez.com/article.php?id=269)
(only 3% of SF voters are registered as Greens.)  This course of action
is totally in line with my feelings towards the democratic party after
they've rallied around someone like Newsom (who was given a D by the
Sierra Club, vs. Gonzalez's A+.)  And Gonzalez used to be a Democrat
before switching to the Green party in 2000.  The New York Times had a
bit to say about it all in today's paper:
http://www.mattgonzalez.com/article.php?id=270  It's a good read.

Also, there's an event tomorrow night that Heidi posted about a little
while ago: Uncovered: The Whole Truth About the Iraq War at the
Sublounge, and it's also being shown at the UNCOVERED Film Screening and
Party for Matt at the Punch Gallery (doors at 6 and film at 7.)

And remember to make sure you help a couple of friends make it to the
polls too!

What's up all you ravers out there!  Tonight we've got yet another phat
ass show coming your way.  Check out the timeslots and links below:


07-08pm EST - Intro Hour - ODJ & Jerel rock shit out host style.

08-09:30pm EST - illEffect - The scratch master and host of Expansion
Broadcast drops bombs fer ya.

09:30-11pm EST - Crucial Carl - The one like Crucial plays a special
edition all Dubs set.  Boh!

11-12am EST - Outro Hour - we play the intro hour again, in reverse.  It's
fun, trust me ;)


So yea, tune in!  Just head over to http://dirtboxradio.com/listen.html
for the audio, video, and chatroom links!


If you'd like to play on Dirtbox Radio, or have us air a mix cd or tune
for you, just send an email to bookme@dirtboxradio.com and we'll sort you
out.  We're always looking to showcase new talent!


Upcoming Guests:

12/21 - Sabin, Deinfamous
12/28 - New Years' Special (lineup TBA)
01/04 - Rogers & Freefall

Found this on someone's web log.  Don't know the origin:


Breaks lovers like to be known as the elite dancers
Drum-N-Bass lovers wanna be known as the hardcore mofo's
Disco lovers just wanna be sexy
House lovers don't wanna be known as ravers
Trance lovers appreciate the unity the music can create.
Psy Goa lovers are the spiritual hippies in the scene
Techno lovers are the old schoolers who never really grew up.


Love,

Apollo


Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Security is mostly a superstition.  It does not exist in nature, nor do 
the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no 
safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring 
adventure or nothing."
-Helen Keller

"Beware of being too rational.  In the country of the insane, the 
integrated man doesn't become king.  He gets lynched."
-Aldous Huxley, Island

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

OK... so the night started out when JBlaze & I talk on the phone & like well we made plans 2 go out & he told me about this party happening & I was like ok... ok...

So we call the voice mail (3-Way) & listen 2 the "instructions" lol... ok... Jblaze remarked during the vm that the party didn't sound 2 "fun fun" w/ all those specific instructions... LoL...

So anywaze... we go & it was fun fun! I had a fun fun time actually!!  LOLOLOLOMAO... I mean... there was an Awesome vibe of people there & lol.. it was kinda fuinny 'cause every new person I met there.. i mean...seriously... almost all of them I met.. they were like, "Oh... you're name's Osby... Oh shit.. I heard so much about U".... & like I dunno... that kinda freaked me out...

But no... there was an Awesome vibe... people were really nice... lol.. it was fun... Oh shit... I finally saw fuckin Larry aka ChinaOnNitrous (old skool sfr if some of y'all remember) & that was so Dope!!  LoL.. him & I spent the night basically play fighting & pretending we hated each other but we talked soo much & totally caught up & man... it was Dope!  Love that kid so much! Oh yeah... there were alota people there who I ain't seen in months.. that was fuckin' dope!! man.. so fun!  (Hi Christie Ruiz if your still on here =)

OK.. the music was sick!!  Good shit man... ok.. alota surprises... when JBlaze & I got there... welll checked out the rooms & when we finally got up 2 the last room... it was Psy-trance spinning & I dunno... I went up hella close 2 the DJ booth 2 c who was spinning & it looked like this lil' 13 year kid who was on the decks playing & I was like WOW.. then the Dude looked up @ me... it was Michael Lui!!  LoL... how fun fun!!  LoL... so yeah... his set was Awesome!!  I Loved it!!  

Oh yeah... speaking of... I saw Jonnyr there also... LOLOLOLOLOLMAO... Hello 2day... h im & I ain't been 2 a party @ the same time since like last year, summer.. so that was fun!! LoL.. OK.. I'm gonna shut up now about JonnyR... Love Ya Dude!!! =)

OK... but what really trip me out was when Jmarr went on after him... OK... soooo confusing but so pleasing... he was like doin' cross fader tricks w/ his record & Michael Lui's record & it was breakbeats... @ 1st I thouhgt, ok, well... he's gonna sin trance & probably is jus usin' the breakdown in the song, la la la... ok.. but I was trippin... he played a whole fuckin' set of BREAKBEATS!!! OK.... YUMMY!!!  I Loved it man... he even got like 80 Nostalgic & played the RockBerry track from like early 80's & Shake it by Salt N Pepa & even oh gosh.. I loved it... then he played alota Acid Breaks, but not like the Acid breaks that Konkers spins... but his tracks had alota acids licks in them.. Oh Gosh man.. I Loved it... alot Future breaks in his set... Good shit man...

OK.. if i remember correctly... there was this hardcore track he soun w/ Gun N Roses like sampled... but it was totally fun fun man... but then mean etard girl was there well... the small blond etard meaie was there... she's never nice 2 me...

All these fun things hanging from the walls.. it was Bad Ass!!! =)

Gosh man... I can't believe whata fun fun time  I had there & it was like totally unexpectedly!!  I seriously didn't expect 2 C all the people I saw lastnight... that was trippy!

Thanks JBlaze 4 takin me out Homie!!  Hey... we got projects 2 work on Dude! =) Hello 2day

Subject: RE: [sfraves] Fun Fun Review

Hey, what's up Osby?
    I actually saw you last night, but I didn't have the chance to say hi 
(my bad).  Anyway, last night was pretty damn Fun-Fun.  Unfortunately, the 
venue (commonly called "Jared's", The Dojo, The Dungeon, or Hell) was hotter 
than fcvk but it looked really nice.  I was actually at a party there the 
night before as well and I liked the Viberite decorations a lot more.  They 
are a really cool crew and I had a blast last night... So, the sign had a 
ton of bright red cherries on it and said, "No matter how many you eat, 
you'll never get your cherry back!"  HA HA HA.  It was amazing.  J-Marr 
played Push-It and the crowd went nuts.  Who thought that they'd ever hear 
Salt and Peppa at a rave.  Great sets from Tronic and Carlos Alfonzo as 
well.  I saw JonnyR, and it was good.  There were more crackies there than 
usual, and there were a lot of people who smelled like a combination of B.O. 
and Vaporub (how depressing), but I still had a really good time.  Big ups 
to Viberite for bringing good sound, good vibes, and an overall great party.
Peace.Love.Unity.and.Noise....
Joey Frisco

From: tigerstar <tiger0star@yahoo.com>
