MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] 12/25 CHRIST ON CRUTCHES!!! (a co-op party)

hey there y'all:

i live in a berkeley co-op with some nice speakers and
a pretty good space for dancing.  i'd like to put
together a small shindig for the night of xmas (thurs
12/25).  we're talking like 50-100 people, 9 - 1
pounding techno music; 1 -> late chiller stuff. 
(berkeley has a fairly strict noise ordinance and i
just can't afford to get slapped with a
fine...however, most of our neighbors are frat boys
and they'll be hibernating for winter, so i can assume
that somewhat loud music won't be a problem...)

so, is anyone interested in participating?  we have to
keep this small and intimate, but i'd like to extend
the invitation to the community, especially if there
are any djs/musicians out there who'd like to perform
and any
jews/atheists/buddhists/hindus/muslims/nonxmascelebrating
christians etc etc etc out there who have absolutely
nothing to do on xmas and wanna hear some phat beats.

i'd like to make this a completely co-operative and
free event, so i would love as many helping hands as
possible.  please get back to me if you're interested.

thanks!

*emma*

Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Today NRR

I was at this crazy little warehouse.. I guess it's the 'SPAZ' space?
Really low-key. Not raveish at all, although I saw some people poiing (is
that a word?) to the weird trippy music.

Those cats are pretty amazing. They're doing some pretty exciting things.

Anyway. I have a very unsettling sight to report:

I'm sitting there, pretty zony, when I see this little tiny kid tottering
around holding a record. I'm like -huh! The kid likes records! that's
cool.

So he walks up to the decks. waves at them with the record. His mom gets a
milk create or something and he climbs up on top.

Fits the record into place. Lays down the needle. Switches the fader over.

What the fuck.

"How old is he?"
"Year and a half."
...then:
"Yeah, he can't beatmatch for shit, but he's getting there."

I fear the skills this kid will have in 15 years. :b

S

Subject: [sfraves] Endangered Species...Get Freaky

--=====================_7980044==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

I rarely go to club or any other dance events these days with security 
measures that violate my person;  that is, pat downs and searches of 
personal items.  Anything beyond an ID check and I walk away.  So my 
partying recently has been limited to undergrounds and club venues, like 
Club 6 and  Barneveld,  where patrons are treated with respect and not like 
potential criminals.

I was delighted, therefore, when I heard that the latest edition of "Get 
Freaky" was to be held at 550 Barneveld.  Haven't been there since Thump 
moved to the DNA.  Love the venue, but the recent parties there have been 
commercial or mediocre.  "Get Freaky" was neither.  Rather, it was a 
rebirthing of those energetic, creative, innovative and magical nights I 
experienced in the seminal days of the rave/club scene in San Francisco in 
the early nineties.

Brandon has characterized "Get Freaky" as Thump with breaks.   Indeed, "Get 
Freaky" has the same respectful, loving vibe as the early Thump 
parties.  And there is the same ecstatic, sweaty, sexually infused dance 
floor peopled with folks who love the music and dance with both the body 
and soul.  But "Get Freaky" is darker, harder and more cutting-edge than 
Thump.

Many of the psytrance people seemed to have migrated to this party, but 
with an attitude and dress that is more modern primitive and tribal than 
dayglo.  Costumed dancers were the rule here.  There were a large number of 
people who appeared to have raided the props department of "Road Warrior" 
whilst adding some touches from Burning Man encampments.  Half-naked dudes 
with bondage gear.  One guy who appeared to have mud smeared over his upper 
torso.  All very stimulating.  Earthy.  Tribal.  Hot.  The moisture dripped 
from the ceiling onto the dance floor in the main room reflecting back the 
steamy body work of the dancers on the floor.  Outside in the smoking area 
there were fire dancers supported by drummers and keyboards.  I really love 
this kind of party.  This is what San Francisco was and is becoming 
again:  a maelstrom of sensually-infused spirit.

San Francisco.  We arrived in the middle of Lorin's set and, towards the 
end he stopped the music and made an announcement.  Lorin quoted a recent 
statement by Jeb Bush during a Cabinet meeting last month.  While pointing 
to a environmental map showing various wildlife, Bush said:  "It looks like 
the people of San Francisco are an endangered species, which may not be a 
bad thing.  That's probably good news for the country."  Well, Jeb, SF is 
still wild and free and will continue to be so.  "Get Freaky" was packed 
with Matt Gonzalez supporters, myself included.  I haven't worked so hard 
on a political campaign in years.  The endangered species in SF were the 
artists, musicians, crafts people and "freaks."  Well, we are coming back 
and reclaiming our little city state and to hell with you.

I have often said that positive, paradigm breaking cultural and artistic 
change arises in discordant, challenging times.  We are on the cusp of 
change, especially in the dance and rave communities.  The music I danced 
to at "Get Freaky" was a clear indication of a movement I have been feeling 
in my feet and yearning for in my heart for many moons.  Adam Freeland's 
set was astonishing.  Breaks?  Well, sure there were breakbeats but dancing 
to his set I experienced a concretization of my belief that house, breaks 
and hip-hop are converging, whilst sampling some of the great dance music 
from the past, to create something new and wonderful.  KraftyKuts did both 
a hip hop set in the side room, and then went on to throw down 
"experimental" breaks in the main room infused with dub, reggae and hip hop 
beats as well as trance-like interludes that broke into wild, 
psytrance-like beats.

"Get Freaky" was an epiphany for me.  It confirmed my belief that our 
revolutionary community of ravers and dancers is far from dead.  Rather, we 
are moving into a new age of musical and social innovation and I'm happy 
and lucky to be a part of it all....once again.  As Jacques Attali 
wrote:  "Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead 
of the rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually 
become visible."  This new world is about to envelope us.

Love,

Apollo



Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Security is mostly a superstition.  It does not exist in nature, nor do 
the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no 
safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring 
adventure or nothing."
-Helen Keller

"Beware of being too rational.  In the country of the insane, the 
integrated man doesn't become king.  He gets lynched."
-Aldous Huxley, Island

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: Another reason I love this area....

So, at least once a week on my way to work, between the BART and my office 
building, there's a guy playing jazz/blues guitar on the sidewalk next to a 
little coffee shop hut thingy. Now, this isn't anything extraordinary on 
it's own, but this isn't your typical panhandling street musician. This guy 
is fucking GOOD at what he does, and he's not panhandling! He's just playing 
to play. What makes it even more special (to me anyway) is the fact that on 
the days he's there, about a block before you see him, you will hear these 
random, sweet notes floating through the air lazily, almost like a feather 
caught in a gentle breeze. The closer you get the more sweet the tune, and 
no matter how shitty a mood I'm in, at least while I can hear him, all that 
negative energy is gone. As I walk past him towards my building, the notes 
seem to follow, and one by one drift off like a cloud sticking to the wing 
of a plane as you fly through it...slowly dissipating until you've gotten 
further along down the line.

Anyway...it always puts me in a good mood, so I thought I'd share. (and I'm 
trying to keep my spirits up cuz I'ma be one lonely SOB this Xmas)

Anyhoo...what's going on this weekend party-wise??? Anyone, Bueller??

M-

Subject: [sfraves] BE.ES.PEE !! Sticky II !! 12.13.03 :: SF :: $10 :: FREE spirits (drinky kind) :: 9 - 4am+

I'm sure a lot of your remember the last Sticky party from 420 this past
April. If you were there then you also know what to expect in terms of food,
drink., and most important music and friends! This Saturday, December 13th
we once again bring you Sticky!

The holiday madness is upon us and it's time to get everyone under one roof
for a family reunion. We've prepared a solid lineup the SF Bay's finest
house, breaks, and downtempo for your listening enjoyment. The key to any
Sticky event is the space. Remember how amazing that last spot was?? Well
we've got another NEW space that really is NEW! No, really... it's badass
space that hasn't been used for a party until now. The space is a large,
cozy 2 room loft with ample outdoor space complete with a garden in back and
fire pit! How many spots in SF do you know like that? I sure as hell haven't
seen the like. The fire pit will surely add to the charm and warmth that
surrounds this holiday season.

Like the last Sticky, all drinks and food are complimentary. Translated...
free open bar with free food to match. Drink up, eat lots and be funky like
always! Food and drink wise we'll have a lot just like the last time. I
don't think anyone was hungry or complained about lack of "spirits"

This party is being powered by Evite and we would *GREATLY* appreciate you
letting us know via Evite if you intend to come. The link is below. You can
use PayPal too!

&unknownUser=true>

(Emeryville//SF//Oakland//Berkeley//Walnut Creek) I have tickets. Reply here
or at ryan@sninesix.com. To arrange ticket pickup//drop off.

know and we'll see all of you in a few days!

Importance: Normal
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 08 Dec 2003 19:59:33.0020 (UTC) FILETIME=[CC4B4DC0:01C3BDC5]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] Re: Today NRR your baby's future

Classical is always a good base music to train any child.  It
encompasses all forms of instrumentation, (strings, percussion, brass,
composition, harmony and melody etc) and also many a study has shown
that it improves intelligence or at least the intelligence quotient and
concentration.  (IMO, any music without words leads to higher
concentration on a task in front of you, I've been listening to a lot of
Wagner and Beethoven lately while reading on the train and I seem to be
retaining more from the books I'm reading than normal.)  And in
conjunction with sonograms, the babies will know the low end of the
spectrum as well which is the bass we all love (that's is just my guess
of course) ;)

As for parents listening flavor and growing up.. My dad listened to 50's
bubblegum, and my mom liked classic rock.  I hated both styles growing
up but now..  I sometimes gotta listen to some Buddy Holly or Everly
Brothers (not to mention it helped me fall immediately in love with the
Avalanches) and you can take my classic rock when you pry it from my
cold dead hand.  I still haven't found a better music for road trips on
a sunny day.  :)

-Rayn

Subject: [sfraves] (NRR) Bill of Rights Day - December 15

(Forwarded message from Lance Brown)

Hi folks,

I've put together a central site to help people organize their  
celebration
of Bill of Rights Day. This year is sort of the "beta" version, but  
there
are still tons of ideas and resources there -- and I will be adding more
steadily all week.

http://billofrightsday.com
  The domain name is just now starting to work -- if it doesn't work for  
you
then try again in a few minutes, or a few hours.

One special feature is a step-by-step guide to putting together a  
Funeral
for the Bill of Rights. There's still time for you to do one this year  
and
I *highly* recommend it. There is a sample press release, poster,  
handout,
and instructions for the rest, here:

http://billofrightsday.com/archives/ 
cat_funeral_for_the_bill_of_rights_guid
e.html

There's a place to list your event, there are sample resolutions,  
letters,
and op-eds, and lots more. Come grab an idea or a template and rock the
holiday. And pass this on right away, so other late starters can take
advantage of the booster shot!

http://billofrightsday.com
"Bill of Rights Day is December 15th. What are you going to do about  
it?"

Be Well, Be Free,

Lance Brown
Freedom Activist

lance@freedom2008.com
ICQ #:2694547
Phone: 530-274-2474

The Free View - weblog of a presidential candidate
http://freedom2008.com

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: [sfraves] Flyer advertising and listing submission deadline

Just a heads up...

Advertising info (Listing submission guidlines below) please read
carefully------

As most of you know, I've recently taken a position with Flyer
Magazine, a free pocketsize magazine that navigates the latest
movements in city culture after dark. Along with its concise calendar
of urban nitelife, the magazine features articles, reviews and
interviews focusing o nthe latest in music, film, art, and fashion.

http://www.flyermagazine.com

It is also the most comprehensive and most used event listing guide in
New York, Atlanta, Los Angeles and San Francisco.

Right now Flyer is offering wicked rates for advertising and placement
for January's issue. This includes events for New Years Eve!!!!

Whether you have an event, club, indie, major record label, store or
clothing company we can accomodate you.
Flyer's street team distributes 155,000 copies to over 1,200 locations.

THE FLYER FORMULA
-Extremely accurate listings calendar
-High contact rate through pocket-size format and daily calendar
-High pass-along rate through portability
-Customized distribution to target group meeting points
-Additional lifestyle marketing, street promotion, and retail promotion
via our national street team network
-Worldwide integration into trend network through Flyer publications in
Germany and Japan


Please contact me at sarah@flyermagazine.com - include your phone
number and I'd be happy to call you back and speak with you about it.

1/3, 1/2, and full page ads are available today.


Listing info ------------

Its that time again! Please submit your January event listings in the
format listed below. The deadline for submission is Monday December
8th.
Don't forget to include the following:

Day of the week:
Venue:
Event name:
Weekly, monthly or one-off:
Resident DJs, artists and guests:
Brief description and styles of music/genres:
Time/ages/cover:

Also, please let us know of any events that aren't happening anymore.

Email all of the info above to: sflistings@flyermagazine.com or reply
to

this email.


Thanks!

-
Sarah Randolph // Flyer Magazine
SF Listings Editor // Advertising // SF Distribution
www.flyermagazine.com // sarah@flyermagazine.com

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] Tips Please On How TO Get Started DJ'N *not for me*

I will give my two cents as I just bought some Technics in August.  If she 
is passionate about tables, then I highly recommend getting Technics, she 
will never have to replace them.  If she just wants to try it out, she could 
go for those DJ in a box deals, but I still would go against that.  If you 
ask anyone on this board, or ask anyone who is passionate about tables, they 
will suggest Technics all the way.  Some good forums to gain information 
are:

djforums.com
www.futureproducers.com (go to the DJ section)

If she does a few searches in those forums, she will come up with all the 
information she needs.  DJ forums has some really good tutorials and even 
has a comparison of Technics to other tables, I think.

When I first got my tables, I started with two identical progressive house 
records, moved on to two identical drum and bass records, and now Im having 
a blast mixing hiphop and dnb...next investment will be final scratch.

Peace

fable....

Received: (qmail 62453 invoked from network); 9 Dec 2003 22:29:42 -0000
X-Originating-IP: [130.212.14.66]
X-Originating-Email: [josephwhunt@hotmail.com]
X-Sender: josephwhunt@hotmail.com
From: "Joey Frisco" <josephwhunt@hotmail.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Bcc: 
Date: Tue, 09 Dec 2003 22:29:40 +0000
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; format=flowed
Message-ID: <Law15-F34b1z7SXccqw00021468@hotmail.com>
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 09 Dec 2003 22:29:40.0132 (UTC) FILETIME=[EF5D4640:01C3BEA3]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] Tips Please On How TO Get Started DJ'N *not for me*

I'd suggest working your ass off to get your beat matching on point before 
you try to learn any tricks.  Beat matching is the most fundamental and 
important thing when mixing.  It doesn't matter how many tricks you can do, 
or how on point you can cut if your beats sound like sneakers in the dryer.  
After that, I'd work on phrasing and cutting.   Then programming a set, I 
guess.  If you can figure out all of those things, you're in a better place 
then half of the people who pretend to be dj's.  Oh, and once you've learned 
to beat match fairly consistantly, learn to pitch-bend (adjusting the pitch 
live without touching the platter).  This makes your live performance sound 
a lot cleaner (I'm still working on my pitch bending, touching the platter 
is a hard habit to break, if I had to start over again I'd learn to only 
pitch bend).  Once you've mastered the fundamentals, you can learn new ways 
to mix, fade, cut, drop, and scratch; but I'd wait until I had the other 
stuff down before I worked on the advanced stuff.
Cheers and goodluck,
Joey

josephwhunt@hotmail.com

Subject: [sfraves] .: New Mixes | Dirtbox Radio | 11/23, 11/30, 12/07 :.


Need some help gettin thru the day?  Well, Dirtbox Radio's got the answer
for ya...

New mixes have been posted up on the site, from 11/23, 11/30, and 12/07,
featuring Crucial Carl, illEffect, Jerel, Joey Migraine, Kauz, ODJ, Phil
Scott, and Plejik.

Just click on the link below, and you'll be blessed with about 20 hours of
music available in both modem-streamable real media, and high quality
downloadable mp3:

http://www.dirtboxradio.com/archives.html

There's also a video cooked up by Defekt (www.defekt.org), wherein he used
live footage he shot @ ALIAS in DC layered over an exerpt from ODJ @
Dirtbox Radio 11/09.  Defekt's a resident at Alchemy (ALIAS' sister
party), spinning the finest selections of "goth music" for the moodier
massif.

So yeah, check out our shit.  Hear us live on Jungletrain.net and
Destroyer.net every Sunday from 7pm 'til 12am (and sometimes later), or
check out the rebroadcast every Wednesday on Dartainian.com (when I
remember to send Brian the files :-x).  Lineups and all that good shit are
up on the site as well.

That's about it.  Y'all enjoy.

Jackson (ODJ)
Partners in Crime ? Dirtbox Radio ? Trividual Productions ? ALIAS ? Your
Mom's Bed

.....................jackson.
.partners.in.crime...........
.dirtbox.radio...............
.trividual.productions.......
.a.l.i.a.s...................
.........................odj.

X-Virus-Scanned: by amavisd-new
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] NRR, or is it?  (story)

Add a sentence or two when you have time.  Sense this is a rave list I would
like the story to be about raves; music, parties, finding the place,
whatever.  I would also like to publish it when it is done, so if you could
not go over an "R" rating I would appreciate it.
This is my first time trying this, so if you have any comments let me know.

 -Andrew RB

The story: 
As usual we had to drive for two hours looking for the place.
   "Map point my ass!"
   My buddy from the back sit said sarcastically "Oh man! I'm sure glad we
got those tickets in advance."

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Tips Please On How TO Get Started DJ'N *not for me*

Dear nice young lady who wants to learn to spin,
I learned to spin when i was 15.  I live in New York City and I used to live in 
the Bay Area as well.  If you're not already on the list, join NYCRaves.  Then 
you'll be able to chat with more East Coast deejays and find out about events, 
etc.  They're easy to find on the web.  Let me know if you have problems 
joining.

Just like the other guys said, get good at mixing before learing all the tricks 
and scratching and stuff...  There are videos and books out there that you can 
buy now, but nothing beats practice!  Practice does NOT make perfect!  Perfect 
practice makes perfect! 

Good luck :)

Frank

"Neither snow nor rain nor heat nor gloom of night stays this rider from the 
swift completion of his appointed rounds"

--Zephyr Stormrider (2003),

adapted from the inscription on the James A. Farley main post office building 
in New York City, which was in turn adapted from the writings of Herodotus in 
the fifth century B.C.

zephyr@steelwolverine.com

(646) 64-FRANK  mobile voice/SMS

PO Box 2005
New York, NY 10008

AIM  ZephyrNewYork

--- Andrew Baumrucker <abaumrucker@astound.net> wrote:

> rave list I would

> not go over an "R" rating I would appreciate it.

> comments let me know.

> The story: 
> As usual we had to drive for two hours looking for the place.
>    "Map point my ass!"
>    My buddy from the back sit said sarcastically "Oh man! I'm
> sure glad we
> got those tickets in advance." 

In the front seat, Steve0 sat next to me in silence, feverishly
sucking on his blowpop.  He'd never rolled before, and had
taken his "e" an hour ago with the intention of a smooth
entrance past security.

Abruptly, Steve0 stopped his slurping.  "Oh you guys!  You know
that I don't care what we end up doing tonight!  I'm just so
happy that we get to spend time with each other.  You're my
bestest friends!  I love you..."

I tried to casually scoot away from Steve0, but was limited by
my ability to be able to drive properly.  He promptly filled
the gap between us and started stroking my leg.

>
> In the front seat, Steve0 sat next to me in silence, feverishly
> sucking on his blowpop.  He'd never rolled before, and had
> taken his "e" an hour ago with the intention of a smooth
> entrance past security.
>
> Abruptly, Steve0 stopped his slurping.  "Oh you guys!  You know
> that I don't care what we end up doing tonight!  I'm just so
> happy that we get to spend time with each other.  You're my
> bestest friends!  I love you..."
>
> I tried to casually scoot away from Steve0, but was limited by
> my ability to be able to drive properly.  He promptly filled
> the gap between us and started stroking my leg.

This, however, was the least of my worries. The drugs had taken hold.

"Take the wheel you filthy beast!" I howled as the asphalt -- solid, mere
moments ago -- twisted and churned beneath the wheels of my  mom's
minivan, black lava lapping against the doors in slowly mounting waves.
Soon, they would crash overhead and that crap would be into the air ducts.
We were not equipped to breathe asphalt.

Steve0's saucerlike eyes rolled in terror as his focus shifted from wang
to wheel, darting back and forth in panic. "I don't want to die man!" he
whined.

"WE WILL IF THAT GODDAMN ASPHALT GETS INTO THE AIR DUCTS!" I bellowed,
thrashing in my seat. I gave him a rough shove aside, reaffirming my role
as captain of this ship. Never send an etard to do a man's job.

Horns blared somewhere, far in the distance - lights strobed across my
field of vision. A sharp jerk to the left seemed to calm things down,
silencing the screams of my charges.

"Will you kids stop--"

"There!" Jessie, from the back seat, jabbed a finger past my face, the
motion sending distorted ripples through the already thickening air.
Another sharp tug on the wheel, and I applied the emergency break to calm
the angry roar of the engine.

"Someone take the wheel. I'm going to shake this joker down for
information," I mumbled, clawing at my seatbelt and launching myself out
the driver's-side window. The door was rigged. I knew it.

Brush some gravel from the old skivvies (they'll love my tie-dye
longjohns, I mused) and a sharp tug to the ole beanie as I get to my feet.
Give him the look. There, in the shadows, a terrified-looking kid in pants
big enough to fit two dogs and a moderately endowed chinese girl. I put on
my most reassuring smile, and began my sauntering approach.

---
Griffin
http://www.DefSF.com - 97.4% techno

> happy that we get to spend time with each other. 
> You're my
> bestest friends!  I love you..."
> 
> I tried to casually scoot away from Steve0, but was
> limited by
> my ability to be able to drive properly.  He
> promptly filled
> the gap between us and started stroking my leg.

It wasn't until now that I really noticed his
fasionable attire- 70's terry-cloth shirt, short
tennis shorts with a stripe on the side, could it all
have been for me?
My mind raced at the thought of this new side of
things-
I tried to concentrate on my driving but this was just
too much- I focused ahead but stole glances, and
always watched him out of the corner of my eye.
I saw his eyes occasionally look up at me, then away,
never interrupting his incessant rhythmic stroking-
I thought I noticed a bit of drool coming off his
chin, but I dare not look directly over at him.
Then I noticed him running his tongue over his lips,
taking the drool with it.
I suppose I was right.
With a sudden grunt, he seemed to fall over on to me-
before I could even react, his head was laying on my
leg.
I looked down, yes, drool.
He looked up at me with his big brown eyes with a
quizzical look, as if he wasn't quite sure what he was
doing.
His tag glinted in the oncoming headlights-
"Crotchmaster" it said- his tongue was now slurping
again.
This was just getting messy all over my pants- "Bad
Dog!" I yelled out.
Steve0 reluctantly went back to his side of the car.
I focused on the road again, but quickly looked back
at him very confused-
Who dressed my dog was in that shirt and shorts?
Some questions were never meant to be answered I suppose.

=====
--
live- http://www.thedenofsin.org/
to- AIM: IMFDUP
_-jupiter accepts your offer-_

Story version 1: 

    As usual we had to drive for two hours looking for the place.
> >    "Map point my ass!"
> >    My buddy from the back sit said sarcastically "Oh man! I'm
> > sure glad we
> > got those tickets in advance."
>
> In the front seat, Steve0 sat next to me in silence, feverishly
> sucking on his blowpop.  He'd never rolled before, and had
> taken his "e" an hour ago with the intention of a smooth
> entrance past security.
>
> Abruptly, Steve0 stopped his slurping.  "Oh you guys!  You know
> that I don't care what we end up doing tonight!  I'm just so
> happy that we get to spend time with each other.  You're my
> bestest friends!  I love you..."
>
> I tried to casually scoot away from Steve0, but was limited by
> my ability to be able to drive properly.  He promptly filled
> the gap between us and started stroking my leg.

This, however, was the least of my worries. The drugs had taken hold.

"Take the wheel you filthy beast!" I howled as the asphalt -- solid, mere
moments ago -- twisted and churned beneath the wheels of my  mom's
minivan, black lava lapping against the doors in slowly mounting waves.
Soon, they would crash overhead and that crap would be into the air ducts.
We were not equipped to breathe asphalt.

Steve0's saucerlike eyes rolled in terror as his focus shifted from wang
to wheel, darting back and forth in panic. "I don't want to die man!" he
whined.

"WE WILL IF THAT GODDAMN ASPHALT GETS INTO THE AIR DUCTS!" I bellowed,
thrashing in my seat. I gave him a rough shove aside, reaffirming my role
as captain of this ship. Never send an etard to do a man's job.

Horns blared somewhere, far in the distance - lights strobed across my
field of vision. A sharp jerk to the left seemed to calm things down,
silencing the screams of my charges.

"Will you kids stop--"

"There!" Jessie, from the back seat, jabbed a finger past my face, the
motion sending distorted ripples through the already thickening air.
Another sharp tug on the wheel, and I applied the emergency break to calm
the angry roar of the engine.

"Someone take the wheel. I'm going to shake this joker down for
information," I mumbled, clawing at my seatbelt and launching myself out
the driver's-side window. The door was rigged. I knew it.

Brush some gravel from the old skivvies (they'll love my tie-dye
longjohns, I mused) and a sharp tug to the ole beanie as I get to my feet.
Give him the look. There, in the shadows, a terrified-looking kid in pants
big enough to fit two dogs and a moderately endowed chinese girl. I put on
my most reassuring smile, and began my sauntering approach.

---
Griffin
http://www.DefSF.com - 97.4% techno

Story version 2:

--- "michael, the red stickman"
<red_stickman@yahoo.com> wrote:
> 
> --- Andrew Baumrucker <abaumrucker@astound.net>
> wrote:
> > Add a sentence or two when you have time.  Sense
> this is a
> > rave list I would
> > like the story to be about raves; music, parties,
> finding the
> > place,
> > whatever.  I would also like to publish it when it
> is done,
> > so if you could
> > not go over an "R" rating I would appreciate it.
> > This is my first time trying this, so if you have
> any
> > comments let me know.
> > 
> >  -Andrew RB
> > 
> > The story: 
> > As usual we had to drive for two hours looking for
> the place.
> >    "Map point my ass!"
> >    My buddy from the back sit said sarcastically
> "Oh man! I'm
> > sure glad we
> > got those tickets in advance."
> 
> In the front seat, Steve0 sat next to me in silence,
> feverishly
> sucking on his blowpop.  He'd never rolled before,
> and had
> taken his "e" an hour ago with the intention of a
> smooth
> entrance past security.
> 
> Abruptly, Steve0 stopped his slurping.  "Oh you
> guys!  You know
> that I don't care what we end up doing tonight!  I'm
> just so
> happy that we get to spend time with each other.
> You're my
> bestest friends!  I love you..."
> 
> I tried to casually scoot away from Steve0, but was
> limited by
> my ability to be able to drive properly.  He
> promptly filled
> the gap between us and started stroking my leg.

It wasn't until now that I really noticed his
fasionable attire- 70's terry-cloth shirt, short
tennis shorts with a stripe on the side, could it all
have been for me?
My mind raced at the thought of this new side of
things-
I tried to concentrate on my driving but this was just
too much- I focused ahead but stole glances, and
always watched him out of the corner of my eye.
I saw his eyes occasionally look up at me, then away,
never interrupting his incessant rhythmic stroking-
I thought I noticed a bit of drool coming off his
chin, but I dare not look directly over at him.
Then I noticed him running his tongue over his lips,
taking the drool with it.
I suppose I was right.
With a sudden grunt, he seemed to fall over on to me-
before I could even react, his head was laying on my
leg.
I looked down, yes, drool.
He looked up at me with his big brown eyes with a
quizzical look, as if he wasn't quite sure what he was
doing.
His tag glinted in the oncoming headlights-
"Crotchmaster" it said- his tongue was now slurping
again.
This was just getting messy all over my pants- "Bad
Dog!" I yelled out.
Steve0 reluctantly went back to his side of the car.
I focused on the road again, but quickly looked back
at him very confused-
Who dressed my dog was in that shirt and shorts?
Some questions were never meant to be answered I suppose.

Subject: [sfraves] SF liberation radio benefit : Dec 11:1015 folsom: live, dance, and
 djs

Hi folks,
I'll be hosting some of the folks involved with this benefit on the
radio tomorrow morning.  Be sure to listen in, and be sure to support
the cause to.  SFLR has been a GREAT resource for SF over the years,
including amazing coverage during the war protests.

90.1 FM, 9a-Noon (http://kzsulive.stanford.edu)




SFLR is a micro-radio station that has broadcast at
93.7 FM in the S.F. Bay Area for the past 10 years.
SFLR has been a dedicated outlet and resource for
communities underserved by the media mainstream. On
Aug. 19, 2003, S.F. Board of Supervisors supported the
station, citing the need for media diversity in
general, and directed the SF police to leave the
station alone.

On Oct. 16, 2003, Appr. 10 federal agents, 10 S.F.
police, and 5 FCC agents equipped with battering ram
and firearms raided SFLR studios. The FCC confiscated
all equipment in the station. SFLR has been a vocal
critic of the Bush administration policies regarding
the war on terror and on media consolidation in
general.

Currently 10 parent companies control the radio
spectrum. Viacom and Clear Channel alone control 42
percent of listeners and 45 percent of industry
revenue. The FCC and Clear Channel have shut down any
initiative to let communities have their own micro
power radio.

We are responding with nuclear armeggedon.

no, just kidding. we are responding with art,
intellect, media, conversation, live music, and ripper
deejays... 1015 folsom has donated the space for our
insane installation. this benefit is for Liberation
Radio's cause, all the acts artists and producers are
donating their time to make one deafening, fire
spewing act of bass driven futility. was it over when
the germans bombed pearl harbor ?? hell no.

Line-Up:

Live: F-Space, Cookie Mongoloid, Tom Jonesing,
Transcender, Danny Shorago and more

DJ=92s: Adam Ohana, Laird, The Brass Tax / Boombox djs,
Space Cowboys vs. Halon Crew on battledecks with live MC
=2E.. Tom Thump, DJ Seven, Alibi, OOAH,
Chihiro, Daisy Crave, Drei, Jim Yu, and Toph One.

Visuals: DAX, Sherry, Stareway, Digital Dan, goodfoodpro

Performances: Chris Sia (IK) and many other special guests

Thursday Dec 11, 8pm-3am 1015 Folsom SF. $5-$50
donations at the door 21up w/ ID

Liberation Radio has been providing SF with a radio
alternative since 93, Let=92s Show the FCC that SF will
not be silenced!

More info @ liberationradio.net - http://thebraintree.org
links:

http://liberationradio.net
http://sf.indymedia.org
http://www.media-alliance.org/
http://www.mobilization.com
http://www.wearemongoloid.com
http://an-ten-nae.net/
http://thebrasstax.com
http://www.yourblueroom.net/
http://djlaird.com/
http://houseball.com
http://djhalon.com
http://www.stareway.com/
http://thebraintree.org


San Francisco Liberation Radio Raided!


FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE
October 16, 2003
SAN FRANCSICO -- Approximately 10 federal agents, 10
San Francisco police, and 5 FCC agents raided San
Francisco Liberation Radio (SFLR) studios yesterday.
The raid began at 11 a.m., and lasted for
approximately 2 hours. They arrived equipped with
battering ram and firearms, although neither was
necessary. The FCC confiscated all equipment in the
station at the time, including a 16 channel Mackie
sound board, microphones, a computer, CD, record, and
tape players, and so much more.

SFLR and its supporters view this attack within the
context of media consolidation. Currently 10 parent
companies control the radio spectrum. Viacom and Clear
Channel alone control 42 percent of listeners and 45
percent of industry revenue. Since the passage of the
1996 Telecommunications Act Clear Channel grew from 40
stations nationwide to 1,240. In 28 of the 30 major
music formats, 4 companies control over 50 percent of
listeners, and the same holds true for two thirds of
the nations news radio listeners. A debate about media
ownership, competition, localism, and diversity is
currently raging in the halls of Congress, in the
nations court systems, and on the streets. SFLR has
contributed its view of grass roots media activism to
this debate, and for this it has been targeted.

SFLR has been a vocal critic of the Bush
administration policies regarding the war on terror in
Iraq and elsewhere, as well as the California state
and local policies including San Francisco's targeting
of homeless people. The Bush administration has made
every effort to silence criticism of the government.
Dick Cheney, in a rare speech just several days ago
warned against public dissent. Donald Rumsfeld has
clearly insinuated that criticism of Bush
administration policies is killing the American troops
in Iraq. And yet the killing of innocent civilians in
Iraq, Afghanistan, Palestine, and Oakland continues on
a daily basis. The next major anti-war demonstration
is taking place on October 25th, and includes a major
convergence in San Francisco. SFLR sees this
unprecedented attack on the station within the context
of these national and international events.


--=20
braintree / SFLR / dc raves


--=20
"To announce that there must be no criticism of the President or
that we are to stand by the President right or wrong is not only
unpatriotic and servile but it is morally treasonable to the
American public."

-Theodore Roosevelt, 1918

"Opinions are my own only, and do not necessarily represent those of
KZSU Radio or Stanford University." (or words to that effect.)

Subject: [sfraves] EMDEF News:  Rave Act and NYC Cabaret Laws

--=====================_15107713==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

Miami Club Owners Speak Against RAVE Act

Louis Puig, owner of Space34 in Miami, recently blasted the government's 
crackdown on clubs in a written statement: "The notion that Space34 and 
this nation's night clubs are the source of drug abuse in our society is a 
blanket statement that is nothing short of ludicrous.  Listening to music 
and dancing is not a crime.  Our government is using the unconstitutional 
Amber Bill / Rave Act / Crack House Law to try and shut down night clubs, 
concerts and public gatherings.  These establishments should not be blamed 
for the inefficiency of our nation to control the importation, 
distribution, sales and use of illegal drugs.  Shutting down night clubs 
will not stop people from doing drugs."

Crobar Miami's manager Paulo Pincente spoke out against America's RAVE Act 
in DJ Magazine:  "It is jeopardizing the very existence of nightlife in the 
US.  One irresponsible clubber caught with drugs on the premises can 
potentially force the closure of an entire club."  And, the RAVE Act is 
only the tip of what's in store.

If sponsors of two bills in the U.S. House have their way, the CLEAN-UP 
Meth Act of 2003 and the Ecstasy Awareness Act of 2003 will give federal 
prosecutors additional means to shutdown electronic music events and 
venues.  If you haven't already done so, please visit the EM:DEF Action 
Center (link below) and write your Representative to voice your opposition 
to these bills.

     http://www.emdef.org/act

   - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -


New York Cabaret Laws Up for Repeal

The city of New York may repeal a controversial 1926 law which requires 
bars and nightclubs to obtain a special cabaret license if they allow 
dancing.  In 1997, Mayor Giuliani stepped up enforcement of the cabaret law 
as the Nightlife Enforcement Task Force targeted bar and nightclub owners 
in his Quality of Life campaign.  The Bloomberg administration at first 
continued the campaign, but with complaints by activists and business 
owners Gretchen Dykstra, the commissioner of the city's Department of 
Consumer Affairs announced that it will submit a plan to the City Council 
to repeal the law, replacing it with a "nightlife license" addressing 
issues neighbors are concerned about: noise, dirty sidewalks, and 
disorderly patrons.

Legalize Dancing NYC is a group of business owners, dance enthusiasts, dj's 
and concerned citizens working to repeal the jazz era laws that allow the 
citation and closure of bars when their customers are caught dancing.  The 
organization has built a base of support and secured an attorney to 
represent their cause.  Legalize Dancing NYC's next challenge will be 
getting the City Council to approve the repeal plan introduced by 
Bloomberg's office.

Not everyone in the nightclub industry agrees with repealing the cabaret 
laws.  Robert Bookman, a lawyer for the New York Nightlife Association, 
says clubs that went through the expensive and lengthy process of getting a 
license should not see their competitors receive the same benefits with 
none of the cost.

EM:DEF encourages our readers to review the points of view and take action 
accordingly.  If you support the repeal, sign the Legalize Dancing NYC 
petition on their web site.  If you are a resident of New York, e-mail your 
city council member urging them to support the repeal.  Visit the links 
below to learn more.

      http://www.nyna.org/
      http://www.legalizedancingnyc.com/
      http://www.wnbc.com/politics/2650669/detail.html




Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Security is mostly a superstition.  It does not exist in nature, nor do 
the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no 
safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring 
adventure or nothing."
-Helen Keller

"Beware of being too rational.  In the country of the insane, the 
integrated man doesn't become king.  He gets lynched."
-Aldous Huxley, Island

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

At 03:26 PM 12/10/2003, Pauly Morf wrote:
>  He may have one the election, but it was an amazing
>success for the people working at the Gonzalez HQ
>IMHO. Considering the resources they had to deal with.
>AFAIK this is the closest a Green has gotten to a
>major position. We got all the propositions we wanted
>passed.
>
>  Also enjoy this http://lower.org/gavin.html

I confess I was bummed out last night...but the results were very 
encouraging.  One must consider that the very well-entrenched, well funded, 
and highly organized Democratic establishment was behind Newsom.  Matt had 
been campaigning for a few months with a very limited budget vs Newsom's 
year-long effort and millions in contributions.

Change is in the air, and I believe it has nothing to do with political 
parties (ie, Green vs Democrats).  This was one of the most energetic 
campaigns I have been involved with in SF, and Matt did much to move the 
apathetic and cynical into the ranks of the involved and hopeful.  This is 
just the beginning.  The challenge as I see it now is to maintain the raw 
political structure Matt created rather quickly.

Love,

Apollo

Subject: [sfraves] Housemate desparetely needed

Our new guy just told us he has to go... and we need a super cool roomie!!!
Our place is awesome and you should be too :)

Roommate Ad:

***PICS*** Master BR avail. NOW --- __Exquisite Views of SF!!__

We are looking for 1 person to share our spacious, 4-bedroom townhouse, 1 
full and 2 half baths and a GREAT outdoor deck where we enjoy spectacular 
sunsets nightly and incredible postcard views of San Francisco from Yerba 
Buena Island (the lush hill next to Treasure Island, halfway across the Bay 
Bridge)!  Imagine watching all the fireworks shows in the City from the 
comfort of your own home...  Ours is arguably the best unit and view on the 
island! Plus there's lots of tranquil outdoor space on both Yerba Buena and 
Treasure Islands for hiking, biking, picnics and more.  And we rock too!  
The room is available NOW.


THE VIEW from our apartment

Downtown From our home
<a href="http://www.hydrogirl.com/ybi_view/downtown1.jpg"><img 
src="http://www.hydrogirl.com/ybi_view/downtownThumb.jpg" 
align="left">http://www.hydrogirl.com/ybi_view/downtown1.jpg</a>

Downtown with the Bridge
<a href="http://www.hydrogirl.com/ybi_view/downtownBridge.jpg"><img 
src="http://www.hydrogirl.com/ybi_view/downtownBridgeThumb.jpg" 
align="left">http://www.hydrogirl.com/ybi_view/downtownBridge.jpg</a>

The TransAmerica Pyramid from our back deck
<a href="http://www.hydrogirl.com/ybi_view/pyramid1.jpg"><img 
src="http://www.hydrogirl.com/ybi_view/pyramidThumb.jpg" 
align="left">http://www.hydrogirl.com/ybi_view/pyramid1.jpg</a>

(the living room, kitchen, all bedrooms and the back deck all have views 
similar to these images)

The main living space is large with two areas (dining, and a living room 
with high ceilings), a full kitchen (gas), and a huge back-deck.  Did I 
mention the sweeping view of the City? Plus there are a few surprises up our 
sleeves. Basic utilities are INCLUDED with the rent! (see full Amenities 
list below)

San Francisco, Berkeley, AND Oakland are all VERY CONVENIENT to the islands, 
since we're halfway across the Bay Bridge. It's only 4 minutes to downtown 
San Francisco (7-10 with traffic) by car (my commute to and from Oakland is 
a *breeze*) and it's an easy, quick MUNI hop to downtown SF 24/7. 
Additionally, there's a convenience store, an ATM, a Cafe (B'fast/lunch 
only) and nice space for hiking/biking on the island.


THE ROOM:

Master Bedroom: 13.5' x 11.5', Great view of SF skyline!, high ceiling, 
gigantic closet (it runs the full length of the room).  Also, attached to 
this room is a 1/2 bath with a large linen closet.  ($740)  Available Now!


AMENITIES:

Free parking! (also a short, easy MUNI hop downtown)

Free utilities! (electric, gas, H2O and waste removal)

Also: laundry, dishwasher, disposal, DSL / LAN, high ceilings, very safe, 
quiet neighborhood, sunny space, postcard City and sunset view from all 
rooms, large outdoor deck.

We share costs of iDSL, NetFlix, the w/d rental (cheap), bottled H2O, and 
biweekly Planet Organics deliveries.  And we have housecleaners come 
every-other week.


US:

Beth, Danny, and Jessica.  We're all between 24-27 and are very chill but 
like to throw killer parties on occasion, super-friendly, open, ecclectic, 
and looking for someone cool to fill the one remaining void in the house...

Namely, we're looking for someone who wants to build a harmonious, 
cooperative, respectful household that isn't centered around the TV and 
isn't just people locked away in their room.  We don't have to be best of 
friends, but we'd like to at least enjoy your company since we will share 
common space.  (The 3 of us get along famously!)  Mature, respectful 
individuals, please.


YOU:

Employed, 24-33ish, responsible, cool, interested in a respectful, 
cooperative and creative atmosphere, okay with a mish-mash of partying and 
quiet and living in an unbelievable place.

Deposit is $700.

No pets.

Email us and tell us a bit about yourself, like what you're looking for in a 
household/roommates, any questions you may have, and some days/times you 
would be able to meet with us.

Hope to see you here soon!

it failed the first time does not mean you give up.  If that were true
we wouldn't have this country in the first place.  The puritans would've
been slaughtered/died of starvation with no more colonization, and Spain
would probably now have most of the US and still probably have Mexico.

Subject: [sfraves] Gatekeeper Inspection Announcement

My name is Deepfog, though you ought to know that by now if you've paid 
attention for the last, oh, 10 or so years.  A few years ago, I decided 
I am the gatekeeper of San Francisco.  And why not?  Some guy named 
Norton declared himself the Emporer of San Francisco, at least I don't 
rule with an iron fist.

Unless I get pissed off.  And some of you invariably piss me off, so 
I'm going to fly in for an inspection of the city, its contents, its 
inhabitants, its ravers (are there any left?) ... and I'm certain I'll 
be issuing *lots* of citations.  Because for one, you people have moved 
from the East Coast and driven up the rent in my city!  Not to mention 
the late night coalition is still being run by that purple-haired 
pervert!

And, and ...

I will be meeting with the other gatekeepers, Gatekeeper Jr. and 
Gatekeeper  Sr. to discuss the current situation in San Francisco and 
what we intend to do about it, if anything.


See you January 1st.   And don't beat yourself up if you can't figure 
this email out.  I've been trying unsuccessfully to figure myself out 
for years.

-d

Date: Thu, 11 Dec 2003 02:14:25 -0800 (PST)
From: Dj Gram <synthesoundproductions@yahoo.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <Law15-F34b1z7SXccqw00021468@hotmail.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative; boundary="0-136292742-1071137665=:29558"
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] I THINK THIS SAYS IT ALL (Tips Please On How TO Get Started DJ'N *not for me*)

--0-136292742-1071137665=:29558
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

Word.......as a still somewhat beginner DJ I can definitely agree with Joey.  I thought it was going to be the easiest thing in the world to beat match two records when I first started spinning (seeing as I have a musical background and am good at math.)  I wanted to try to incorporated all theses neat little DJ tricks into all my little mixes and look cool.  All that happened was I sounded like shit and made an ass of myself in front of a bunch of my friends.  Best advice I could give would be: Master your beat matching.......Don't let the tables beat your ass, any two records can mix.......When you are at home, no matter how many people you have over (unless you are having a party and you are the DJ) you are learning, not preforming, Don't worry about looking cool, just keep your head in your mix and get it right.......Don't freak out and over compensate if the beats start train recking.........If your headphones have a nob on your mixer that pans from channel to channel USE IT,
 you will learn to love it and thank me later.........Keep one ear in your headphones at all times so you can tell what sound is coming from what record (very important for new DJs who haven't gotten to know their tracks yet, also good with new records)............LEARN YOUR RECORDS........Don't be afraid of your pitch control adjuster, if one record keeps losing the beat adjust the pitch accordingly..........AND LAST BUT CERTAINLY NOT LEAST, this shit takes time, DON'T GIVE UP!!!
-Graham
Hope that helped........

Joey Frisco <josephwhunt@hotmail.com> wrote:
I'd suggest working your ass off to get your beat matching on point before 
you try to learn any tricks. Beat matching is the most fundamental and 
important thing when mixing. It doesn't matter how many tricks you can do, 
or how on point you can cut if your beats sound like sneakers in the dryer. 
After that, I'd work on phrasing and cutting. Then programming a set, I 
guess. If you can figure out all of those things, you're in a better place 
then half of the people who pretend to be dj's. Oh, and once you've learned 
to beat match fairly consistantly, learn to pitch-bend (adjusting the pitch 
live without touching the platter). This makes your live performance sound 
a lot cleaner (I'm still working on my pitch bending, touching the platter 
is a hard habit to break, if I had to start over again I'd learn to only 
pitch bend). Once you've mastered the fundamentals, you can learn new ways 
to mix, fade, cut, drop, and scratch; but I'd wait until I had the other 
stuff down before I worked on the advanced stuff.
Cheers and goodluck,
Joey

__

__ // // --\\__//__\\
// // // ||\\

\\_// ______________

josephwhunt@hotmail.com

of womens sufferage, resegregated public offices and replace white
people in positions that were majority black again.  Change takes time
without forceful revolution and if people keep voting republican or
democrat, no change will ever be made as the parties both become more
and more the same.  We may lose at first and it may cost us dearly, but
the mistakes that Wilson made and the people of that time remember, his
would be sucessor lost by the largest landslide in presidential history
to a republican who hadn't campaigned at all.  We've got to be the
change we want to see, not continue to choose the lesser of two evils in
our minds.  Bush's popularity rating for reelcection is very low, and
you're right, if more people vote green and Dean loses because of it
that doesn't mean it wasn't in vain.  3% registered voters in San
Francisco were Green yet Gonzales still pulled 47% of the vote.  People
want change.  People are waking up.  Bush has made too many mistakes for

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Newsom




What?  If half the Greens who voted for Nader in Florida voted for Gore
instead, Bush would not be in office now.

Voting green is a great fantasy.. but the reality of politics dictate
you fight your political wars one battle at a time.  And the battle now
is to remove Bush by any means necessary.

What good is a 3rd party... when all it will do is insure constant
victory for the Republicans?

-troy

Subject: RE: [sfraves] Newsom

I'm not talking about the individuals in power alone.  I'm talking more
about the parties themselves, the lobbying, the co-sponsored bills.  I
mean when you have Hatch and Kennedy writing bills together, that's just
enough right there to see ultra-conservative mormon and drunken liberal
catholic working together as if they were the same party.  The special
interests and their own personal interests are what run them.  They're
so well established that it doesn't really matter who's in office
because both are going to pass bad bills, and make up for it with a few
good bills.  Clinton's track record was better than Bush, but Clinton
was no way near being an incredible president, what with the Rwandan
massacre and our stuff over in Kosovo.  Its all about charisma and
telling people what they want to hear to join your cause.  What I see in
the green party although I myself don't claim a party is more of a
rebel, get things done, anti-big business aspect to them which reminds
me a lot of the radical republicas.  The whigs and the torries were
finally replaced, we need to start trying to replace the dems and repubs
because they've become too comfortable, too uncaring and too greedy.

-Rayn

from the bar.  Why???? I had a bloody good experience playing at =

and making people move to me is the best feeling in the world, and WELL =
worth it.=20

to keep up with. I just play anything that is dark and has a good beat. =

there, and whatever else I can dig out of my record box. It's definitely =
something different.=20

 sfraves@hyperreal.org
To: Troy Sheets <tsheets@atari.saturn5.com>
From: Starchild <sfdreamer@earthlink.net>
In-Reply-To: <20031211202500.GK9535@atari.saturn5.com>
Message-Id: <4876AB7E-2CA2-11D8-AF4A-003065DA480A@earthlink.net>
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Mailer: Apple Mail (2.553)
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Re: Republicans and Democrats -- how different are they, really?

	When you look at the big picture, the two establishment parties are 
almost exactly alike. A few years back during the Clinton 
administration, there was a huge fight over the budget. There was talk 
of the government experiencing a temporary "shutdown" because the two 
sides couldn't agree. Guess how much of a difference in the federal 
budget the Republicans and Democrats were fighting over? Four percent! 
In the big picture this is practically nothing!

	Republican politicians talk a good game of being fiscally prudent and 
standing up for ordinary taxpayers. The reality is that they vote for 
bigger government and more spending right along with the Democrats. Now 
that Republicans control the presidency and both houses of Congress, 
spending is going up even faster than when Clinton was in charge. Of 
course government spending more money sooner or later means government 
taking more money out of your pocket.

	Democrats likewise talk a good game about being for civil liberties 
and civil rights. The reality is they go right along with Republicans 
in pouring billions of dollars into the war on drugs, imposing stiffer 
and stiffer criminal penalties, and passing unconstitutional laws that 
trash the Bill of Rights and ramp up the police state. It was a 
Democratic Senator who sponsored the anti-rave "Reducing America's 
Vulnerability to Ecstasy" legislation.

	Bush has killed innocent civilians by bombing other countries. So did 
Clinton, usually supported by Democrats in Congress. He bombed Sudan 
and Bosnia, and sent troops to Bosnia, Kosovo, and Somalia. Democratic 
presidents got the United States into both World Wars, the Korean War, 
and the Vietnam War. Both Republican and Democrat leaders use military 
power as a tool not to champion freedom and democracy around the world 
where people are oppressed, but in order to advance U.S. interests or 
maintain the global status quo on behalf of their buddies who run the 
other governments of the world. Both parties have supported an 
expanding military budget and maintaining a large nuclear arsenal even 
after the Soviet Union collapsed from the weight of its own bloated and 
super-powerful government.

	Both Republicans and Democrats favor continuing the "winner take all" 
voting system and restrictive ballot access and campaign laws that 
place alternative parties like the Libertarians and Greens at a 
disadvantage. Each establishment party seeks to keep its supporters 
afraid the other party is going to do something horrible to them, thus 
they keep Americans voting for one or the other half of the two-party 
duopoly. In reality, Democrat and Republican leaders share the same 
primary concern: Maintaining their ability to control us and spend our 
money.

								<<< Starchild >>>


"The only partisan difference was that the Democrat bashed the budget 
before making the case for more money, while the Republican praised the 
budget before asking for more."

	-Michael Lynch of Reason Magazine, commenting on a "Hardball" TV show 
exchange between representatives of the two parties over Bush's budget, 
April 12, 2001 (http://reason.com/ml/ml041201.shtml)


On Thursday, December 11, 2003, at 12:25  PM, Troy Sheets wrote:

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Re: Republicans and Democrats -- how different are they, really?

Did you even read the link I posted?

Apparently not, else you wouldn't have missed out on
this:
(I'm cutting and pasting the Race section because
you're a lazy fuck, and like commenting on things
before you read them)

8. Race. Moore does not directly state that Heston is
a racist--he is the master of creating the false
impression --but reviewers come away saying "Heston
looks like an idiot, and a racist one at that" Source.
"BTW, one thing the Heston interview did clear up,
that man is shockingly racist." Source.

    The remarks stem from Heston's answer (after Moore
keeps pressing for why the US has more violence than
other countries) that it might be due to the US
"having a more mixed ethnicity" than other nations,
and "We had enough problems with civil rights in the
beginning." A viewer who accepts Moore's theme that
gun ownership is driven by racial fears might conclude
that Heston is blaming blacks and the civil rights
movement.

    But if you look at some history missing from
Bowling, you get exactly the opposite picture. Heston
is talking, not about race, but about racism. In the
early 1960s, the civil rights movement was fighting
for acceptance. Civil rights workers were being
murdered. The Kennedy Administration, trying to hold
together a Democratic coalition that ranged from
liberals to fire-eater segregationists such as George
Wallace and Lester Maddox, found the issue too hot to
touch, and offered little support.

    Heston got involved. He picketed discriminating
restaurants. He worked with Martin Luther King, and
helped King break Hollywood's color barrier (yes,
there was one.). He led the actors' component of
King's 1963 march in Washington, which set the stage
for the key civil rights legislation in 1964.

    Here's Heston's comments at the 2001 Congress on
Racial Equality Martin Luther King dinner (presided
over by NRA director, and CORE President, Roy Innes).
More on Heston.

    Most of the viewers were born long after the
events Heston is recalling. To them, the civil rights
struggle consists of Martin Luther King speaking,
people singing "We Shall Overcome," and everyone
coming to their senses. Heston remembers what it was
really like.

    If Heston fails to explain this in Bowling, we've
got to note that Moore (despite his claim that he left
the interview almost unedited) cut a lot of the
interview out. Watch closely and you'll see a clock on
the wall near Moore's head. When it's first seen, the
time is about 5:47. When Heston finally walks out, it
reads about 6:10. That's 23 minutes. I clocked the
Heston interview in Bowling at 5 1/4 minutes. About
three-quarters of what Heston did say was trimmed out.
[Why the clock indicates six o'clock, when Moore is
specific that he showed up for the interview at 8:30
AM, will have to await another investigation!]

This is the LAST BSP you will see from us. Tickets are close to gone (no...
really... you guys are starting to wake up out there!) and it seems like

tickets are $15 so don't slack and end up paying more! Even if you did pay

:: r y a n ::

<!-- Original.BSP.below -->

I'm sure a lot of your remember the last Sticky party from 420 this past
April. If you were there then you also know what to expect in terms of food,
drink., and most important music and friends! This Saturday, December 13th
we once again bring you Sticky!

The holiday madness is upon us and it's time to get everyone under one roof
for a family reunion. We've prepared a solid lineup the SF Bay's finest
house, breaks, and downtempo for your listening enjoyment. The key to any
Sticky event is the space. Remember how amazing that last spot was?? Well
we've got another NEW space that really is NEW! No, really... it's badass
space that hasn't been used for a party until now. The space is a large,
cozy 2 room loft with ample outdoor space complete with a garden in back and
fire pit! How many spots in SF do you know like that? I sure as hell haven't
seen the like. The fire pit will surely add to the charm and warmth that
surrounds this holiday season.

Like the last Sticky, all drinks and food are complimentary. Translated...
free open bar with free food to match. Drink up, eat lots and be funky like
always! Food and drink wise we'll have a lot just like the last time. I
don't think anyone was hungry or complained about lack of "spirits"

This party is being powered by Evite and we would *GREATLY* appreciate you
letting us know via Evite if you intend to come. The link is below. You can
use PayPal too!

<http://www.evite.com/pages/invite/viewInvite.jsp?event=ZASBJHNMHVMIZVNEUZAZ
&unknownUser=true>

For those that want to get tickets and are local
(Emeryville//SF//Oakland//Berkeley//Walnut Creek) I have tickets. Reply here
or at ryan@sninesix.com. To arrange ticket pickup//drop off.

This is a limited capacity event! Spread the word to your friends that don't
know and we'll see all of you in a few days!

STICKY II
A holiday cocktail getdown (translates to get drunk until you fall down)

9pm - 4am (or later)
2 Rooms of Music
Very Limited Capacity (150 Tix)
SF Location (near Candlestick Park)

:: the.space ::

2 Room Loft (Old Fashion Country Style Mansion)
Large Outdoor Garden with Fire Pit (No more smoking in the cold)
Very Comfortable, Good Ventilation, & Room To Spread Out!

:: refreshments :: FREE

Open Bar Till Close (4am)
Beer: Rock Bottom Brewery
Spirits: Vodka, Rum, Gin, & Tequila
Wine: Merlot & Pinot
Specialty: Jell-O Shots
Mixers galore or bring your own for those that want to add some flair

:: snacks :: duh - FREE

Finger Foods, Hors d'oeurves, Fruit, Candy, & Ganja Treats!

:: line.em.up ::

:: The "NICE" THUMP ROOM ::

ADNAN

:: support ::

Sierra & Twilight :: 4 Corner Crystal Clear Bass Bumpin Sound

:: tickets//invitations ::

Pre-Paid Invitation Only, Friends of Friends..
All Persons must RSVP to Reserve space

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Security is mostly a superstition.  It does not exist in nature, nor do 
the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no 
safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring 
adventure or nothing."
-Helen Keller

"Beware of being too rational.  In the country of the insane, the 
integrated man doesn't become king.  He gets lynched."
-Aldous Huxley, Island

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"  
--=====================_4294885==.ALT--

Yea, this is part of that speech Heston made...enjoy.

"But on the other hand, I find my blood pressure rising when Clinton's 
cultural shock troops participate in homosexual-rights fund-raisers but 
boycott gun-rights fund-raisers... and then claim it's time to place 
homosexual men in tents with Boy Scouts, and suggest that sperm donor babies 
born into lesbian relationships are somehow better served and more loved.

Such demands have nothing to do with equality. They're about the currency of 
cultural war—money and votes—and the Clinton camp will let anyone in the 
tent if there's a donkey on his hat, or a check in the mail or some yen in 
the fortune cookie.

Mainstream America is depending on you—counting on you—to draw your sword 
and fight for them. These people have precious little time or resources to 
battle misguided Cinderella attitudes, the fringe propaganda of the 
homosexual coalition, the feminists who preach that it's a divine duty for 
women to hate men, blacks who raise a militant fist with one hand while they 
seek preference with the other, and all the New-Age apologists for juvenile 
crime, who see roving gangs as a means of youthful expression, sex as a 
means of adolescent merchandising, violence as a form of entertainment for 
impressionable minds, and gun bans as a means to lord-knows-what. We've 
reached that point in time when our national social policy originates on 
Oprah. I say it's time to pull the plug."


Yea...he says he was involved with MLK way back when, but then turns around 
and spews this kind of shit. He's not intolerant or leaning entirely on 
stereotypes at all...noooooooo...not ol' Chuck.

M-

>Did you even read the link I posted?

>Apparently not, else you wouldn't have missed out on
>this:
>(I'm cutting and pasting the Race section because
>you're a lazy fuck, and like commenting on things
>before you read them)
>
>8. Race. Moore does not directly state that Heston is
>a racist--he is the master of creating the false
>impression --but reviewers come away saying "Heston
>looks like an idiot, and a racist one at that" Source.
>"BTW, one thing the Heston interview did clear up,
>that man is shockingly racist." Source.
>
>     The remarks stem from Heston's answer (after Moore
>keeps pressing for why the US has more violence than
>other countries) that it might be due to the US
>"having a more mixed ethnicity" than other nations,
>and "We had enough problems with civil rights in the
>beginning." A viewer who accepts Moore's theme that
>gun ownership is driven by racial fears might conclude
>that Heston is blaming blacks and the civil rights
>movement.
>
>     But if you look at some history missing from
>Bowling, you get exactly the opposite picture. Heston
>is talking, not about race, but about racism. In the
>early 1960s, the civil rights movement was fighting
>for acceptance. Civil rights workers were being
>murdered. The Kennedy Administration, trying to hold
>together a Democratic coalition that ranged from
>liberals to fire-eater segregationists such as George
>Wallace and Lester Maddox, found the issue too hot to
>touch, and offered little support.
>
>     Heston got involved. He picketed discriminating
>restaurants. He worked with Martin Luther King, and
>helped King break Hollywood's color barrier (yes,
>there was one.). He led the actors' component of
>King's 1963 march in Washington, which set the stage
>for the key civil rights legislation in 1964.
>
>     Here's Heston's comments at the 2001 Congress on
>Racial Equality Martin Luther King dinner (presided
>over by NRA director, and CORE President, Roy Innes).
>More on Heston.
>
>     Most of the viewers were born long after the
>events Heston is recalling. To them, the civil rights
>struggle consists of Martin Luther King speaking,
>people singing "We Shall Overcome," and everyone
>coming to their senses. Heston remembers what it was
>really like.
>
>     If Heston fails to explain this in Bowling, we've
>got to note that Moore (despite his claim that he left
>the interview almost unedited) cut a lot of the
>interview out. Watch closely and you'll see a clock on
>the wall near Moore's head. When it's first seen, the
>time is about 5:47. When Heston finally walks out, it
>reads about 6:10. That's 23 minutes. I clocked the
>Heston interview in Bowling at 5 1/4 minutes. About
>three-quarters of what Heston did say was trimmed out.
>[Why the clock indicates six o'clock, when Moore is
>specific that he showed up for the interview at 8:30
>AM, will have to await another investigation!]
>
>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Re: Republicans and Democrats -- how different are they, really?

Did you even read what you just pasted?

His views expressed in your excerpts below are not
fighting against the groups he mentions, rather he is
upset by the back-handed hypocritical nature of what
drives tolerance and acceptance.
 
The paragraph immediately preceeding the one you
pasted is this:

"The gay and lesbian movement is another good example.
Many homosexuals are hugely talented artists and
executives... also dear friends. I don't despise their
lifestyle, though I don't share it. As long as gay and
lesbian Americans are as productive, law-abiding and
private as the rest of us, I think America owes them
absolute tolerance. It's the right thing to do."

My take on him (after reading his entire speech here:
http://www.vpc.org/nrainfo/speech.html ) is that yeah,
he's an old guy, and consequently has some
old-fashioned ideas about certain things, but on the
whole seems to be all about an America where everyone
is equal- period.  We all have the same rights and
opportunities, and nobody has to feel bad about who
they are.
That's what I'm about too.

So that's that- in any case, the racist and intolerant
way he was portrayed by Moore was ridiculous by any
measure.

(and go look up the word "stereotype"- a stereotype,
by definition, is true)

> >a racist--he is the master of creating the false
> >impression --but reviewers come away saying "Heston
> >looks like an idiot, and a racist one at that"
> Source.
> >"BTW, one thing the Heston interview did clear up,
> >that man is shockingly racist." Source.
> >
> >     The remarks stem from Heston's answer (after
> Moore
> >keeps pressing for why the US has more violence
> than
> >other countries) that it might be due to the US
> >"having a more mixed ethnicity" than other nations,
> >and "We had enough problems with civil rights in
> the
> >beginning." A viewer who accepts Moore's theme that
> >gun ownership is driven by racial fears might
> conclude
> >that Heston is blaming blacks and the civil rights
> >movement.
> >
> >     But if you look at some history missing from
> >Bowling, you get exactly the opposite picture.
> Heston
> >is talking, not about race, but about racism. In
> the
> >early 1960s, the civil rights movement was fighting
> >for acceptance. Civil rights workers were being
> >murdered. The Kennedy Administration, trying to
> hold
> >together a Democratic coalition that ranged from
> >liberals to fire-eater segregationists such as
> George
> >Wallace and Lester Maddox, found the issue too hot
> to
> >touch, and offered little support.
> >
> >     Heston got involved. He picketed
> discriminating
> >restaurants. He worked with Martin Luther King, and
> >helped King break Hollywood's color barrier (yes,
> >there was one.). He led the actors' component of
> >King's 1963 march in Washington, which set the
> stage
> >for the key civil rights legislation in 1964.
> >
> >     Here's Heston's comments at the 2001 Congress
> on
> >Racial Equality Martin Luther King dinner (presided
> >over by NRA director, and CORE President, Roy
> Innes).
> >More on Heston.
> >
> >     Most of the viewers were born long after the
> >events Heston is recalling. To them, the civil
> rights
> >struggle consists of Martin Luther King speaking,
> >people singing "We Shall Overcome," and everyone
> >coming to their senses. Heston remembers what it
> was
> >really like.
> >
> >     If Heston fails to explain this in Bowling,
> we've
> >got to note that Moore (despite his claim that he
> left
> >the interview almost unedited) cut a lot of the
> >interview out. Watch closely and you'll see a clock
> on
> >the wall near Moore's head. When it's first seen,
> the
> >time is about 5:47. When Heston finally walks out,
> it
> >reads about 6:10. That's 23 minutes. I clocked the
> >Heston interview in Bowling at 5 1/4 minutes. About
> >three-quarters of what Heston did say was trimmed
> out.
> >[Why the clock indicates six o'clock, when Moore is
> >specific that he showed up for the interview at
> 8:30
> >AM, will have to await another investigation!]
> >
> >
> >
> >--- Van Mundegaarde <electrofunk138@hotmail.com>
> >wrote:
> > > Yea, but no matter if you factor in the movie or
> > > not, Charleton Heston IS a
> > > racist, insensitive lunatic.
> > >
> > > Can we say fundamentalist Christian anyone?
> > >
> > > M-
> > >
> > >

I got there earlier 'caue I got outta class early... so yeah..there was some dude upstairs apinning like house & stuff... la la la.. i went down stairs & saw this dork on the tables spinning an Awesome Acid Breakbeat set.. Good shit... oh, it wasn't a dork.. it was Tyler!!!  It was a fun set!!  Loved it Tyler! =)

OK... so ok...  CJ's set (CAlaminty Jane) was sooooo fuckin' Awesome...  good shit man... she spun a wonderful Awesome set of BAd Ass Breakbeats, I think I might a heard some hard house tunes in there.. but oooooooooh man... her breakbeats were heaven!!!  I mean... seriously.. CJ know's what tracks go good 2gether in her soup of records she was pinning & I mean... every fcukin' time I see her spin.. I'm on a fuckni' HIGH after that... but man... I think i mighta heard some new vinyl??  Awesome!!!  But yeah... i must also add that her "behind- the-decks-while-she-spinning" dancing has actually now evolved some... she doing more foward body bobswhile she spins & ooh man... when she twirls her hair when she's all you go girlfriend knob tweakin kinda 'tude... it's actually pretty sexy!!  LoL  Really! =)  OK... I"m buggin'!  

OK.. Michael Anthony came on next after her... & it was Awesome... I mean.. he was spinning this like tribal house set then i dunno... it got like into kinda prog house i think... but ok.. he asked me what I wanted 2 hear... I said BREAKBEATS... & OK.. Hello 2day... he busted out this Awesome BReakbeats Track.. ok.. I was like dancing.. then I sat next 2 CJ in the airport seeats... & she was diggin' the track as much as I was... as it turned out... it was an import & ooh man... it was totally sweet!

but his whole set was AWesome... well.. I was diggin' more on the breakbeats...

OK... than after him... Blooshaman spun... mmmmmmm.. more Acid Breakbeats... I Loved it... then he went in2 some tracne.. OK... later in heis set.. I could sworn he bumped something that was like a hybrib of Electroclash & trance or soemthing... LoL... it was Awesome!!  I mean.. I always have fun when Blooshaman spins...

Upstairs.. there was alota house DJs spinning this & that... I Loved it!!  But not aw much as what went on downstairs... =)

OK.. the Crowd was Groovy... LoL.. I was so happy 'cause well as it turned out... JC was there & WOW.. we had soooooooooo much 2 talk about... Hello 2day... things ranging from like well... 800 miles away & stuff... Philip Diaz was there

Oh oh oh oh... ok.. so like I met Hiedi from here... What Up Girl =)  She is sooooo Awesome!!! I had the best time hangin' out w/ her & man...we can like talk  & talk & talk & talk & talk & talk as we did 4 like almost an hour lastnight about eeeeeeeeeeverything!!! LoL

JBlaze came by & we kicked it... it was Dope... he brought this Awesome girl..I 4got her name.. but she was fun... LoL... we were all like dancing 2 Blooshamans set downstairs & she was all like well.. she almost dances like Molly Ringwald in breakfast club...

Oh gosh.. who else was there... ooh oh oh .. so like after Sublounge closed... JBlaze, Girl, & I were outside chilin'... then we well.. they were talkn' 2 someone else... but i was talkin' 2 these Irish Dudes who live in the mission & we like lol.. well.. they were hella funny 2 hang out... LoL... oh yeah.. there's a new dance I learned called the 1,2,3 stop & pose dance... anyway... it's god 2 like do htat during house music... anywaze,, it was a fun night

So JBlaze said he'd bring me home so like afterwards.. we had soup & icecream @ her placein the mission.. it was fun...

Oh Gosh man..I had suck a fun time lastnight!!! =)
