Have Yourself a Pentagon Christmas

By Nick Turse, <http://www.tomdispatch.com>tomdispatch.com
December 22, 2003

'Tis the season for putting wish lists together! It's the least the toy 
industry expects of you. After all, according to the National Retail 
Federation, $217 billion in holiday sales are up for grabs and an anxious 
toy industry is hoping to take home a sizeable chunk of that (especially 
given last year's weak $20.3 billion toy market).

As for you, it's never too early to head into the mall maelstrom in search 
of the hottest toy in shortest supply for your child. Toy industry pundits 
and child experts are rushing out their lists of recommendations. If you 
want to catch that blank look of disappointment on your child's face this 
Christmas morning, by all means follow their advice. Go buy Hasbro's BTR 
Transformer off the Toy Wishes "Hot Dozen" list; K'nex's Rippin' Rocket 
Roller Coaster, one of FamilyFun magazine's "Toys of the Year" or strip 
those shelves of Mattel's Hokey Pokey Elmo from KB Toys annual "Holiday Hot 
Toy List."

But if you'd really like to "wow" the kids, stick to this list of "Hot as 
Depleted Uranium Toys for a New Imperial Age."

You surely don't want to deny your child the right to strut an 
aircraft-carrier flight deck or duke it out in person with Osama bin Laden. 
So from the Pentagon to you, via us, comes the A (for "Armed to the Teeth") 
list of presents sure to make this a true military-industrial Christmas!

America's Last Action Heroes

What would the holidays be without little muscularized, molded plastic 
dolls holding big guns in a kung-fu battle grip?

Now, thanks to Blue Box International your child can pilot Air Force One 
into Baghdad with 
<http://www.etoys.com/genProduct.html/PID/2431939/ctid/17/ls/default>Elite 
Force Aviator: George W. Bush, the greatest American hero, dolled-up in 
Naval Aviator regalia – a fully posable 12" action figure in "g-pants." 
"Actual figure," warns the maker, "may vary slightly from item shown" 
(which is so totally Mission Accomplished!) Then, for only an extra $29.95 
(plus shipping and handling) your child can feed the troops a turkey dinner 
using the <http://www.talkingpresidents.com/products-af-bush.shtml>George 
W. Bush Talking Action Figure, the aviator's civilian counterpart, clad in 
the more traditional Republican dark suit and red power tie. He spouts 17 
phrases including the apropos Bush-ism "...working hard to put food on your 
family..."

And that's only the beginning! Just imagine your son holding his own news 
conference with 
<http://www.talkingpresidents.com/products-af-rummy.shtml>the Talking 
Donald "Rummy" Rumsfeld Action Figure ($29.99 plus shipping and handling) 
to announce that weapons of mass destruction have just been discovered in 
Bethesda, Maryland. Press his button and catch 28 different phrases from 
"Rumstud" (as the Elite Aviator likes to call him) including the classic: 
"I believe what I said yesterday. I don't know what I said. But I know what 
I think. I assume that's what I said."

And you California parents, don't miss 
<http://store1.yimg.com/I/herobuilders_1761_1965385>the Talking Governator, 
hero of Total Recall, the movie and the election, in plastic form... or 
call him Robot Arnie and fight the world with 
<http://www.etoys.com/genProduct.html/PID/2458879/ctid/17/ls/default>the 
T-850 Terminator in his black-leather get-up.

http://www.alternet.org/story.html?StoryID=17436




Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Security is mostly a superstition.  It does not exist in nature, nor do 
the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no 
safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring 
adventure or nothing."
-Helen Keller

"Beware of being too rational.  In the country of the insane, the 
integrated man doesn't become king.  He gets lynched."
-Aldous Huxley, Island

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"  
--=====================_881737==.ALT--

AMBER ALERT
 

 

Please look at the picture and then forward it on. 

Maybe if every one passes this on someone will see this child, that is how the girl from Stevens Point was found by circulation of her picture on tv.  The internet circulates even overseas South America, and Canada etc. Thanks 
Please pass this to everyone in your address book. 


We have a store manager (Wal-Mart) from Longs, SC who has a  9 year old daughter who has been missing for 2 weeks. Keep the picture moving on. 
With luck on her side she will be found. 
I am asking you all,  begging you to please forward this email 
on to anyone and everyone you know,  PLEASE.   My 9 year old girl, 
Penny Brown,  is missing.   She has been missing for now two weeks.. 
It is still not too late.  Please help us.  If anyone anywhere 
knows anything,  please contact me at: zicozicozico@hotmail.com 
I am including a picture of her.   All prayers are appreciated!! 
It only takes 2 seconds to forward this on.   If it was your child, 
you would want all the help you could get. 
Thank you for your kindness.  Hopefully you can help us.

> >  
> > 
> >  
> >

> >

> > this child, that is
> > how the girl from Stevens Point was found by
> > circulation of her picture
> > on tv.  The internet circulates even overseas South
> > America, and Canada
> > etc. Thanks

> > who has a  9 year old

> > picture moving on.

> > this email 
> > on to anyone and everyone you know,  PLEASE.   My 9
> > year old girl, 
> > Penny Brown,  is missing.   She has been missing for
> > now two weeks..

> > anyone anywhere

> > I am asking you all, begging you to please forward
> > this email 
> > on to anyone and everyone you know, PLEASE. My 9
> > year old girl, 
> > Penny Brown, is missing. She has been missing for
> > now two weeks.. 
> > It is still not too late. Please help us. If
> > anyone anywhere 
> > knows anything, please contact me at:
> > zicozicozico@hotmail.com 
> > I am including a picture of her. All prayers are
> > appreciated!! 
> > It only takes 2 seconds to forward this on. If it
> > was your child, 
> > you would want all the help you could get. 
> > Thank you for your kindness. Hopefully you can help
> > us. 
> > 
> > 
> > 
> > 
> > 
> > 
> > 
> > 
> > 
> > >

Subject: [sfraves] PHUTURO was SO DOPE Lastnight!

OK... so Jaze picks me up & we head 2 the City... we stop by a friends pad & for a while well.. some kinda adventure started... then we treked over to The Top 4 Phuturo... 

OK... I gotta say man... it rocked so damn hard lastnight!!!  Genome, Raise, Juju, and 4 Real were doin' this Bad Ass tag set playin' all these hard Jungle tracks the whole night through!  The crowd was Sik!  I mean... the dance floor was rockin' as hard as the DJs spinning... there was this Mondo Groovy vibe I totally felt...

It was really just an amazing night... other than the Super Amount of energy in the club... I got 2 spend time w/ the Junglist Crew I been hella missin'!!  Hello 2day, Almost all the old schools were out lastnight!!  So Dope!!

I seriously musta danced so long & hard 'cause all the elements mixed 2gether totally filled me up & man... it was just fuckin' Awesome man... there was this moment that was kinda CooL when I was dancing like in the middle of the floor & I had my eyes closed & jus' moved however the music made me... but aside from that... I spent most my time up in the front by the DJ booth w/ Audio Angel dancin' up a storm!

I dunno man.. there's not 2 much else 2 say about how Dope it was last night... I mean.. the energy carried through 'til the end of the night & Jaze & I left totally satisfied with out time there!!  I mean... like right now, I'm still hella Happy about lastnight man... I got this mondo afterglow 'cause yeah... LoL... hello 2Day.. y'all know what I'm sayin' by now... LoL

Totally Fun Stuff man! =)



Take Care,

Subject: [sfraves] Happy Holidays, sfraves

--=====================_9477497==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

Wishing all of you a happy holiday and a new year filled with love, light 
and liberty.

I, for one, am happy to see 2003 go away.  It was a year filled with much 
darkness, divisiveness and violence IMO.  Hoping there is some positive 
change in the new  year.

A raver from another list forwarded the lyrics to what has become the 
Holiday hit single in the UK.

It's a re-working of the 1982 Tears for fears song "Mad World" sung by the 
unknown Gary Jules.  Just a simple vocal and piano recording with no post
production. The song is haunting and captured the popular mood at the end 
of a rather sad year.

Here are the lyrics for the British Christmas hit of 2003:

 >>

All around me are familiar faces
Worn out places, worn out faces
Bright and early for their daily races
Going nowhere, going nowhere
And their tears are filling up their glasses
No expression, no expression
Hide my head I want to drown my sorrow
No tomorrow, no tomorrow
And I find it kind of funny
I find it kind of sad
The dreams in which I'm dying
Are the best I've ever had
I find it hard to tell you
'Cos I find it hard to take
When people run in circles
It's a very, very
Mad World
Children waiting for the day they feel good
Happy Birthday, Happy Birthday
Made to feel the way that every child should
Sit and listen, sit and listen
Went to school and I was very nervous
No one knew me, no one knew me
Hello teacher tell me what's my lesson
Look right through me, look right through me

 >>

Much love to all of you, sfraves,

Apollo




Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Security is mostly a superstition.  It does not exist in nature, nor do 
the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no 
safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring 
adventure or nothing."
-Helen Keller

"Beware of being too rational.  In the country of the insane, the 
integrated man doesn't become king.  He gets lynched."
-Aldous Huxley, Island

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"  
--=====================_9477497==.ALT--

Subject: [sfraves] BSP:  Legends of House Tonight

--=====================_17590964==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed


Legends of House 6.0

Mickey "Mixin" Oliver (Hot Mix 5-Chicago)
Jesse Saunders "The Originator of House" (Chicago)
Sen Sei and DJ David Coleman (Thump Radio/Kinetic/Atwater)
Dusty Crates in the lounge

A Holiday Gift to All! RSVP by Midnight Thurday December 25 and receive Free
Admission to Legends Of House 6.0 on Friday December 26th for you and up to Six
of your friends (We must receive the first and last names of all guests). All
guests must arrive by 11pm for FREE ADMISSION. Otherwise admission is $10 all
evening. Doors open 9 pm - 4 am.

Mickey "Mixin" Oliver - (Hot Mix 5 - Chicago)

Mickey "Mixin" Oliver was a founding member of Chicago's Legendary Hot Mix 5.
Along with Farley "Jackmaster" funk, Scott "Smokin" Silz, Ralphi Rosario and
Kenny "Jammin" Jason. Together they were the first crew to bring House Music to
the airwaves. On any given Chicago night the Hot Mix 5 was on the air, up to
500,000 listeners tuned in(1/6 of the city's pop.). Mickey "Mixin" Oliver's
hundreds of credits include classics "You used to hold me", "Pump up the Acid",
and "I want your Love". This is Mickey "Mixin" Oliver's first San Francisco
appearance in over 10 years and is a must see appearance.

Jesse Saunders (Chicago) - Artist/Producer/Remixer/DJ. Known worldwide as the
Originator of House Music. He wrote, produced and released the first House
record titled "On & On". Jesse Saunders production credits include works 
for the
likes of De La Soul, George Clinton, Rick James, and Paula Abdul just to name a
few. Additionally, Jesse wrote and produced the best selling House Music record
ever "Love Can't Turn Around". Jesse Saunders is knownworldwide and his DJ sets
are always one of a kind. This night we celebrate the release of his single
released on Broken Records/King Street "Everybody".

Sen-Sei & David Coleman (San Francisco, Thumpradio/Atwater Synicate/Kinetic
Grooves). Since 1995 Sen-Sei and DJ David Coleman have moved the San Francisco
scene to a new level. Their partnership is a perfect blend of two unique
talents. Sen-Sei is like the maestro behind the keyboards and David Coleman DJ
sets rank as some of the best in the Bay Area. You will always find this duo
listed on any Top Ten DJ ranking in the Bay Area.

time: 10 pm - 4 am
admission: $10, 21+
location: Club Six







Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Security is mostly a superstition.  It does not exist in nature, nor do 
the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no 
safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring 
adventure or nothing."
-Helen Keller

"Beware of being too rational.  In the country of the insane, the 
integrated man doesn't become king.  He gets lynched."
-Aldous Huxley, Island

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"  
--=====================_17590964==.ALT--

> okay, that diddit
>
> maybe summayoo remember when I posted about MAD COWS DISEASE a long ass time ago. . .
>
> it was this disease urinating somewhere in europe from infected cow remains that were used to feed other cows. . .
> It quickly crossed the seas and was found in various places in the US. Not much was ever mentioned about it.
>
> Cows infected with this become horribly enraged, roaming city streets, sticking their tongues in their noses. . .killing every living creature in sight just to get
> to the poor victims lil brains. Once they uncover a human brain, these so called "Happy Cows" immediately call upon their cow "homies" and commence an
> act which can only be assumed to be some type of "tea party". They then eat the poor victims lil brain and do some kind of ritual called "The Freak" with other "Happy Cows" in celebration of their victory.
>
> When a simple minded McDonalds frequenter is exposed to this virus. . .a similar rage comes upon them. But for some odd and (to this date) unknown reason the humans infected exhibit a preponderance to eat strange objects, touch themselves in frightening ways. . .and the worst part. . .they make ugly faces and the faces get STUCK LIKE THAT !
>
> Research is pending, but one somewhat effective way to defeat these vile creatures (the human ones) is to "steal their nose". The humans then, bewildered at their lost nose, run around blindly until they literally run in circles trying to find it. . . twisting their heads off of their own necks. . .
>
> sounds crazy. . . it IS !
>
> really tho,
> it is everywhere. It can be transmitted from consuming products from infected cows. It's also been known to effect other animals.
>

Wednesday, December 31, 2003 ** Spundae's Birth of a New Year **

NEW YEARS EVE 2OO4 Birth of a New Year

wednesday, december 31st, 2OO3 SPUNDAE mainroom: 61,529 clubbers from 120
different countries worldwide voted TALL PAUL one of the TOP 2O most
popular DJ on the planet right now by: DJ MAGAZINE 2OO3 TALL PAUL
duty-free recordings / djtallpaul.com / uk One of the UK's best producer
and DJ in the trance scene. Paul has constantly been in the spotlight for
the past 10 years. Currently holding a residency at Turnmills' Friday
nighter The Gallery and plays regularly for Godskitchen, Gatecrasher,
Sundissential, Cream and Golden to name but a few. His popularity has seen
him DJ worldwide travelling to Canada, Japan,Australia, Argentina, Brazil,
Hong Kong, South Africa and all over Europe. Paul is also in the process
of taking the United States by storm, and has dedicated two weeks out of
each month's DJing schedule to concentrate his efforts in this particular
territory.  DAVE RALPH systemrecordings.com / rfactor-recordings.com /
daveralph.com / uk Dave was instrumental in bringing new sounds from
around the world to clubs across the UK (in fact, he was the first person
ever to bring Paul van Dyk to England to spin). He also wrote, reworked
and sang on the Bassheads^=D2 classic ^=D3Is Anybody Out There?^=D4 while
establishing his own GLOW Records. Dave spent two years as Paul
Oakenfold^=D2s support DJ of choice, which gave him the opportunity to
travel the globe honing his skills for international crowds. He later
became resident DJ for Cream in Ibiza, where he spent summers performing
for three consecutive years. THE SCUMFROG thescumfrog.com / positiva / new
york The Scumfrog's widely publicized and much talked about live
performances are not limited to mixing records. They include his live
vocals, percussion, samples, and occasional guest performances. His
colorful live sets and consistently innovative productions landed him on
the cover of DJ magazine in May 2003, and brought him frequent exposure on
Pete Tong's BBC1 radio shows.  GIANNI...spundae frontroom: GARTH 5 hour
set...wicked / grayhound records FRENCHY LE FREAK...frenchylefreak.com
NORMAN STRADLEY...second sunday blueroom: SPESH...looq / qool / bedrock /
rennaisance ALEX WHALEN...arrival soundsystem / r-factor records JONATHAN
OJEDA...spundae / spundae reckords SCOTT CARRELLI...qool / satellite
bassment: ST. JOHN...housenation TOM SLIK...skills DENISE aka DJ
D...djdenise.com RAFAEL...release / sonic upstairsroom hosted by: EUPORIA
DREAMS JOEY MAZZOLA...solmatic / moonshine DAVE ONEX :: DJ DIGGLER CYBER
JOE :: DJ STAN STEVIEBFUNK :: URANIUM THE METHOD :: INDUCE

Wednesday, December 31, 2003 ** ENDUP's NEW YEAR'S MARATHON 2004 **


         On Wednesday December 31, 2003 at 10 PM through Thursday January
1, 2004, at 5 PM, the Endup Nightclub will host another legendary New
Years Marathon. This event will consist of 19 hours of non-stop revelry to
bid farewell to 2003 and auspiciously welcome 2004!
         Once again, the Endup has assembled a wealth of Bay Area DJ
talent for its celebrated New Year^=D2s Marathon to ensure that 2004 starts
out perfectly. NYE begins with FREQUENCY 3, The BARONESS, JULIUS PAPP,
ADRIAN; TRACY; W. JEREMY. Then, The Endup continues this relentless
regimen of dance floor artistry until 5 PM on New Years Day - with the
exceptional ELLEN FERRATO at 12 noon, followed by a special 3 hour closing
set by the master of deep house - DAVID HARNESS.

        Along with this stellar DJ line-up, the Endup New Year^=D2s Maratho=
n
2004 will also feature catered food, party favors, a balloon drop, and
midnight toast. Add to the mix - good friends, great cocktails, superb
surroundings, and that special Endup vibe - and you will undoubtedly
experience a perfect start to 2004.

Saturday, January 17, 2004 ** Cold Phusion Winter Music Festival by BR
Productions, Next Level Promotions, and KCRH 89.9FM **

 he COLD PHUSION Winter Music Festival! Line-up TEASER!!! COLD PHUSION
will feature over 40+ Artists performing on 4 MASSIVE stages of sound! THE
WARP BROS: The legendary Warp Brothers - DJ's Oliver Goedicke and J=FCrgen
Dohr. It did not take a long time and their first single Phatt Bass hit
the German market and made it to the top 3 in the dance charts! Shortly
after this they entered the Sales-Charts Europe wide up to the #2! No
wonder that they draw the music business attention, with placing a solid
techno-track in the sales-charts.Shortly after their uplifting style
flooded Europe, the wave swept over to the US, Canada, Australia and
Japan. You might somehow compare the style of the Warp Brothers to Prodigy
or Chemical Brothers but the truth is that they created their own creative
and unique sound, like you can read in an article of the Face magazine.
Although the Warp Brothers are friendly people - they are in possession of
a lethal weapon, which is called Harder House. Remarkable is their success
in the UK sales-charts #9 and Top 10 positions in several Sales -Charts.In
Denmark they were rewarded with gold. Undoubted the Warpies as they are
keenly called by their fans turn it up on stage! DJ DRC: San Francisco's
Pioneer DJ DRC has relocated to New York City and is geared up to take the
Electronic Music Industry by storm. With her Mixed Album "UNDEFINED" in
the works and a list of releases on IMIX, Vision Music, Off World, Merge,
Twin Soul and her own label Undefined Musik, DRC equivocates the
expeditious pace of her new stomping grounds. Her original music is also
featured in two movies, "Vision of Vibe" with Carl Cox and "Intellect"
being released this February 2003, featuring Paul Van Dyk and many others.
DRC's latest single SEEKER can be heard on the SPANKEE clothing line
websight. With all this under her belt and more, it is obvious DRC has
already had her finger on the pulse of the Big Apple/ Manhattan. DRC
Returns to S.F. for a special set at COLD PHUSION! PLUS MORE CALIFORNIA
SUPERSTARS.... DJ JMARR (BR Productions/Liquid Vinyl DJs), FELIPE AVELAR
(BR Productions/ djfelipeavelar.com / bigfloor traxx), THE DOCTOR (BR
Productions/ Liquid Vinyl DJs) w/ MC FADER (Gravity Crew), DJ ORIONZ (BR
Productions / NextLevelPromotions.net), DOCTOR ROSS (BR Productions/KCRH
89.9FM/M.I.M.E. Recordings) *CD Release Party for Doctor Ross's new CD
"Open Heart Surgery" On M.I.M.E. Recordings!, VALERIE SPARKS (BR
Productions), CARLOS ALFONZO (BR Productions/ YuccaTribe / Deciblast),
JAMES DUB (BR Productions/ Space Monkey), DJ GIRLIE (BR Productions/
lovetribe.net / space monkey / ultrasounz), DJ DOZA (BR Productions/ The
Bounce / KCRH 89.9 FM), CRIS ROX (BR Productions/ M.I.M.E Recordings),
RECLIPSE (BR Productions/ Deciblast), DJ RYAN (Nextlevelpromotions.net)
*CD Release!, OSHY (BR Productions), & DOZENS MORE TO BE ANNOUNCED! PLUS:
Arena 4: Outdoor open air Rock/Alternative/Funk Stage! Outdoor Music Ends
@ 11pm SPECIAL EVENT FEATURES: - 4 Arenas Of Banging Sound! - 40+ DJs &
LIVE Acts! - Amazing Lighting! - Winter Themed Decorations! - Multiple
Stages! - Large Capacity VIRGIN Location! THIS IS A BENEFIT EVENT!! KCRH
89.9FM (College Radio) has launched the careers of many of todays hottest
radio DJs! - but California's budget crisis has hurt this renowned radio
station. Equipment repairs, new equipment, and much more is badly needed.
Profits from Cold Phusion go towards supporting this amazing radio
station, which has stood by the dance and rock scene from the beginning!
KCRH 89.9 is currently home to two of the Bay's most respected DJ Mix
Shows - BR Radio & The Bounce - which plays every Wed Night from
8pm-Midnight! ADDITIONAL INFO: 18+ With Valid ID. Zero Tolerance for
Weapons/Drugs/Alcohol. Tickets Go On Sale SOON - Stay Tuned for more info
TBA! We'll see you all @ COLD PHUSION!!!

Friday, January 23, 2004 ** SOMA Sessions w/Marcus Intalex **

SOMA Sessions Fourth Fridays @ AsiaSF

For the inaugural session we bring you, all the way from Manchester UK,
the sounds of:

MARCUS INTALEX (Soul:r, MIST - UK)  Marcus Intalex is known across the
globe for his infectious, smooth style of Drum 'n Bass. Only a few years
after his first production efforts in 1995 on Flex and his own Intalex
Productions imprint came anthems such as "How You Make Me Feel," "Love &
Happiness" and "Universe," which firmly positioned Marcus as one of the
world's top D&B personalities. Today, Marcus and longtime studio partner,
S.T. Files continue to blaze trails as M.I.S.T. with their wildly popular
Soul:r label. With over a decade of experience on the decks, SOMA Sessions
is proud to welcome back to San Francisco one of the UK's most in-demand
Drum 'n Bass DJs.

METHOD ONE (Cov.Ops, method-one.com)  By 1994 Method One was both an
acclaimed DJ and and experienced rave promoter in Philly. By 1996 he was
also an established producer. Recording with partner Kaos as Atlantiq,
Method One signed tunes to labels like Good Looking and True Intent while
holding down DJ residencies at Konkrete Jungle and Dieselboy's Platinum.
Since relocating to the Bay, Jason continues to wreck dancefloors with his
diverse DJ sets and release top-shelf tunes on labels such as ASC's Covert
Operations.

Resident Support:  DJ M SOUND:BOY

10:30pm - 3am For discount presale tickets, mailing list and more
information visit http://somasessions.com
http://www.hyperreal.org/raves/sf/calendar2/events/view?identifier=3D958 Sa=
n
Francisco California, USA

Friday, January 30, 2004 ** Tribal Flux by Raw Heaven **

January 30, 2004.  Tribal Flux by Raw Heaven

On January 30, 2004, Raw Heaven brings you our first indoor party, TRIBAL
FLUX. if you went to any of our free full moon gatherings over the past
year, you know what we're about.  This winter, we decided to take things
indoors. Our goal is to create the same feeling we all felt dancing under
the full moon and the stars. Also, we want to bring you a full season of
free outdoor next year on a more bangin sound system. There will be two
rooms of music, plus an ambient chill room.

PSY TRANCE: Mubali, Chromeatone, Random, Zul, Doctah Spook, Witchdoctah,
Nikon HOUSE/BREAKS: ill-D, Christian Intrigue, Hijinx, Mahesh,
Demosthenese

Part goes from 9p-5a. Chai tea will also be available.

Francisco.  At the door, tickets will be $15, or $10 with a can of food or
other non-perishable item.

Saturday, January 31, 2004 ** Winter! **

Surreal Entertainment and SFBang! productions proudly present!

Winter!  January 31st 2004!!!  A mini massive to start the year off with a
BANG!! and what better way than the joining of 2 crews to mix their magic
and make your wildest dreams come true. Surreal Entertainment (Known for
their yearly Earthdance,Liquid lotus festival,Refliections and their Club
Further) branching out all the way from Arizona to join forces with SF's
newest and quickly growing production company SFBang!, they brought you
GhettoTechnoSuperCaliExtraBootyLicious and if you attended that you know
the vibe and you know the rukus and a rocking time to look forward to!

WINTER is going to be SF's First EVER snow party!  dance the night away in
the falling snowflakes with 2 brand new artificial snow machines! You all
are encouraged to wear stylish winter themed costumes. The Surreal girls
will be there in full effect dressed as sexy snow bunnies and snow
angels!!! Feel free to join them on the fun!

This party will have somthing for everyone including House, Trance,
Breaks, Drum and Bass, and some good old fashioned HARDCORE!

THE SFRaves.org Calendar is sent via email every week.

To subscribe to the list, send a message to:
sfraves-calendar-subscribe@hyperreal.org

To remove your address from the list, send a message to:
sfraves-calendar-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org

Send mail to the following for info and FAQ for this list:
sfraves-calendar-info@hyperreal.org or sfraves-calendar-faq@hyperreal.org

Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 62176 invoked by uid 1103); 28 Dec 2003 02:09:10 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>
list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 62162 invoked from network); 28 Dec 2003 02:09:09 -0000
X-Authentication-Warning: gere.odin.pdx.edu: srg owned process doing -bs
Date: Sat, 27 Dec 2003 18:09:03 -0800 (PST)
From: Sean G <srg@pdx.edu>
X-X-Sender: srg@gere.odin.pdx.edu
To: "michael, the red stickman" <red_stickman@yahoo.com>
cc: Daniel Kox <dank@countercultured.net>, <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
In-Reply-To: <20031228013508.14934.qmail@web12101.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0312271751210.22631-100000@gere.odin.pdx.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=X-UNKNOWN
Content-Transfer-Encoding: QUOTED-PRINTABLE
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Uhh.. Richard Humpty Vision as a headliner?


Damn that 'geigh house' music.

So when's anabolic frolic coming to SF?!?

:P :P :P~ phhbt!

At least SF is just mired in bad prog house and trance. :) It could be
worse. I can see Dannyboy explosively shitting his pants and taking half
the bay with him if it was AF instead of humptydumpty headlining. ;)

Speaking of which, however... I've been listening to a lot of old hardcore
and breaks recently... This' got me thinkin'. I'm too young and too much
of a n00b to have been around for the 'golden age' of 92-95... but does it
occur to anyone that the reason for the lack of energy/vis/whathaveyou in
parties recently is just because the music has changed so drastically? You
listen to some of the older electronic music, and there's just so much
*energy* there (no matter how cheesy the choons..) that you just don't get
in a lot of modern music. Maybe our tastes got too refined for our own
good? Don't get me wrong -- the music out there now is refined,
high-quality, max-produced *quality* music... but maybe in our rush to be
refined artiste`s we've really lost some of the basic energy of raves?

A lot of the music out there right now (aside from jungle, where the vibe
is just... directionless and angry, and techno, which ... well, is techno)
seems to be either amped drug music (coming in fluffy etard trance, speedy
gonzales hardcore, etc) or 'get your groove on' sleazegrind-moozic, best
suited to sipping cocktails and trying to get into them panties at your
local clubaroonie. What happened to all that ENERGY that was in the music
even 6, 7 years ago? Is it the DJs, is it the producers, is it just that
this is the kind of music the crowds want?

Is it that the low-fi nature of electronic music, before we started
superproducing everything down to a razor edge, was more condusive to
getting people on their feet? Maybe there was more for people to connect
with? Imperfection makes the art, and all that?

Maybe I'm just gettin' jaded. But as time passes, the music I hear at
parties seems less and less danceable. The crazy little undergrounds seem
to be waning, replaced with the mass-produced shrinkwrapped rave
experience. Maybe I'm outta the loop. Maybe I'm not doing enough drugs.
But what the fuck is going on?

Don't get me wrong. I've been to a few great parties recently. But, you
know.. a *few*. The music seems a little less lively, the crowds are a
little more bitchy, nerves seem a little more raw. Maybe I'm just seeing a
reflection of the country as a whole?

But where them smilin' faces? Where that thumptythump oontz oontz
dancypantsy whooplah?

this is your rambling nonsense for the day.

--Geri Dahl

---
Griffin
Department of Disinformation

http://www.DefSF.com - 97.4% techno

----- Original Message -----=20
From: "Sean G" <srg@pdx.edu>
I'm too young and too much
of a n00b to have been around for the 'golden age' of 92-95... but does =
it
occur to anyone that the reason for the lack of energy/vis/whathaveyou =
in
parties recently is just because the music has changed so drastically?
..

nope... it's that half the tech jobs in the bay were suddently gone, and =
the other half took pay cuts.  all tech centers around the world =
experienced the same... then it took a few years to really hit the rest =
of the world through trickle-down.  now we're on the rock bottom.  it's =
all uphill from here.

once people are back to working 60hrs a week, making bank, and needing =
to seriously release during those few remaining hours of the week, =
wellfare not being an issue... you'll see more parties, more music, more =
smiling faces.

it will never be quite the same as those years. we can only improve from =
here... but it will take some evolution.

-=3Ddave

Subject: [sfraves] .: Dirtbox Radio New Years Special | Henry Varno, Phil Scott, Plejik
 :.


Happy holidays ravin crew!  Dirtbox Radio's rollin out tonight with some
phat tunes to celebrate the beginning of another year of phat junglist
hoodlumousness.  Tune in to jam out with your hosts ODJ & Jerel, and the
following special guests:

Phil Scott & Plejik - You know these guys, and you know they rock out
hard.  I talked to them this weekend, and they've got a slew of new shit
to throw at yer ears, so don't sleep!

Henry Varno - Back in town for a bit, Henry's coming by to tantalize your
ears with turntablism mastery and some new shit of his own, hot offa the
digital press.

We might have some more cats up in the studio to mash up, so keep your
ears sharp, and stay locked the fuck in.

To tune in, simply point your web browser to
http://dirtboxradio.com/listen.html.  We run red from 7pm EST 'til
whenever the fuck we end up, live simulcast-style on Jungletrain.net and
Destroyer.net.

Here's a sneak peak at our upcoming guests:
01/04 - Agent Sunshine, Rogers and Freefall
01/11 - DJ Twist, Moody Moore
01/18 - Bizar, Haaps
01/25 - Psykofly, Cam One
02/01 - Akasha, Shade
02/08 - 2Charming (TBC)
02/15 - RsonisT, Ransom

If you'd like to get on the show, get your mix aired, or pass us some
tunes to try out, just hit up myself (odj@dirtboxradio.com) or jerel
(jerel@baked.net), and we'll sort ya out with all the necessary info.

Aiiight well we'll see y'all tonight.  Hope you had a happy holidays, and
may you have a bomb ass 2004.

Keep it rollin,
Jackson (ODJ)
Partners in Crime | Dirtbox Radio | Trividual Productions | ALIAS //
Maryland

Date: Sun, 28 Dec 2003 14:10:16 -0800
To: "aK" <aK@hard-grooves.com>
X-Mailer: Apple Mail (2.609)
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] nrr, whats the name for: that classified list board. . . uuuhh

i've always gotten good results by going, in person, to property 
management & real estate offices and asking for their new rental 
listings.

if you get there right when they open, you'll be the first to see 
anything that's available. most places will let you take the key and 
check out the house if you leave a $20 deposit with them.

i know this isn't as easy as an online listing, but it's way more 
effective, and free.

but if you insist on an online listing, i'd recommend metrorent, rent 
tech, or something similar. there are a few in the bay area. for about 
$70 (for 3 months) you get emailed updates of new rentals, and you can 
log in and look up photos and other info. and, after you find your 
place, you can always give your subscription to someone else to use.

hope this helps.

-philip-

Subject: [sfraves] Artist Unit 21 of Cobalt Recordings are going to be artists to watch out for

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Thats right Unit 21 of Cobalt Recordings is going to be an artist to keep 
watch on in the future.  They have two hot tracks on Cobalt Recordings CD 
compilation entitled : The New Power.  People are giving excellent feedback on Unit 
21's work : " I am really digging their style. I would like to see a entire CD 
by the group in the future!"   Xavier.  To learn more about Unit 21. Log onto 
www.unit21.org and listen to some of their other tracks. There you will also 
find other links to other rising Cobalt Recording Stars.  You can also log onto 
our website at www.cobaltrecordings.tk  for upcomping release information!
Keep dancing to the global beats of the underground.  
One Love, 

Tony Da Tiger 


Tony Russo
Cobalt Recordings
Co-owner
Bookings,Events, Promotions
e-mail : monk7923@aol.com
(C) 704-619-0984 

www.cobaltrecordings.tk 

--dc.4e42bf_alt_bound

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Uhh.. Richard Humpty Vision as a headliner?

Well for starters in 92 the Scene had just gotten to SF a year earlier.. I 
recall parties in 91 being the small UG parties and the first Gatherings and 
FTT parties etc.. by 92 the "Scene" was in full swing it was NEW FRESH and 
if you recall in 91-92 you could do all night dance parties in the city of 
SF perfectly Legally!! which you can not do now or probably will able to do 
again.. At least not at no shady warehouse on any giving street in SF. Some 
of you remember the charter oak days, 16@harrison, Jose's Latin Palace, 
8@townsend etc... And I have some old tapes from back then. Bang the drum, 
Ghetto Gangsta, No rest for the wicked old Carlos and Bones tapes etc.. and 
I wouldn't say the music was better then just different. Some of it is kind 
of weak in terms of production when you compare it to similiar toones of 
today. I mean look at the rave classics.. Liberty citys "Get some luvin" 
Granted it is a good toon but very minimal and weak by comparison. Yet at 
the time it was a big toon. Or DJ Dukes "Wheres my whistle" Which I still 
own a copy of. Every major DJ from the wicked boys to the hardkiss boys were 
banging that toon at that time and if you listen to it today it doesn't have 
that same energy, it was the crowd that had the energy that accompanied the 
track. In addition alot of those old producers that made famous Rave anthems 
back then are still producing tracks till this day they have just evolved 
there sound.

For instance I just found out the other day that Jon Debo was responsible 
for the "Mind warp" tracks on stress.. And if any of you were a DJ or 
followed the wicked boys back in the early 90's they use to play alot of the 
stress tracks including mindward 1 and II same with alot of the old Junior 
boys own and stress guys.

Not exactly sure where I was going with my rant but you get the picture ;)

Alot of factors have changed and made the scene what it is today but one 
thing we can all still agree on is that the simple fact is it is still 
GOING!! more then 12 years or longer if you follow it back to the disco 
history of this subculture being around. That is a pretty good feet 
considering most sub cultures have died out and are now coming back 
Punkers,breakers etc.. So for it to sustain for so long is pretty impressive 
consedering all the obsticles it has had to face.


Mac

From: John B. <SvnLyrBrto@yahoo.com>
Date: Sun, 28 Dec 2003 17:33:38 -0800
To: Sean Griffith <srg@pdx.edu>
X-Mailer: Apple Mail (2.609)
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Uhh.. Richard Humpty Vision as a headliner?

"Sean G" wrote:

 > You listen to some of the older electronic music, and there's just so 
much
 > *energy* there (no matter how cheesy the choons..) that you just 
don't get
 > in a lot of modern music.
...
 > What happened to all that ENERGY that was in the music
 > even 6, 7 years ago?
...
 > But where them smilin' faces? Where that thumptythump oontz oontz
 > dancypantsy whooplah?

Amen to all that!!!

I wasn't around for the REALLY old school either.  But even in the few 
years *I* have been around, I've noticed a distinct souring of the vibe 
at parties, a loss of energy, and a loss of the blissful happiness that 
first got me hooked into SF's rave scene.  Even happy hardcore, when 
you hear it at a party, doesn't sound "happy" anymore.  And it's not 
JUST a jadedness or depression in myself... the music is more 
aggressive and less cheerful.  Sure, it was corny as hell to hear 
Shooting Star and Eye Opener at every party, and usually more than once 
at said parties... but it was FUN, dammit.

And thanks to Ishkur's guide to electronic music:

http://www.ishkur.com/features/music/index.htm

I've been looking into even older genres lately... the very same ones 
you're talking about, I think... stuff that dates all the way back to 
when I got myself dragged to my first few raves in Florida, hated them, 
and vowed that I'd never go to another...

So, along with Jpop, this "Old School" stuff has been at the top of my 
downloading lists, of late.  And I'm loving it all, uber-cheezy and 
all.  I'm talking about the sort of stuff you see in those old "This is 
Old School" and "This is Rave" boxed sets... stuff like *OLD* Moby, 
before whatever happened that set him on his depressive music thing; 
stuff like "Next is the E", "Voodoo Child", "Go", and so on... stuff 
like OLD Prodigy... stuff like Altern 8's "Activ 8"; which is just so 
corny as to be horrible; it's like the stuff that they play in the 
Arena when a basketball team runs out to the court.

None of it is "refined".  It's not the sort of stuff that the hipster 
martini-sipping crowd would ever denign to listen to.  Like the Jpop, 
which I am also coming to just love, it is horribly corny and cheezy.  
It's not "mature" music by a long shot.  The very vinyl it's pressed on 
would probably shatter if you tried to take it past the threshold of 
SOMAarts or the Tenderloft.

But, also like Jpop, it is FUN!!!  It's cheerful and optimistic.  It's 
bright.  It's happy.  It's high in energy, gets my heart racing, and if 
I ever found a party where they'd play it, it would damn well get me 
MOVING, in a way no party has in a long time.  And I think that kind of 
joy, cheer, and unbounded optimism is what's been missing in the scene 
for quite some time.


cya,
john

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Mailer: Apple Mail (2.553)
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Why energy seems missing (was Re: Richard Humpty Vision...)

	I think there's some truth to what both Dave and Sean say. A thriving 
countercultural needs an abundance of leisure time, which means that 
the economy must be strong enough that most people aren't spending most 
of their time simply working to pay rent and put food on the table. One 
of the factors behind the countercultural explosion that took place in 
the late 1960s in SF was very cheap rents in the Haight-Ashbury (this 
was before the era of rent control and other government regulations 
that drove up the cost of housing in SF).

	Nevertheless, Sean's original post about a correlation between the 
music and the energy level of raves was insightful. But I would say 
that the music becoming more produced and polished, and with less happy 
energy, is a *result* of the scene changing, not the cause. You could 
have a party with all early techno/trance, and you wouldn't necessarily 
get the same vibe you had with that music in 1993. We can still have 
raves with that overflowing positive energy, but I don't think the 
answer will be found in the music.

Groove on,
						<<< Starchild >>>


On Saturday, December 27, 2003, at 07:33  PM, SE/30 wrote:
>
> ... it's that half the tech jobs in the bay were suddently gone, and 
> the other half took pay cuts.  all tech centers around the world 
> experienced the same... then it took a few years to really hit the 
> rest of the world through trickle-down.  now we're on the rock bottom. 
>  it's all uphill from here.
>
> once people are back to working 60hrs a week, making bank, and needing 
> to seriously release during those few remaining hours of the week, 
> wellfare not being an issue... you'll see more parties, more music, 
> more smiling faces.
>
> it will never be quite the same as those years. we can only improve 
> from here... but it will take some evolution.
>
> -=dave

From: Sean G <srg@pdx.edu>
Date: Sat Dec 27, 2003  6:09:03  PM US/Pacific
To: "michael, the red stickman" <red_stickman@yahoo.com>
Cc: Daniel Kox <dank@countercultured.net>, <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Uhh.. Richard Humpty Vision as a headliner?


Damn that 'geigh house' music.

So when's anabolic frolic coming to SF?!?

:P :P :P~ phhbt!

At least SF is just mired in bad prog house and trance. :) It could be
worse. I can see Dannyboy explosively shitting his pants and taking half
the bay with him if it was AF instead of humptydumpty headlining. ;)

Speaking of which, however... I've been listening to a lot of old 
hardcore
and breaks recently... This' got me thinkin'. I'm too young and too much
of a n00b to have been around for the 'golden age' of 92-95... but does 
it
occur to anyone that the reason for the lack of energy/vis/whathaveyou 
in
parties recently is just because the music has changed so drastically? 
You
listen to some of the older electronic music, and there's just so much
*energy* there (no matter how cheesy the choons..) that you just don't 
get
in a lot of modern music. Maybe our tastes got too refined for our own
good? Don't get me wrong -- the music out there now is refined,
high-quality, max-produced *quality* music... but maybe in our rush to 
be
refined artiste`s we've really lost some of the basic energy of raves?

A lot of the music out there right now (aside from jungle, where the 
vibe
is just... directionless and angry, and techno, which ... well, is 
techno)
seems to be either amped drug music (coming in fluffy etard trance, 
speedy
gonzales hardcore, etc) or 'get your groove on' sleazegrind-moozic, best
suited to sipping cocktails and trying to get into them panties at your
local clubaroonie. What happened to all that ENERGY that was in the 
music
even 6, 7 years ago? Is it the DJs, is it the producers, is it just that
this is the kind of music the crowds want?

Is it that the low-fi nature of electronic music, before we started
superproducing everything down to a razor edge, was more condusive to
getting people on their feet? Maybe there was more for people to connect
with? Imperfection makes the art, and all that?

Maybe I'm just gettin' jaded. But as time passes, the music I hear at
parties seems less and less danceable. The crazy little undergrounds 
seem
to be waning, replaced with the mass-produced shrinkwrapped rave
experience. Maybe I'm outta the loop. Maybe I'm not doing enough drugs.
But what the fuck is going on?

Don't get me wrong. I've been to a few great parties recently. But, you
know.. a *few*. The music seems a little less lively, the crowds are a
little more bitchy, nerves seem a little more raw. Maybe I'm just 
seeing a
reflection of the country as a whole?

But where them smilin' faces? Where that thumptythump oontz oontz
dancypantsy whooplah?

this is your rambling nonsense for the day.


---------------------------------------------------------------------

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Uhh.. Richard Humpty Vision as a headliner?

Usually when people say it was better back in the day, they're referring to
whenever they started partying.  They do it for a couple years, things
shift, everything's not as new anymore, and they long for one of those first
few magic party experiences.  How often do you hear anyone say, "it's even
better now than back in the day" about anything?  Nostalgia, remember the
best, filter out the rest.

-Andrew

> > years *I* have been around, I've noticed a distinct souring of the vibe

> > you hear it at a party, doesn't sound "happy" anymore.  And it's not

> > Shooting Star and Eye Opener at every party, and usually more than once

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Uhh.. Richard Humpty Vision as a headliner?

It depends if one can provide objective truth about it being better or not
being better.  Sure, nostalgia plays a part in everything, but the delta
between
"it was amazing" and "it sucks" is large, and there seems to be a large
number
of people in this camp over the past 4 years vs. "it was better" and "it's
not
as good".  The later being nostalgia.  Do you really think there's only
nostalgia
as a factor?  I don't.

i dunno - i'm having more fun now than i did "back in the day".

but my personal involvement in partying has changed as well.  i
started out "just partying", then helping flyer for parties,
helping set up parties, helping/throwing my own, and now
DJing/throwing my own.

doing the same old thing year after year gets boring.  do
something new - contribute in some way.

m

What this says to me is that too many whites are getting away with drug
use, too many whites are getting away with drug sales, too many whites
are getting away with trafficking in this stuff. The answer to this
disparity is not to start letting people out of jail because we're not
putting others in jail who are breaking the law. The answer is to go out
and find the ones who are getting away with it, convict them and send
them up the river, too."

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: make a *WISH for the New Year

Get your tickets to Wish now!

We've had a lot of positive feedback concerning this event and we have 
limited space available. Your presale ticket saves you money and assures 
your entrance to this event.

Get your tickets here:

Online at http://www.infinitebeat.net

In these stores:
Ceiba Records - 463 Haight @ Fillmore in San Francisco
Primal Records - 2420 Parker @ Telegraph in Berkeley

Tickets are $25 pre-sale and $30 at the door.

We're pulling out all the stops this New Years Eve! We've gone over the top 
to bring out some of the sickest music and visuals you're going to see and 
hear this year. A 2.5 watt full color laser, the old-skool master Donovan on 
visuals, and lighting by Shock Therapy, Radiant Atmospheres and the Infinite 
Beat will provide an insane amount of visual eye-candy and complement decor 
by Marin, Carrie, Julia, and friends. We'll also be featuring some of the 
cleanest and clearest sound in the Bay Area, including a special 4-corner 
Know:Audio sound system (with Bassmaxx technology), the original Gateway 
Sound System, and Soundwave Systems. Musically, the lineup speaks for 
itself:

DDR            (Stay Up Forever/Hazchem) LIVE PA   acid
Sarah FAB      (Stay Up Forever/Vinyl Vixens)      techno
Galen          (Pacific)                           house
Donna Matrix   (Infinite Beat)                     breaks
J-Bird         (Pacific)                           house
Ethan          (Friends and Family)                house/breaks
Solar          (Pacific)                           electro
Kabal          (Infinite Beat)                     tech-trance
Smoove         (Space Cowboys)                     breaks
ViaJay         (Delve)                             breaks
Micron         (Infinite Beat/Lick the Micron)     techno
Aneurysm       (Switchcraft/Slowleak)
vs                                   LIVE PA      evil breaks
The Thing      (S.P.A.Z./IOT)

Danny          (Moontribe)                         downtempo
Oze            (Infinite Beat/Circuit Breaker)     hip-hop/downtempo
vs
Joe Rice       (FnF/Circuit Breaker)               downtempo
Blueshaman     (Infinite Beat)                     downtempo
396            (T.B.I. 25, NYC)                    hip-hop

Leave your belongings at the coat check when you arrive, enjoy a refreshing 
smoothie at the juice bar, stay late for our champagne breakfast, and check 
out the wide variety of art being exhibited. And don't miss the special 
trapeze performances.

This event is a fundraiser for the Infinite Beat's Burning Man multimedia 
art installation and all proceeds go to making the playa a brighter place in 
2004.

For updated info, visit our web site:
http://www.infinitebeat.net

Or check our voicemail at 415.705.0600

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Uhh.. Richard Humpty Vision as a headliner?

--=====================_8463079==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

At 04:53 PM 12/29/2003, Sean wrote:
>From: Sean G <srg@pdx.edu>
>
>
>A lot of the music out there right now (aside from jungle, where the vibe
>is just... directionless and angry, and techno, which ... well, is techno)
>seems to be either amped drug music (coming in fluffy etard trance, speedy
>gonzales hardcore, etc) or 'get your groove on' sleazegrind-moozic, best
>suited to sipping cocktails and trying to get into them panties at your
>local clubaroonie. What happened to all that ENERGY that was in the music
>even 6, 7 years ago? Is it the DJs, is it the producers, is it just that
>this is the kind of music the crowds want?

I do think much of the emphasis lately in music production and delivery has 
been on refinement of technique rather than innovation.   Much of this 
music lacks...well...soul:)  Lineups for parties are based on some rather 
rigid genre paradigms and many DJs seem to be heavily invested in 
maintaining these status quo boundaries in their sets.

We have all been attempting to meet what we think are the expectations of 
our dancers, but just meeting expectations ultimately leads to boredom and 
mediocrity.

Experimentation and innovation is, however, risky for both the party-giver, 
DJ and producer.  There is comfort in the tried and true.  Things are 
changing, however, and I feel this yearning for less "mechanistic" dance 
music in many dancers.  I am always surprised, for example, at the 
enthusiastic reception Jesse Saunders receives when he spins here.  Jesse 
does love house passionately, and when he throws down some of those soulful 
old tunes the crowd goes wild.  I personally miss vocals and meaningful 
lyrics and use of instruments like the sax in house music.  These days I 
have been looking back on the last twenty years of EDM for inspiration and 
so, apparently have others.  Something wonderful will arise from all this, 
and that's the way it has always been.  Coincidentally, I am having an 
ongoing email conversation with Greg Wilson of UK electrofunk fame on this 
very subject.  There are revivals of all kinds of older musical 
styles;  the stuff is remixed;  new genres evolve.  About time.

>Don't get me wrong. I've been to a few great parties recently. But, you
>know.. a *few*. The music seems a little less lively, the crowds are a
>little more bitchy, nerves seem a little more raw. Maybe I'm just seeing a
>reflection of the country as a whole?
>
>But where them smilin' faces? Where that thumptythump oontz oontz
>dancypantsy whooplah?

The conditions that exist now are pretty much the same as those that 
defined the early days of raving:  war with Iraq;  poor economy; and lots 
of darkness connected with mortality (AIDS, etc.) and uncertainty about the 
future.  On a personal level, life seemed far more risky then than 
now.  Musically, though, there was anarchy -- not the genre structure we 
have now.  DJs played eclectic sets and would bounce from house to 
industrial to punk and back.  Some of it would be considered sloppy today, 
but there was energy.  And by god the new music started flowing and the 
party scene exploded.  It wasn't money that drove it all, but a desire 
amongst many of the participants to make new connections on the dance floor 
and experience personal transformation.  Consider this little piece from 
the Raver Manifesto:


"We were first drawn by the sound. From far away, the thunderous, muffled, 
echoing beat was comparable to a mother's heart soothing a child in her 
womb of concrete, steel, and electrical wiring. We were drawn back into 
this womb, and there, in the heat, dampness, and darkness of it, we came to 
accept that we are all equal. Not only to the darkness, and to ourselves, 
but to the very music slamming into us and passing through our souls: we 
are all equal. And somewhere around 35Hz we could feel the hand of God at 
our backs, pushing us forward, pushing us to push ourselves to strengthen 
our minds, our bodies, and our spirits. Pushing us to turn to the person 
beside us to join hands and uplift them by sharing the uncontrollable joy 
we felt from creating this magical bubble that can, for one evening, 
protect us from the horrors, atrocities, and pollution of the outside 
world. It is in that very instant, with these initial realizations that 
each of us was truly born."

Many came to parties with this intentionality in mind and soul.  I still 
do:)  Nothing really new here.  This statement could have described the 
shared feelings of the dancers at the Paradise Garage in 70's NYC.  As 
raving moved into the mainstream in the late nineties I think much of this 
community of shared belief was replaced by "...it's just entertainment;  a 
way to blow off steam from a 24/6 work week."

But this shared dancers' belief in the transformative power or music and 
dance -- the quality that makes for those smilin' faces and wooplah -- is 
still out there.  I find it in the most unlikely places these days.  Yes, 
there is dissatisfaction with things as they are but one hell of a lot of 
people are looking for that old, ancient, vibe.  And they will find it, 
because it is they who will create our future.  No one can deliver the 
spirit to you.  You bring it to the mix.  These disaffected dancers will 
find their soul mates and something new and wonderful will begin.  Ah...it 
already has:)

Love,

Apollo



>Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net
>
>House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm
>
>"Security is mostly a superstition.  It does not exist in nature, nor do 
>the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no 
>safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring 
>adventure or nothing."
>-Helen Keller
>
>"Beware of being too rational.  In the country of the insane, the 
>integrated man doesn't become king.  He gets lynched."
>-Aldous Huxley, Island
>
>"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
>rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
>visible."
>-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"


Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Security is mostly a superstition.  It does not exist in nature, nor do 
the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no 
safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring 
adventure or nothing."
-Helen Keller

"Beware of being too rational.  In the country of the insane, the 
integrated man doesn't become king.  He gets lynched."
-Aldous Huxley, Island

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Subject: RE: [sfraves] Spirit of Raving: Your First Party

I'm a relative noob, so...

My first "rave" was Cyberfest in summer 2000 on Fresno.  Every DJ and
their mom played at that, but some of the headliners were Oakenfold, BT,
and Aphrodite.

My first real party was in January 2001 in a little "community center" up
in Woodland.  I don't remember the event's name or who threw it, and the
turnout was pretty minimal, but Deepsky headlined and they rocked.

C.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Spirit of Raving: Your First Party - found info

:)  i tracked down some info about my first party, found it on the Silver Pearl website.
Quest, Nov 14, 1998, at the JJ Newberry store on Broadway in Oakland. 
Upstairs: Eric Spire, Jeno, Garth, Tracy, Tony
Downstairs: Mystre, JBot, Greg Sandler, and a 3-hr set by Doran (I was wrong about there being a jungle room, but all the music was new to me and I didn't know the styles)
Mark Johns did animations and projections on 3 screens. UV99 did lasers. Total of about 2000 people. There were edible altars, and this beautiful entry made of tree branches and flowers. 
No wonder I was en-tranced!  (totally sober, too). I'd love to hear from anybody who was at that party. Quest parties were something special; I believe I went to two more of them which were held at Home Base. 

At a Trance & Jungle party (Thomas Trouble) not too long after at the JJ Newberry store, I heard the main floor collapsed, sending dust and concrete onto the heads of the dancers below. I didn't hear about anybody getting hurt but i'm sure it messed up a few highs. Anybody go to that one?  ow. 

looking forward to hearing about other peoples' first rave.  :)
John

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

At 12:13 PM 12/30/2003, Karina wrote:
>What was your first party in the SF Bay Area?
>
>If you can recall the following details: BONUS
>
>Date, Location, Event Name, DJ Lineup, Promotions Crew
>
>Spanks!
>Karina

Spanks!  Then I guess my first party in SF was at an S&M club on Folsom in 
the seventies:)

Before I moved to SF permanently in the late eighties from NYC I made 
several extended visits to the City in the seventies.  In 1979 I came out 
here for three months in the summer to soak up the sex and sensuality and 
spin some New York disco at the Troc.  The first dance party I attended I 
kinda' stumbled into one night while touring the Castro.

Back then the Castro was nothing like the dead commercial strip it is 
today.  In the seventies there were many dance clubs, sex venues and a 24/7 
party atmosphere in the Castro/Market area.  As I was doing a little 
discovery tour one Saturday night soon after my arrival I wandered into a 
dance club called Alfie's on Market.  The place was on fire.  Everyone was 
dancing, including the bartenders and staff.  Great vibe.  The music was, 
of course, disco and I have no idea who the DJs were.  But I still remember 
that evening fondly.

My first "rave" here was a Wicked FMR in '91 on Baker Beach.  THAT was a 
truly transformative experience:)

Love,

Apollo



Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Security is mostly a superstition.  It does not exist in nature, nor do 
the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no 
safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring 
adventure or nothing."
-Helen Keller

"Beware of being too rational.  In the country of the insane, the 
integrated man doesn't become king.  He gets lynched."
-Aldous Huxley, Island

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"  
--=====================_14194450==.ALT--

hmm lets see date  Oct-??-1991
Event name: hmmm don't recall it was so long ago.. Location One step beyond

DJ lineup I think I still have the flyer but lets see it was Buck,Lily 
Tron,Bones,Markie Mark,Ghost

gear.. Back when rave apparel was becoming the rage.. The party was semi 
weak by todays standards but it was a going on crowd with a hot sweaty quasi 
two room setup but with a nice big thick green laser that was super cool and 
the sound was super loud  :) Stayed for a few hours then had to go home 
cause I could not take the music all night.. hahahh funny how things turn 
out  ;)

roger that!!

My first was a Quests party at homebase ...........

The thing i remember best was parking accross the street,watching hordes of
peeps dressed in the crazy of craziest cross in all directions.When i
crossed they had one of the big ass roll up doors like halfway open and you
could see the mass of peeps dancing and the lasers & music busting out all
over the place.Then we walked around the back where i stayed in line for
almost 2 hours.That was the craziest of all LINE EXPERIENCES......LOL.I
could write a book just about the shit you hear in line.Anyways,after
getting in there were the fruit alters and a ton of decorations.The kewlist
pawty ive been to of this kind fo sho.The one thing that sticks out also was
the music.It seems to me that that time or era of the rave scenes music was
intense.I still have many mix tapes i have from a couple years ago that have
alot of those most common trax or hits that were popular and still blow me
away.Is it just me or has the music changed that much?I luv to hear new
stuff but it just dont thrill me like it did.Long live EDM & Silver
Pearl!...................

P.S. I had just turned 33,moved from LA,a dancerphobic and was a HUGE 80's
metal head.Go figure...............

Subject: [sfraves] last minute WISH info...12/31/03

For those of you attending, or considering attending our NYE event...
here is some last minute info that may alleviate confusion:

*Paypal orders will be held at will call at the event. Paypal tickets
will be available until Wednesday afternoon.

*Presale tickets will still be available at Ceiba records in SF, and
Primal records in Berkeley... until the shops close for the evening!

*After that... tickets will be available at the door for $30... not $35
as previously stated.

*Directions to the event will be available on our website at
www.infinitebeat.net or on our voicemail: 415-705-0600 tomorrow
afternoon.

Hope to see you all there!!

I found out I had better search results when I used google and searched for
"property management" rather than "rentals", or "homes for rent".

There was a place a few houses down from my budd. . .he pays like 900/mo,
and the management peeps wanted 1500 for the same style house. . .

I could easily get an apartment I'm sure, but I have like 2 cars, a car
trailer, and a mc trailer. . . I guess if I need to I can stick with storage
n all, but it would limit my mechanical hobbies / business activities and
such if I didn't have a ton of space to work with.

I almost had a live-in wherehouse which was huge for like 650/mo (which
would have been totally perfect), but I was too slow. I'll keep looking in
that area and maybe I'll get lucky talking to someone else who hates
management companies or something like that.

thanks for the help mann

From: "Philip.X.Diaz" <st_indigo@earthlink.net>

Sent: Sunday, December 28, 2003 2:10 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] nrr, whats the name for: that classified list board.
. . uuuhh


> i've always gotten good results by going, in person, to property
> management & real estate offices and asking for their new rental
> listings.
>
> if you get there right when they open, you'll be the first to see
> anything that's available. most places will let you take the key and
> check out the house if you leave a $20 deposit with them.
>
> i know this isn't as easy as an online listing, but it's way more
> effective, and free.
>
> but if you insist on an online listing, i'd recommend metrorent, rent
> tech, or something similar. there are a few in the bay area. for about
> $70 (for 3 months) you get emailed updates of new rentals, and you can
> log in and look up photos and other info. and, after you find your
> place, you can always give your subscription to someone else to use.
>
> hope this helps.
>
> -philip-
>

Subject: [sfraves] BSP:WISH 2004!!!

Get your tickets to Wish now!

We've had a lot of positive feedback concerning this event and we have 
limited space available. Your presale ticket saves you money and assures 
your entrance to this event.

Get your tickets here:

Online at http://www.infinitebeat.net

In these stores:
Ceiba Records - 463 Haight @ Fillmore in San Francisco
Primal Records - 2420 Parker @ Telegraph in Berkeley

Tickets are $25 pre-sale and $30 at the door.

We're pulling out all the stops this New Years Eve! We've gone over the top 
to bring out some of the sickest music and visuals you're going to see and 
hear this year. A 2.5 watt full color laser, the old-skool master Donovan on 
visuals, and lighting by Shock Therapy, Radiant Atmospheres and the Infinite 
Beat will provide an insane amount of visual eye-candy and complement decor 
by Marin, Carrie, Julia, and friends. We'll also be featuring some of the 
cleanest and clearest sound in the Bay Area, including a special 4-corner 
Know:Audio sound system (with Bassmaxx technology), the original Gateway 
Sound System, and Soundwave Systems. Musically, the lineup speaks for 
itself:

DDR            (Stay Up Forever/Hazchem) LIVE PA   acid
Sarah FAB      (Stay Up Forever/Vinyl Vixens)      techno
Galen          (Pacific)                           house
Donna Matrix   (Infinite Beat)                     breaks
J-Bird         (Pacific)                           house
Ethan          (Friends and Family)                house/breaks
Solar          (Pacific)                           electro
Kabal          (Infinite Beat)                     tech-trance
Smoove         (Space Cowboys)                     breaks
ViaJay         (Delve)                             breaks
Micron         (Infinite Beat/Lick the Micron)     techno
Aneurysm       (Switchcraft/Slowleak)
vs                                   LIVE PA      evil breaks
The Thing      (S.P.A.Z./IOT)

Danny          (Moontribe)                         downtempo
Oze            (Infinite Beat/Circuit Breaker)     hip-hop/downtempo
vs
Joe Rice       (FnF/Circuit Breaker)               downtempo
Blueshaman     (Infinite Beat)                     downtempo
396            (T.B.I. 25, NYC)                    hip-hop

Leave your belongings at the coat check when you arrive, enjoy a refreshing 
smoothie at the juice bar, stay late for our champagne breakfast, and check 
out the wide variety of art being exhibited. And don't miss the special 
trapeze performances.

This event is a fundraiser for the Infinite Beat's Burning Man multimedia 
art installation and all proceeds go to making the playa a brighter place in 
2004.

For updated info, visit our web site:
http://www.infinitebeat.net

Or check our voicemail at 415.705.0600

Wednesday, December 31, 2003 ** Spundae's Birth of a New Year **

NEW YEARS EVE 2OO4 Birth of a New Year

wednesday, december 31st, 2OO3 SPUNDAE mainroom: 61,529 clubbers from 120
different countries worldwide voted TALL PAUL one of the TOP 2O most
popular DJ on the planet right now by: DJ MAGAZINE 2OO3 TALL PAUL
duty-free recordings / djtallpaul.com / uk One of the UK's best producer
and DJ in the trance scene. Paul has constantly been in the spotlight for
the past 10 years. Currently holding a residency at Turnmills' Friday
nighter The Gallery and plays regularly for Godskitchen, Gatecrasher,
Sundissential, Cream and Golden to name but a few. His popularity has seen
him DJ worldwide travelling to Canada, Japan,Australia, Argentina, Brazil,
Hong Kong, South Africa and all over Europe. Paul is also in the process
of taking the United States by storm, and has dedicated two weeks out of
each month's DJing schedule to concentrate his efforts in this particular
territory.  DAVE RALPH systemrecordings.com / rfactor-recordings.com /
daveralph.com / uk Dave was instrumental in bringing new sounds from
around the world to clubs across the UK (in fact, he was the first person
ever to bring Paul van Dyk to England to spin). He also wrote, reworked
and sang on the Bassheads=92 classic =93Is Anybody Out There?=94 while
establishing his own GLOW Records. Dave spent two years as Paul
Oakenfold=92s support DJ of choice, which gave him the opportunity to trave=
l
the globe honing his skills for international crowds. He later became
resident DJ for Cream in Ibiza, where he spent summers performing for
three consecutive years. THE SCUMFROG thescumfrog.com / positiva / new
york The Scumfrog's widely publicized and much talked about live
performances are not limited to mixing records. They include his live
vocals, percussion, samples, and occasional guest performances. His
colorful live sets and consistently innovative productions landed him on
the cover of DJ magazine in May 2003, and brought him frequent exposure on
Pete Tong's BBC1 radio shows.  GIANNI...spundae frontroom: GARTH 5 hour
set...wicked / grayhound records FRENCHY LE FREAK...frenchylefreak.com
NORMAN STRADLEY...second sunday blueroom: SPESH...looq / qool / bedrock /
rennaisance ALEX WHALEN...arrival soundsystem / r-factor records JONATHAN
OJEDA...spundae / spundae reckords SCOTT CARRELLI...qool / satellite

ABOUT THE HEADLINERS:

DJ Z-TRIP: In the words of Rolling Stone Magazine (in a four-star review),
Z-Trip has "handed rock its head on a vinyl platter." You know the deal.
Z-Trip has developed a reputation worldwide as arguably the best
partyrocking dj of all time, combing everything from rock to hiphop to
jungle to b-boy breaks and everything inbetween. If you don't know, you
better ask somebody. More info at: www.djztrip.com

DISCO D: Tommy Boy Recording artist, Detroit Native, Compression favorite,
and all around slum lord, D flexes the dirty, dirty party rocking jams
with impecable turtablist skills and an uncanny ability to make even the
most rigid butts shake. More info at: www.discod.com

VIKTER DUPLAIX: Representing Philly, Vikter raises roofs worldwide with a
thick blend of funked out house and live vocals. Don't miss this rare live
performance.  More info at: www.hollywoodrecords.com

J BOOGIE=92s DUBTRONIC SCIENCE: Om records =96 J Boogie is a Bay Area
favorite. His hip hop / dub band combines vocals, percussion, sitar, sax,
and turntables.

Wednesday, December 31, 2003 ** ENDUP's NEW YEAR'S MARATHON 2004 **


         On Wednesday December 31, 2003 at 10 PM through Thursday January
1, 2004, at 5 PM, the Endup Nightclub will host another legendary New
Years Marathon. This event will consist of 19 hours of non-stop revelry to
bid farewell to 2003 and auspiciously welcome 2004!
         Once again, the Endup has assembled a wealth of Bay Area DJ
talent for its celebrated New Year=92s Marathon to ensure that 2004 starts
out perfectly. NYE begins with FREQUENCY 3, The BARONESS, JULIUS PAPP,
ADRIAN; TRACY; W. JEREMY. Then, The Endup continues this relentless
regimen of dance floor artistry until 5 PM on New Years Day - with the
exceptional ELLEN FERRATO at 12 noon, followed by a special 3 hour closing
set by the master of deep house - DAVID HARNESS.

        Along with this stellar DJ line-up, the Endup New Year=92s Marathon
2004 will also feature catered food, party favors, a balloon drop, and
midnight toast. Add to the mix - good friends, great cocktails, superb
surroundings, and that special Endup vibe - and you will undoubtedly
experience a perfect start to 2004.

Saturday, January 10, 2004 ** Capricorn presented by Elektrosorcery **

Capricorn, whose constellation is known as Capricornus, is one of the
oldest of the astrological interpretations. Ruled by Saturn, its symbol is
the goat. This is sometimes depicted as a sea borne hybrid or Dolphin. The
image is often an animal with the body of a goat and the tail of a fish.
In one tradition the image represents the god Pan transforming into a sea
creature. A representation, perhaps, of the extremities found within this
Astrological sign. The Capricornian is generally a serious character
possessing a wry sense of humor. Independent, steady as a rock, Capricorn
reflects earthy qualities that range from clever to vacuous. Mostly
cautious, confident, strong willed, reasonable and hard working,
Capricorns are a rock upon which to build.They are capable of great
endurance; a whatever it takes, for as long as it takes persistence.
Reliable in any profession they undertake, but lacking in originality,
they usually excel in following up on what someone else has started. With
Capricorn DJs: DYLOOT, UPHONIC, COVERT, SUNDANCE KID, and more to be
announced. $10 presale $15 at the door.
http://www.hyperreal.org/raves/sf/calendar2/events/view?identifier=3D1013 S=

Saturday, January 17, 2004 ** Cold Phusion Winter Music Festival by BR
Productions, Next Level Promotions, and KCRH 89.9FM **

 he COLD PHUSION Winter Music Festival! Line-up TEASER!!! COLD PHUSION
will feature over 40+ Artists performing on 4 MASSIVE stages of sound! THE
WARP BROS: The legendary Warp Brothers - DJ's Oliver Goedicke and J=FCrgen
Dohr. It did not take a long time and their first single Phatt Bass hit
the German market and made it to the top 3 in the dance charts! Shortly
after this they entered the Sales-Charts Europe wide up to the #2! No
wonder that they draw the music business attention, with placing a solid
techno-track in the sales-charts.Shortly after their uplifting style
flooded Europe, the wave swept over to the US, Canada, Australia and
Japan. You might somehow compare the style of the Warp Brothers to Prodigy
or Chemical Brothers but the truth is that they created their own creative
and unique sound, like you can read in an article of the Face magazine.
Although the Warp Brothers are friendly people - they are in possession of
a lethal weapon, which is called Harder House. Remarkable is their success
in the UK sales-charts #9 and Top 10 positions in several Sales -Charts.In
Denmark they were rewarded with gold. Undoubted the Warpies as they are
keenly called by their fans turn it up on stage! DJ DRC: San Francisco's
Pioneer DJ DRC has relocated to New York City and is geared up to take the
Electronic Music Industry by storm. With her Mixed Album "UNDEFINED" in
the works and a list of releases on IMIX, Vision Music, Off World, Merge,
Twin Soul and her own label Undefined Musik, DRC equivocates the
expeditious pace of her new stomping grounds. Her original music is also
featured in two movies, "Vision of Vibe" with Carl Cox and "Intellect"
being released this February 2003, featuring Paul Van Dyk and many others.
DRC's latest single SEEKER can be heard on the SPANKEE clothing line
websight. With all this under her belt and more, it is obvious DRC has
already had her finger on the pulse of the Big Apple/ Manhattan. DRC
Returns to S.F. for a special set at COLD PHUSION! PLUS MORE CALIFORNIA
SUPERSTARS.... DJ JMARR (BR Productions/Liquid Vinyl DJs), FELIPE AVELAR
(BR Productions/ djfelipeavelar.com / bigfloor traxx), THE DOCTOR (BR
Productions/ Liquid Vinyl DJs) w/ MC FADER (Gravity Crew), DJ ORIONZ (BR
Productions / NextLevelPromotions.net), DOCTOR ROSS (BR Productions/KCRH
89.9FM/M.I.M.E. Recordings) *CD Release Party for Doctor Ross's new CD
"Open Heart Surgery" On M.I.M.E. Recordings!, VALERIE SPARKS (BR
Productions), CARLOS ALFONZO (BR Productions/ YuccaTribe / Deciblast),
JAMES DUB (BR Productions/ Space Monkey), DJ GIRLIE (BR Productions/
lovetribe.net / space monkey / ultrasounz), DJ DOZA (BR Productions/ The
Bounce / KCRH 89.9 FM), CRIS ROX (BR Productions/ M.I.M.E Recordings),
RECLIPSE (BR Productions/ Deciblast), DJ RYAN (Nextlevelpromotions.net)
*CD Release!, OSHY (BR Productions), & DOZENS MORE TO BE ANNOUNCED! PLUS:
Arena 4: Outdoor open air Rock/Alternative/Funk Stage! Outdoor Music Ends
@ 11pm SPECIAL EVENT FEATURES: - 4 Arenas Of Banging Sound! - 40+ DJs &
LIVE Acts! - Amazing Lighting! - Winter Themed Decorations! - Multiple
Stages! - Large Capacity VIRGIN Location! THIS IS A BENEFIT EVENT!! KCRH
89.9FM (College Radio) has launched the careers of many of todays hottest
radio DJs! - but California's budget crisis has hurt this renowned radio
station. Equipment repairs, new equipment, and much more is badly needed.
Profits from Cold Phusion go towards supporting this amazing radio
station, which has stood by the dance and rock scene from the beginning!
KCRH 89.9 is currently home to two of the Bay's most respected DJ Mix
Shows - BR Radio & The Bounce - which plays every Wed Night from
8pm-Midnight! ADDITIONAL INFO: 18+ With Valid ID. Zero Tolerance for
Weapons/Drugs/Alcohol. Tickets Go On Sale SOON - Stay Tuned for more info
